PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt. Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Treasurer.
—The Treasurer is not in the chamber.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that the latest newsletter of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia has called for a detailed inquiry into the role, state, problems and needs of small business in Australia? In view of the call by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, will the Government agree to conduct such an inquiry in order to find solutions to some of the 25 anomalies raised in the newsletter?

—I have noticed the call by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia for the inquiry to which the honourable member referred. The honourable member will be aware that this Government introduced as one of its initiatives to assist small business the Small Business Advisory Council. Recently the Minister for Industry and Commerce asked me to chair that Council. I will be chairing it at its next meeting. It comprises representatives of both employers and trade unions and departmental officers, and, of course, a member of the Opposition traditionally is invited to attend meetings. I expect that this is one of the first matters which will be considered at the next meeting of the Small Business Advisory Council. As soon as that meeting is concluded I will report to Sir Phillip Lynch and the Government as to the appropriate course of action.

—I am glad to see that the Treasurer has now come into the House. My question is addressed to him. Is it a fact that sales tax on such basic household goods as furniture, bedding, cutlery, refrigerators, washing machines, heaters, kitchenware, lighting, floor coverings and electrical goods is being increased by another 50 per cent in this year's Budget? Does this bring the total increase in sales tax on these goods in the past two years to a massive 200 per cent? Is it also a fact that sales tax on such luxury items as jewellery and furs is being increased by only eight per cent, making a total increase over the past two years of just on 18 per cent? Can the Treasurer explain this anomaly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the House for my not being here earlier. I do not accept that the assertion of the honourable member for Henty that this is an anomaly is an accurate description. The fact is that the rate of sales tax on luxury items, as a result of the increases I announced the other night, is to be 32 1/2 per cent. Obviously, if one makes the same increase to each of the three steps in a sales tax scale the percentage increase for items at the top end of the scale will be less than for those at other points in the scale. The honourable member will be aware that, as part of the overall tax package contained in the Budget, there have been some modest increases in sales tax.

ANSWER.PARA: There is advantage in broadening our sales tax base and in reducing the over reliance that our taxation system still has on personal tax as a source of revenue. The honourable member is correct in identifying the items that she has identified as being subject to the sales tax increase. Of course, I draw her attention to the fact that average Australian households will be better off to the tune of $16, $17 or $18 a week net after allowing for those increases after 1 November. Average Australian households overall will be significantly better off in disposable income terms as a result of all of the tax changes I announced in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Technology. In view of the Government's decision to fund the Australia Telescope, which is a very gratifying decision as we are leaders in that field, will he inform the House as to the future of the Starlab space telescope proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Berowra for his question. I know of his great interest in science and technology. I saw a headline in a newspaper which called this a good news Budget. It is certainly a good news Budget with regard to astronomy and Australia's space projects. I have approved the funding of a feasibility study on the Starlab project costing $3.337m over the next two years. It will be funded under the public interest provisions of the Industrial Research Development Incentives Act. I say in passing that the criticism of this Act by the Opposition yesterday was completely ill-informed and that its figures were wrong. The public interest provisions of the Act have been amended to include an advisory committee to advise me in the selection of projects instead of the Department of Science and Technology doing so as it did previously. The first committee meeting was held two weeks ago.

ANSWER.PARA: The Committee, which consists of businessmen and scientists, considered the Starlab project. It made a very strong recommendation that we should fund the feasibility study of this project. I inform honourable members that this is a joint Australian-Canadian-American proposal to place a one metre telescope in earth orbit in 1989 using a National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space shuttle. I see it as a very important project. It is of importance not only to scientists but also to Australian industry. Eighty per cent of the Starlab work will go to Australian firms. Fifteen Australian firms have expressed interest. It will help to get Australia into the space age. If the feasibility study is successful and the Government eventually decides to go ahead with the project it will take us into the next century and beyond. Together with the Australia Telescope it will put us in the forefront of that branch of science. Honourable members may be interested to know that the telescope, which will be in space above the earth's atmosphere--

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the Minister that he draw his answer to a conclusion.

—I will make two more points, if I may. The telescope will see with 100 times more detail objects that are 20 times fainter than those currently detected by any earth telescope. It will be able to look 10 billion years into the past.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. No doubt he will recall making an allowance in the 1981-82 Budget of $300m for revenue losses due to tax avoidance. I refer the Treasurer to the Government's failure to make any allowance for revenue losses due to tax avoidance in this year's Budget. Is the Treasurer aware of the statment on page 62 of Budget Paper No. 1 which refers to the Government's measures to stamp on some of the more notorious examples of tax evasion and avoidance? Does this mean that the remaining notorious examples of tax evasion and avoidance are still operating and likely to cause substantial revenue losses this year? Is the Treasurer also aware of a report in the Press earlier this month that the Australian Taxation Office had identified 100 tax avoidance schemes used by high income earners in recent years, that only about half of those schemes had been legislated against and that it was too early, in the opinion of the Commissioner of Taxation, to identify new schemes used last year? In view of this apparent continued proliferation of tax avoidance schemes, how can the Treasurer possibly justify making no allowances for tax avoidance losses this year in the Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that there is no allowance this year results from advice I received from the Commissioner of Taxation to the effect that no such allowance was necessary. That decision results entirely and exclusively from that information and that advice being tendered to me and to the Government by the Commissioner of Taxation. So far as the reports to which the honourable gentleman referred are concerned, if the honourable gentleman's real knowledge and understanding of this issue were evident he would know that in May of last year this Parliament, with the support of the Opposition, passed a new general anti-avoidance section which will have the effect, from that date, of prohibiting blatant artifical tax avoidance arrangements. It is the growing opinion, not only of the Taxation Office and the Government's official advisers but also of many private sector people who have knowledge of these matters, that the Government's anti-tax avoidance legislation has been remarkably effective. My colleague the honourable member for Macarthur, in the debate on Tuesday on tax avoidance, produced a letter from the National Chairman of Coopers and Lybrand, one of the most respected firms of accountants in Australia, to the effect that our-

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer will resume his seat. I will not permit the Treasurer to continue until there is silence in the chamber.

—Perhaps I should amend my answer to say that my esteemed and valued friend and colleague the honourable member for Macarthur produced in that debate a letter from the National Chairman of Coopers and Lybrand, one of the most respected firms of chartered accountants in Australia, which contained the unequivocal statement that tax avoidance in Australia is dead and that the credit for that achievement belongs to this Government and the Treasurer in this Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE: AMWSU HEALTH CARE LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer to the Minister's recent announcement that he has approved the registration of AMWSU Health Care Ltd as a health fund under the National Health Act. What does the AMWSU proposal imply for the Goverment's health insurance program? How would AMWSU Health Care Ltd be affected by the Australian Labor Party's health proposals?

—The Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union did put forward a proposal to set up a private health fund under the Government's private health insurance scheme. It was an interesting commentary, indeed, on the support of a union organisation for private health funds, in marked contrast to the treatment it would get under the Labor Party, whose policy would cause that fund to be closed down. If there is an extension of the closed health funds and if the numbers in those funds build up too much and take healthy insured people out of the general funds, the Government has an obvious concern that the community rating principle of the general open funds might in some way be damaged. This matter was considered very carefully by the Department of Health and by me. The maximum number of people that are likely to come into the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union fund is about 180,000, against the total in the open funds of about 10 million people. My advice is that this will not have a substantial effect on the community rating principle. There may be other applications. I understand one was mentioned in the Press this morning and it will be considered in the same way on its merits. It is quite important to see a union which has certain influences within the Opposition party coming out so clearly against the Labor Party's health proposals. In my discussions with the union officials I pointed out to them the dangers that they were entering into should there be a Labor government because their fund would be closed down by such a government coming into office.

—I ask the the Treasurer a simple question: In view of his firm assurance to the House that the tax avoidance industry is now dead, will he give an equally firm assurance to the House that, apart from the foreshadowed retrospective legislation, this House will see no more legislation in relation to tax avoidance because it will no longer be required?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only repeat that the legislation that has been passed by this Government has been the most effective anti-tax avoidance legislation. The statements to which I have referred in my previous reply are statements of the chairman of partners of one of the most respected firms of chartered accountants in Australia. They mirror many other statements that--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that as the Treasurer attempts to answer this question there is continual noise, which is quite unnecessary. The honourable gentleman is entitled to make his reply in silence.

—I can only repeat that the statement to which I referred was a statement of a Mr Cameron, who is the Chairman of Coopers and Lybrand which is not only one of the most respected firms but also one of the largest firms of chartered accountants in Australia. It reflects the views of many other firms of chartered accountants and many other legal firms throughout Australia, the views of the Government's own Taxation Advisory Committee, the views of the Australian Taxation Office and the views of many people who have, in fact, followed this particular issue and this particular debate over the years. From the time that the Government and not the Opposition made fighting tax avoidance an issue in this Parliament from April 1978 the cumulative view of all of those people is that the action the Government has taken and the legislation this Parliament has passed have been remarkably effective and demonstrate what we have repeatedly claimed, namely, that this Government has done more than any other to stamp out and to keep stamped out tax avoidance practices in Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GOVERNMENT EXPENDITURE ON SEARCHES FOR LOST AUSTRALIANS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport aware that as a nation and through his Department we must be spending some millions of dollars on searches for Australians lost in various ways at sea? Is the Minister aware that a justified search for a woman lost yesterday off a boat near Gladstone is under way? Is the Minister aware that recently a lost windsurfer was actually found at sea by a search aeroplane and then lost and he is now presumed drowned? Is the Minister aware that a Queenslander has invented a drifting marker that, with some simple addition, could provide a light and radio homing-in point for both daylight and after dusk aircraft searching? In view of the costliness of searching and the much to be desired efficiency of searching as shown by the windsurfer example, will the Minister have this $150 flashing marker, which I display to the House, which will drift with a person or a lost craft, examined to ascertain its suitability as required standard equipment on search aircraft and even pleasure and fishing boats?

—That is some flasher. The honourable member for Fadden brought this matter to my attention recently. I discussed the concept with the Department. I should like to give the honourable member an assurance that I will have the device thoroughly tested and evaluated to see whether it is better than the equipment currently being used. But it is true that costs for marine searches are very high indeed in Australia. We anticipate each year an estimated expenditure of about $1m. For instance, as I understand it, the search for the windsurfer cost $185,000. It was unfortunate that, although he was sighted on one occasion, due to bad weather the searchers were unable to sight him again. There is no doubt that a device that was satisfactory-a device perhaps of this nature-may have helped locate that unfortunate victim of the sea. I thank the honourable member for bringing this device to my attention. I should like him to assure the person who invented it that it will be thoroughly tested and evaluated.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to allegations that merchant banks, including the Nugan Hand operation, could have been involved in international arms dealings through Australia. Is the Prime Minister aware that the same merchant banks now appear to have been involved in tax avoidance and tax minimisation, bearing in mind a report to the Victorian Corporate Affairs Commission which states that a large number of companies not referred to in the McCabe-Lafranchi report appear to have been so involved and have a connection with those merchant banks, and in fact operate from an address in Collins Street, Melbourne? Is it a fact that those merchant banks and those companies have some association with the painters and dockers inquiry? Is the Prime Minister aware of any fraud on the Commonwealth revenue as a result of those operations? Is it not a fact that the commissioner inquiring into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union furnished an interim report to the Government as far back as 27 July which has still not been tabled in this Parliament and which contains a chapter relating to the amount of fraud on the Commonwealth revenue? Can the Prime Minister indicate the extent of the fraud disclosed in that report, and will he give an explanation as to why that report has not been tabled in this Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a report and a copy has gone to the Victorian Government. I was wondering how long it would take before a question came to me as a result of that.
—I have given you three days-three days this week.

—Yes. I thank the honourable member very much for those three days. The last interim report of the royal commissioner has three parts to it. He recommends that two of those volumes should not be published because he believes that that would impede investigations which he wishes to pursue further . There is one chapter in the report that did not go to the Victorian Government officially, which I think is the chapter to which the honourable member referred in his question. The Commonwealth wanted to be in a position, and will be in a position next Tuesday, to table its response to the report at the same time as tabling the report in this Parliament. I earlier saw a newspaper report that the Victorian Premier was intending to publish the report even though his Parliament was not sitting. I wrote to him suggesting that it would be more appropriate for the report to be tabled in the Parliament. Indeed, I think that earlier newspaper report was probably referring to something that was said before the report had been read. I suspect that there would be very substantial problems and difficulties for anyone who published this report not under the privilege of parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that there was a letter from the Victorian Premier to the Attorney -General-this is subject to confirmation, and if it is not correct I will advise the House later-suggesting that there should be simultaneous tabling in the Victorian Parliament and the Commonwealth Parliament when the Victorian Parliament resumes its sittings, I think early in September. For our part we believe the report ought to be tabled as soon as possible. It is the Attorney- General's intention to do that on Tuesday. The Government has been examining the matter very closely over more than one meeting in the course of this week and initially also last week because it wanted to make up its mind about some recommendations. We wanted to be able to indicate to the Parliament the very substantial actions that the Government would be taking as a consequence of the report. That will be done next Tuesday and the honourable gentleman's anxiety can then be assuaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer seen some suggestions that the example used on Tuesday night of the impact of the Budget on average Australian families is not representative? Can he inform the House of the situation regarding the Budget's impact upon two-income families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a suggestion this morning in at least one newspaper to the effect that the example that I used in the Budget Speech of the impact of taxation and other changes on a single income family comprising two children and a dependent spouse with a weekly income of $300 was not very representative. According to what I understand to be the most recent statistics of families in Australia with dependent children approximately 50 per cent of them involve two incomes and about 50 per cent involve a single income. I understand that the statistics are perhaps a year or two old but they are nonetheless the most recent. Thus to that extent I reject the claim that the example I used was unrepresentative, but that is not really the point of the matter. The point is that the benefits contained in the Budget for double income families in roughly equivalent circumstances are very real indeed.

ANSWER.PARA: If we take the case of a double income family receiving a total weekly income of $400 a week-many double income families in Australia would be receiving much more than $400 a week-and if we assume that there was a split of 60-40 between the partners in contributing to that income the family would still have gross benefits under the Budget of $18.69 a week less some adjustment in respect of indirect taxation of some $3 or $4 a week. So the benefits would be very real. If we take a double income family with a total weekly income of $500-there would be many thousands of Australian families in modest circumstances where, as a result of two incomes, the total household income would be about $500 a week-the gain from the taxation and other changes in the Budget will be $20.69 a week before allowance is made for the effect of the indirect tax increases. Certainly I do not pretend for a moment that every family in Australia is represented by an example of a husband, dependent wife and two children, although when children are young that is still representative of a very significant number of Australian families. The Budget's provisions quite designedly had the position of those families in mind when it spelt out the taxation changes that it did. Likewise the benefits that flow to double income families are also very real. They are equivalent and on all fours with the concessions that have been made to single income families.

The other point I make is that the dollar increase which has been made in the sole parent rebate represents a more generous treatment of that category of taxpayers than has been the case in the past when rebates have been adjusted. On other occasions when the dependent spouse rebate has been adjusted the increase to the sole parent rebate has been proportionate to the increase in the dependent spouse rebate. On this occasion we have increased the sole parent rebate by precisely the same dollar amount as the spouse rebate has been increased. To that extent we have marginally improved the position of sole parents in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Is the Government imposing extra costs on drought stricken primary producers by changing the diesel fuel excise exemption to a rebate? Does the Government know that fuel costs represent a high proportion of farm cash costs, for example, 13 per cent for wheat growers ? Will farmers have to fill in a form to get the rebate? How long will rebate applications take to process? Will the rebate not be repaid until taxation returns are processed at the end of the year? Who was making $176m out of the previous farm exemption system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The changes that I announced on Tuesday night do not represent by any stretch of the imagination discrimination against primary producers. Indeed, to the extent that the Government has decided to retain a situation where primary producers do not bear the excise on off-road distillate, the Budget has in fact deliberately discriminated in favour of primary producers. Any suggestion that the Budget is some kind of visitation of difficulty on drought affected farmers plainly means that the honourable gentleman has not read the Budget documentation. What the Government has done is to introduce a rebate system for enjoyment of the exemption and has abolished the old system because it was subject to fraud. It was subject to abuse and there was evidence that people were using distillate purchased excise-free for on-road and not off-road purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: The only thing the Government could reasonably do in the circumstances, whilst protecting those areas of the economy which it believed were deserving of continued protection including, particularly in the light of the present drought , primary producers, was to introduce the system that we in fact introduced. The rebates will be processed rapidly. People entitled to them will not have to wait for the end of the year. Rebates will not be handled by the Taxation Office. They will be handled by the Australian Bureau of Customs. Additional staff will be recruited to handle the new system. It will work better and more fairly to the benefit of all concerned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Ian Cameron having addressed a question to the Minister for Trade and Resources-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is out of order. He is asking a question based on a hypothetical proposition.

—I refer the Minister for Primary Industry to the Government's Budget decision to allocate $6.5m to the Burdekin River Scheme in Queensland and the dependence of the viability of this scheme on sugar production in the Burdekin Valley. Is it the Government's intention to facilitate the growing of sugar cane in the Ord irrigation area? Does the Minister agree with those opposed to the development of Ord sugar or does he agree with his Country Party and Liberal colleagues in Western Australia who favour it?

—The growing of sugar cane in the Ord has been a matter of serious conversation between the Queensland Government and the Western Australian Government. The position that the Commonwealth has adopted in respect of this matter is simply to state that it has no jurisdiction to make decisions in respect of land use at either the Ord River or any other part of Australia. Therefore, a decision as to the growing of sugar cane in Western Australia has to be of necessity a decision taken by the Western Australian Government. The Commonwealth can have no say in that matter.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of the Victorian Premier's allegation that Victoria is unfairly treated in respect of drought relief under the natural disaster relief arrangement because of the requirement that the State must meet in full the first $7m of expenditure? Is this allegation true?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The support arrangements in respect of natural disasters have been long standing and have worked very smoothly between the States. Until the intervention of Mr Cain, they seem to have worked in a fairly co-operative fashion. For example, in relation to previous droughts, a number of States have proposed specific additional measures because of the circumstances of those droughts and, I think, overwhelmingly the Commonwealth has accepted additional measures that might be relevant to the circumstances of those States. There is a core list of measures which receive the automatic approval and support of the Commonwealth. That is well known to all State governments. If there are other specific measures which any State would like the Commonwealth to consider, it will do so expeditiously and quickly. I understand that in Victoria at the moment a drought has been declared in one shire, the Shire of Kerang.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth noting that there is a base level of funds which each State is meant to provide before the Commonwealth is involved. Thereafter the Commonwealth provides $3 for every dollar provided by the States. So if it is a significant and major disaster, obviously the Commonwealth would be providing the bulk of the funds. The base levels for the different States are: New South Wales, $10m; Victoria, $7m; Queensland, $4m; South Australia, $3m; Western Australia, $3m; Tasmania, $1.2m; and the Northern Territory, $0.25m. Those base levels were last set in 1978-79. So the real value of those base levels has obviously been reduced over time through inflation. They have not been adjusted as State revenues have significantly increased during that period. Therefore, the base levels would represent a considerably lesser proportion of and a lesser burden on State funds than would have been the case in 1978-79 when those base sums were first set.

I hope very much that the Victorian Goverment will continue the close co- operation with the Commonwealth in the management of natural disasters because the omens for the period ahead of us are very bad indeed. The weather patterns seem to be set in a way which is offering no relief over large parts of eastern Australia. In Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria a large part of the cropping areas is already facing total disaster. That applies to New South Wales in particular. The pastoral areas could still be saved but the likelihood of that happening in a major way is, I believe, remote. I hope earnestly that that view will be demonstrated to be totally false, but once this weather pattern sets in it is unlikely to alter. We could be facing the worst drought we have had for many decades, beyond the living memory of most members of this House.

Against that backgound we will need the circumstances in which governments are prepared to co-operate and to work together. It is quite the wrong time to be arguing about the long-accepted arrangements which have existed between the Commonwealth and the States in relation to the support of individuals who might be hurt in these matters. The Commonwealth-I have advised the Premier of this- stands ready to meet its obligations, as it has in past years. The total obligations in support of drought relief have been $100m over the last two years -very substantial indeed. Probably only a relatively small part of that amount was spent in Victoria because the drought has been much worse in other States. Under the present weather patterns, Victoria could be engulfed by drought just as much as New South Wales, Queensland or parts of Western Australia. But it will take a little while to see whether that fear is confirmed or whether the weather pattern breaks and a reasonable season unfolds in a significant part of Victoria and elsewhere.

Potentially, rural parts of Australia are facing an extremely serious and damaging situation and they are doing so at a time when stock prices are low because of depressed world markets. Farmers and farming organisations will need the co-operation of governments. I only wish that Mr Cain would get on with the business of accepting his obligations as they have been accepted by previous governments in all States on previous occasions. Whenever Queensland, Western Australia or New South Wales have suggested special measures because of particular circumstances in their States those special measures have almost overwhelmingly been accepted by the Commonwealth as part of the pattern of arrangements that ought to be supported. There are core measures which the Premier knows full well we will apply forthwith and without consultation to any area which his State designates as a drought area in Victoria. I hope this sniping and passing of the buck in relation--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister is answering a question about a matter of major public importance. I ask honourable members on Opposition benches to remain silent so that the answer can be given and heard.

—I can only put forward a plea that Mr Cain adopt a spirit of working together in relation to this matter. It represents a major potential disaster for many thousands of people in rural areas and many thousands of people in provincial cities. It will need the co-operation of governments if we are to work our way through it. I hope that the State will accept its obligations.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. On the basis of the best estimates available to him within his Department, what does the Minister believe the average level of unemployment benefit recipients will be for the year 1982-83?
—Is that what you said yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat what I said yesterday: My Department is not responsible for estimating unemployment benefit recipients. Those estimates are for average unemployment benefit recipients. Those estimates are made by the Department of the Treasury and administered by the Department of Social Security. I have no reason to disbelieve those figures. What I said and what I am pleased to say in terms of my Department's estimates is that I think the unemployment rate next year, certainly around February-March, will be in the order of 8 per cent. That is based on the forecast of no economic growth and on the fact that a number of people will be entering the work force. We base it on surveys of the employment shedding which is now occurring. I think it is a reasonable estimate-I know the Treasurer expressed the same view yesterday-that we will be looking at an unemployment rate, probably around February or March, of about or slightly above 8 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I do not know how many of those people will be eligible for unemployment benefit, nor do I know what the average number will be throughout the year. Many of the people who, in fact, might be retrenched might move on to other social security arrangements, such as those associated with early retirement, and many others will not necessarily satisfy the criteria for unemployment benefit, especially if they were second income earners in their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Department thought about it at all?

—I am saying that on the estimates available to us for the early months of next year one would expect that until we can place school leavers we will have figures in the order of 8 per cent. The aspect of this Budget that is most important is that if there is a sensible approach to hours of work and wages over the next 12 months the unemployment figure need not get any worse than the 8 per cent I have mentioned. Therefore, the average number of persons receiving unemployment benefit ought not itself to get worse.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. It relates to the proposed rebate system for diesel fuel excise. Which categories of diesel users that were previously eligible for the exemption are now not eligible? Will the new arrangements announced in the Budget relating to the excise rebate be of any benefit to private transport operators and private contractors generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generally speaking, those categories which will no longer be exempt will include construction industry, sections of manufacturing that were enjoying the exemption, electricity generation and transport-particularly public transport. In fact, I think the area which will probably contribute the largest amount in terms of gain to revenue from the withdrawal of the concession will be government railways.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable gentleman asked me what impact the withdrawal of the concession will have on private road transport. In all probability it will improve the competitive position of private road contractors because they will be in a much stronger competitive position with government railways. Hitherto government railways have enjoyed what some would see as the unfair competitive advantage of not paying the excise in respect of the diesel fuel that they consume whereas their competitors, as private road transport contractors, have had to pay the excise. I would say that with the removal of that benefit the position of those private road contractors-the position of truckies, for example-will be significantly improved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer a question. He will recall that a little earlier in Question Time he invoked with some enthusiasm the public repute of Coopers and Lybrand in relation to claims which he made that tax avoidance was dead. Has he had the opportunity to consider the McCabe-Lafranchi report, especially volume 2, which names Coopers and Lybrand as one of the vendors, agents or representatives for an organisation or firm involved in tax avoidance or evasion , namely, Trison Pty Ltd? Did he seek to invoke Coopers and Lybrand on the basis of their practical experience in this field?

—I was perfectly aware, when I gave the answer that I did, that Coopers and Lybrand were referred to in the McCabe report. I would have thought that the authority of people to speak on this subject had something to do with their practical knowledge and understanding of what has gone on in the tax avoidance industry. If one wants to understand what has happened in this area one should not confine one's examination to a reliance on the views of people who have absolutely no practical understanding of what goes on.

—Has the Prime Minister been made aware of the charge by Mr Cain, the Premier of Victoria, that the Commonwealth has framed the Budget to punish Victoria for voting Labor? Is this true? Can the Prime Minister outline to the House the benefits Victoria will receive from the Commonwealth Budget and the Commonwealth's policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assertions by the Premier of Victoria seem to rely on a very inadequate understanding of the Budget Papers, by his failure to read those Papers and to understand what they mean to the State. Some payments of a specific purpose character are included in the total payments for all States but they have not yet been allocated among the States. These include, for example, the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program and some water programs which have not been allocated among the States in the Budget Papers. As a consequence, whereas total payments to the States increased by 13.4 per cent the increase to Victoria in presently allocated payments in the Budget Papers is 12 per cent. I am advised that that is the position for all States.

ANSWER.PARA: In many ways Victoria does much better than a number of other States. Its general revenue grants will rise by 11.6 per cent against the six States average of 10.8 per cent, which is greater than the increase for Queensland and Western Australia which are not and never will become Labor States. Its basic tax sharing grant, leaving aside the special $60m that was made over 15 months ago to benefit the beneficiary States under the changes to the tax allocations formula, was up 17 per cent compared with 13.8 per cent for South Australia, and 13 per cent for Western Australia and Tasmania. Again, this shows Victoria doing very much better than those other three States. Its specific purpose recurrent grants will rise by 16.3 per cent against the six States average of 15.3 per cent-a greater increase than for South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania . Its general purpose capital grants will rise by 5 per cent-the same percentage as the other States. Half of that amount was allocated for welfare housing. At this point I remind the House that we also indicated that if the States wished to increase further their funds for welfare housing from their general purpose capital grants we would do so under the terms and conditions of the Commonwealth -State Housing Agreement which, of course, is more favourable to the States than the terms of the general purpose capital grants. There is potential for additional sums to be made available for welfare housing as a result of that decision by the Commonwealth.

It is worth noting also that Victoria benefits very specifically from other areas of Commonwealth policy. I add that those areas at times give trouble to members in other States. Because of the nature of industry in Victoria-the preponderance of manufacturing industry-it has benefited and is benefiting very greatly from the general decisions that we made in relation to the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the motor industries. Victoria also stands to benefit very greatly indeed from the general provisions that we introduced for improved depreciation provisions for all Australian industry. These advantages to Victoria will be very substantial indeed. Mr Cain cannot sustain the charge of bias against Victoria. The figures show quite plainly that Victoria has been very fairly treated and the proper position of Victoria has been very well recognised in the decisions of the Commonwealth.
