SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this time of the year-Budget time-we hear a great deal about tax avoidance and tax evasion and companies structured for that purpose. Today I wish to comment on a private company in Melbourne which imports aircraft, both new and second hand. This company is chaired by a former Minister in the Fraser Government, Mr Tony Staley. The company today is known as Jet Corporation of Australia. Let me outline to the House the type of company for which this former Minister now acts as chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Australian advertising supplement of Wednesday 28 April, which I have with me, it is stated:
The company looks at aircraft sales and servicing from an investment angle.
It is an entirely investment project, not a love affair with aeroplanes or a way of making a living.
They can even formulate a five-year plan for development with firm estimates of turnover and profitability.
The supplement contains a large photograph of the men at the helm of Jet Corporation: Mr Trevor Huttley, the deputy chairman; Mr Tony Staley, chairman; and Mr Jon Wilson, managing director.

Mr Jon Wilson and Mr Trevor Huttley were two of the main personalities concerned when the veteran Schutt Aviation organisation was taken over in 1978. At that time the two men had a colleague in the business by the name of Edward Sent. Mr Sent sold his shares in the business in 1981 for a reported $4m to the company now headed by the former Minister, Mr Staley. Mr Sent, of Summit Drive, Eaglemont, Victoria appeared in a Sydney court on 3 October 1980 charged with obtaining credit of $110,000 by false pretences.

I shall now deal with a particular case of fraud and deception in which I believe these men have engaged. On 25 June 1981-at the end of the financial year -a Spanish aircraft was flown into this country. The aircraft was destined to be purchased by a syndicate of South Australians organised by a South Australian solicitor, Mr Alex Payer. On the surface this looks like the normal type of business investment which flourished under the Fraser Government's 40 per cent investment allowance policies-investments basically indulged in by many wealthy people in order to take advantage of this Government's policies. However, these contemporaries of Mr Staley defrauded those investors in a big way. The aircraft involved was declared for taxation purposes as a new aircraft as only new aircraft were eligible for the investment allowance. The aircraft itself was a Casa 200 series 212. It was four years of age, with close to one thousand flying hours up, and had first flown in 1978. The value of the aircraft was close to $ 1m. It would be interesting to be able to have access to the Customs declarations which would clearly show the import price of the aircraft.

I asked the Bureau of Customs to make further inquiries. I have the reply to my letter of 2 August from Mr Kilkenny, who is the Collector of Customs in Victoria . He says that the matter has been referred to the appropriate section of the Bureau for further inquiries. I suggest that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) should get involved to see what is going on in some of these companies. This company sold the $1m used aircraft to an aviation syndicate of South Australia as a new aircraft for more than $2m. This syndicate never inspected the aircraft. They relied upon the good name and integrity established by the Arthur Schutt organisation, whose integrity was unchallenged in the industry for 36 years. These men took over that organisation in 1978. They could not start up a business such as that overnight as the Department of Aviation would have to license them and the whole matter would involve a lot of time, money and trouble. It was much easier for them to buy out an existing licensed organisation with a good reputation if they could afford it, and this was done. With that actual organisation they also bought the fabulous goodwill which was built up all over the nation by one man, Arthur Schutt, M.B.E. Mr Schutt started operations before the war, survived Royal Australian Air Force service and, as soon as he could get organised after it, started his own operation at Essendon in 1947. This organisation is in business for one reason- investment. When Mr Schutt sold out, he said:
I got to the point where I had to have big money to continue. Aeroplanes cost a lot of money . . .
That takes big capital-you get no interest on that . . .

At that time Mr Schutt was still a major personality in the organisation and a father figure. He was very valuable to the company because of his image. Let us look at what these men were able to do and the sort of money they have been able to put together to put these operations into practice. To illustrate this point, I quote from a supplement of the Australian. It states:

It would be no exaggeration to say that when news got out of JetCorp's formation a year ago, the industry was staggered. No other general aviation venture had ever brought in big investors on the scale and standing that JetCorp attracted.

The Board is impressed for what its members represent. There is the former Minister of Posts and Telecommunications, Mr Tony Staley, who is taking an increasing part in the day-to-day running of the firm though he is not a fulltime chairman. He finds it fascinating. His deputy is Mr T. B. Huttley, well known Melbourne accountant who built up his own firm. Mr Peter Russell represents Simon, Lidgett Collingwood, the stock exchange firm which was the key to the new organisation. Mr Marc Besen represents Sussan Lingerie and the big plastics firm of M. E. Hogg and Co. has three members on the Board. Messrs B. Collier, M. Hogg and L. Hogg with Mr S. Higgs representing T & G. Mr Jon Wilson is of course the Managing Director. From the standpoint of big finance the great name is that of Sir Andrew Grimwade, a legend in Melbourne.

Investors also include three banks, the State Electricity Commission's Retirement Benefit Fund, ACI and other prestige organisations whose very name is a guarantee of solidity. They have never invested in this sort of project before .
The first step was to provide $15,000,000 capital.
As Mr Wilson says-
This was quoted at the start of my speech-
This is the first time a general aviation organisation has been formed on such a scale that it can and does look at aircraft sales and servicing from the investment angle.

At a time when the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is telling the House that tax evasion and tax avoidance has ceased in this country-the Budget figures clearly show this-this company has clearly entered into a situation in the last 12 months with one purpose in mind; that is, of bringing aircraft into this country for investment for taxation purposes. The point that I believe should be brought to the attention of the Australian people and to this Parliament is that these men are not beyond doctoring the books and they are not beyond bringing in secondhand aircraft. I am raising this matter because I want the Treasurer to have an investigation conducted. There is no way an ordinary person can get the Customs documents needed to prove the case completely. But my information is that the aircraft is clearly four years old and that it was brought into the country on 25 June. In fact the date was specified. It had to be in on that date for the very purpose of being sold to this company in South Australia.

If an aircraft comes into Australia and is genuinely passed through Customs at $1m there is no fraud. Of course, the Customs documents genuinely declare a secondhand aircraft. But if that aircraft is then sold to another company of unsuspecting investors at a price in excess of $2m and declared as a new aircraft, the Government is defrauded of massive amounts of taxation. At that time a 40 per cent investment allowance-some $800,000-was defrauded from the Taxation Office. Here we have an instance in which clearly over $1m profit was made on the sale of one aircraft and the Government dipped out on some $800,000 in genuine revenue from taxation. I do not believe that the people in my electorate who are paying their taxes should have to bear the cost of public expenditure in this country while organisations and people in this country are prepared to do those types of things.

In the last couple of weeks that very company sacked Arthur Schutt, a man whom it promised could have his job for life, and also sacked 20 employees because it is in great difficulty. The aircraft it brought into Australia and sold to investors is sitting on the tarmac and the company is doing very little. Company representatives declared that they intended to make that company public in 1983. I hope that the Treasurer will see fit to investigate quickly the allegations I make here today. If that aircraft has been brought in and is clearly proven to be that secondhand aircraft which I claim it is, those people ought to be made to pay the penalty for defrauding this country and going ahead with taxation concession schemes which clearly should be outlawed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union commenced on 1 October 1981. The terms of reference of that Royal Commission required the Commissioner to inquire into whether the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union or any officer or member of the Union had been engaged in illegal activities in relation to shipping. The direction to the Commission went on in some detail to express the particulars of the terms of reference. A great deal of evidence has been given before that Commission, including evidence on 23 April 1981 in relation to criminal records of members of the executive. The Commission has already brought in an interim report which we have not yet seen and it is due to finish its investigations by 31 December of this year. A report of the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 April 1981 amongst other things states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Douglas Meagher, assisting the commissioner, said the 11-man executive had a total of 251 convictions, an average of 23 a man.
Mr Meagher said the number of convictions for each ranged from three to 61.
The same article later states:
Mr Meagher said nine members of the union executive had served prison sentences -a total of 41 years and seven months.
He said the total fines paid by the 11 men totalled $6,687.
He said they had committed offences in every State and all but two had used aliases.
Ten had been convicted within the past 10 years and six within the past three.
Mr Meagher said the offences included street offences (offensive behaviour and minor offences), firearm offences, harbouring, arson, theft, assault, and, in one case, robbery with violence.

The question I think all honourable members would ask themselves is this: How is it that a union in this country could have an executive with a record that that executive has? The very great majority of unions in this country are very well served by their executive. One must ask these questions: Is it in the members' interests that they should have that sort of executive? Is it in the interests of the public that they have that sort of executive? I would have thought the answer was very simply no and that there was much to be said for the introduction of legislation along the lines of legislation which will be found in the Companies Act which, in certain circumstances, disqualifies people from holding office in companies and imposes a variety of duties upon office holders. In particular, sections 227 and 229 of the Companies Act 1981 deal with those matters. Amongst other things section 227 provides that a person who has been convicted on indictment of any offence in connection with the promotion, formation or management of a corporation or of any offence involving fraud or dishonesty punishable on conviction by imprisonment for a period of not less than three months shall not, within five years after his conviction, be in any way, whether directly or indirectly, concerned or take part in the management of a corporation. Provision is there for an offence which is punishable by a fine and a gaol sentence.

Section 229 deals with somewhat different matters, namely, the duties and liabilities of officers. Section 229 sub-section (1) states that an officer of a corporation is required at all times to act honestly in the exercise of his powers and the discharge of the duties of his office. Section 229 sub-section (2 ) states:
An officer . . . shall at all times exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence in the exercise of his powers and the discharge of his duties.
Sub-section (3) of section 229 states:

An officer . . . shall not make improper use of information acquired by virtue of his position . . . to gain, directly or indirectly, an advantage for himself or for any other person or cause detriment to the corporation.

Sub-section (4) states that an officer is prevented from making improper use of his position. Breaches of all those provisions attract criminal sanctions. These provisions apply to all corporations, to all companies, no matter how small or how large, from the small family company to the largest of corporations. There is no good reason why legislation to a similar effect, with modifications appropriate to reflect the different functions and the different nature of registered organisations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-I refer to employer and employee organisations; particularly trade unions in this context- should not be placed upon such organisations. Obviously there is a very sound and fundamental reason for this and that is to prevent people who are utterly unfit by past conduct from holding office. In the case of a person convicted under the Companies Act, after his discharge from gaol-or where there has not been a gaol sentence, after the conviction-in the subsequent period of five years he can apply to the court for permission to hold office. The same kind of provision could apply to registered organisations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

The opportunities for abuse or misuse of the positions held on the executive of a registered organisation-I am thinking in particular of an organisation such as the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia, or indeed any major union-are too obvious to need stating. After all, these days registered organisations, depending, of course, on their size, have access to large funds. The officers of the organisations have an obligation one would think to act solely in the interests of their members, not perhaps disregarding entirely the interests of the general public. Surely office holders should enjoy the trust and confidence of the rank and file and the respect of the general public. In the kind of example that I have put to this House it could never be said that they should enjoy the trust and confidence of the rank and file and, certainly, it could never be said that they could enjoy the respect of the general public.

In answer to a question earlier today the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that next Tuesday, if my recollection is correct, the Commonwealth's response to the interim report of the Royal Commission into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union would be made known. I hope this Government will consider immediately and carefully the introduction of legislation imposing disqualifications and obligations similar to those provided for under the Companies Act. I hope that if the Government takes that course all honourable members of this House will support legislation to that effect as being in the interests not only of union members but also of the general public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several months ago two old friends, a husband and wife, came to my electorate office. I knew they had just retired. Unfortunately they were very distressed. They had gone to ITP-the Income Tax Professionals-in Burwood to have their final income tax return prepared. The manager knew they were receiving a lump sum for long service leave. Mr Jeff Watt J.P. attended them. He suggested that a good tax avoidance scheme was to place their money in the Alpex Commodity Traders Ltd and therefore they would not lose their fringe benefits. Their big concern was to keep their fringe benefits. After a lifetime of working the husband put $12,000 long service leave money, on the advice of ITP, into Alpex Commodity Traders and that chain of companies. Unfortunately this money is now substantially lost.

SPEECH.PARA: I am afraid this incident opened a Pandora's box for me not just at the action of ITP in taking a secret commission, for selling and promoting this Alpex Commodity Traders, but for the whole number and range of schemes in the community in which elderly folk, retired people, or people about to retire are encouraged to place their funds and thereby obtain the fringe benefits. There are many schemes floating in the community and these give me great concern. The Alpex scheme is well known and has had considerable publicity. The original chartered accountants involved with the scheme, Walker, Meares and Co., miraculously are still acting for the receivers. Apparently there appears to be no conflict of interest for Walker, Meares and Co. My constituents had one aim and that was to keep the medical card. I told them that only the Australian Labor Party offers a decent, fair and honest health scheme. For a small payment we will again have Medibank, which will be fair to the patients, fair to the doctors and fair to the hospitals.

I have noted and I have been approached by various pensioner groups about an organisation called the Australian Retired Persons Association friendly society. I am sure this organisation is an honest organisation, but it is doing what Alpex was doing. It is seeking money from retired people. It is advertising even in many of the papers circulated to pensioners. Another organisation, Brick Securities Ltd, is doing the same thing. They are taking advantage of certain tax provisions available to them under the Friendly Societies Act. They are registering in Victoria and soliciting money in the other States, particularly New South Wales, without any legal basis. In fact, I am told that, under the New South Wales Friendly Societies Act, it is illegal to solicit money in that State . Yet in the May-June 1982 issue of Reveille there appears an advertisement directed to retired members. The article states:
You can now invest . . . 13 1/2% Per Annum Tax Free and without affecting your entitlement to the Service Pension or Fringe Benefits.

In the Budget we are told that there is no tax avoidance. Yet these retired people and ex-servicemen are putting money into these schemes of the Australian Retired Persons Association and into Brick Securities. The Government is pledged to stop any tax avoidance through these schemes. These people are putting their funds at risk in these schemes. There must be a clampdown on these schemes and a plugging of the loophole which enables them to get around the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

It is of great concern to me that the Australian Retired Persons Association is actively promoting throughout Australia a week it is calling Senior Australia Week. It is claiming that this week has the support of organisations of high standing such as the Council of the Aging in New South Wales and that is untrue. I have been told by members of the executive of that organisation that they are most concerned that Senior Australia Week is being promoted by the Australian Retired Persons Association, which puts out a newsletter called Silver Power. It is being promoted not to advance the interests of our senior citizens but merely to promote the interests of the Australian Retired Persons Association friendly society. This organisation quite clearly is after the funds of the retired. This is a genuine business undertaking. I have no quibble about that. What I am complaining about is that it is a scheme aimed at getting the savings of the pensioners and it is offering tax free advantages.

In the Budget we have a statement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) which is endorsed by the Government that all these tax free loopholes will be plugged and that there will be no tax advantages. The senior citizens, pensioners and retired people are being deceived by these organisations. They are being deceived by the Australian Retired Persons Association, by Brick Securities and by similar schemes operating under the Victorian Friendly Societies Act. This matter is of great concern to me because it involves a group of people who are not endowed with financial expertise and are not used to dealing with securities and investments. My friends who brought this matter to my attention had previously never entered an investment of this nature in their lives. Yet, they signed over $12,000 to Alpex Commodity Traders Ltd and lost most of this money.

I feel that the Federal Government, as the Government with responsibility for pensioners and senior citizens, must act together with the States to ensure that the pensioners do not lose their savings. This area of senior citizens' investment is an enormous part of the investment market. So many people retire after a lifetime of work with a lump sum superannuation payment or a large amount of money paid for long service leave. Yet the Government has left this vulnerable group in society completely unprotected. It is a group which is completely open to exploitation. All that these people want to do is keep their fringe benefits. I advise the old people in Australia and people about to retire not to put their money into funds and schemes that are not guaranteed by a State government or by the Federal Government. The Victorian friendly societies scheme does not protect funds outside Victoria. People from New South Wales, other States and the Northern Territory who are putting money into these funds have no guarantee of the security of their investment. If the fund is in difficulty they cannot necessarily get their money back. I call on the Treasurer, who is allegedly plugging the loopholes in the tax Act, to let us know what is happening with this scheme of Brick Securities. That company is advertising throughout Australia about tax free investments and the Australian retired persons scheme. It is getting around this loophole in the Friendly Societies Act .

This matter is giving me great concern. Many people-friends and constituents who are approaching retirement age-are ringing me about it. Often the husband and wife are both earning income and both work in the Public Service or in other jobs where they will receive superannuation and they want to get the fringe benefits. I say to these people: 'Your guarantee is the Labor Party's health scheme. It will give you a health scheme about which you will not have to worry. You will not have to worry if you are sick; you will have a simple, straightforward health scheme. You will have security for your investments if you put them in a bank or a building society. You should have nothing to do with these schemes which aim at avoiding the paying of tax so that you can keep the fringe benefits'.

I served in other places for a long time and I never named an organisation under parliamentary privilege because I regard that as a last resort, but I was so appalled that an elderly couple should go to a firm such as ITP to have their final taxation returns assessed, only to find that the man in whom they were placing their trust was leading them to invest their money in a firm for which investment he got a commission, that I did so. That is an appalling situation. I am told that the Tax Agents Registration Board in Sydney has taken no action against this firm as yet. I am told that it is short of staff in Sydney and the Government cutbacks have stopped any action against this firm. I have told these people to take legal action. They are just too frightened to do so. They have never been in court in their lives. They do not want to take legal action. They have lost their money. I think the Government stands condemned for cutting staff in the Public Service and stopping the Tax Agents Registration Board from supervising these tax agents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow, we are led to believe, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Labor Party leaders are to sit down and work out the approach that they are going to recommend to the unions of this country regarding the future level of wage demands. The subject of wage levels is of paramount importance to our future economic well-being. We have kidded ourselves up until now that somehow we would survive, regardless of the enormous wage increases and the reduction in working hours. Unfortunately, the chickens are now coming home to roost and they are finding that their perches have disappeared. We have been pricing ourselves out of world markets and out of jobs .

SPEECH.PARA: Wage increases have borne almost no relationship to the ability of businesses or the economy to pay. For example, I saw a report recently that since 1969-70 our production per head of population has risen by 18 per cent while money wages have risen by 255 per cent. In 1980-81 average weekly earnings for males increased by 13 1/2 per cent. Inflation in that year was 9.4 per cent. Last year wages went up by around 15 per cent and inflation was 10.4 per cent. Wage rises have consistently been more than the inflation rate. Let us compare that with the situation overseas. This year's Budget Paper No. 1, speaking of the situation in 1981, states:

. . . in the United States total compensation per employee rose by around 9 1/2 per cent; in Japan by 7 per cent; and in West Germany by less than 6 per cent. There have been signs of further slowing in wages growth in these countries in 1982. In the United States, compensation per civilian non- farm worker increased at an annual rate of around 7 per cent in early 1982, while in West Germany the 1982 wages round has been completed and most settlements were for increases of less than 4 1/2 per cent.

Compare that with our wage increase of somewhere between 15 per cent and 17 per cent. The result has been that growth in our economy has been killed off. Profits have fallen. Our inflation rate has risen. Exports have fallen and now unemployment is rising.

The Federal Government has been acutely aware of the problem and has consistently been calling for wage restraint. A good example of the Government's resolve in this matter is our own salary increases. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) submitted to the Remuneration Tribunal this year that maximum restraint ought to be exercised in relation to the salaries of members of parliament. Subsequently, the Tribunal recommended with-I use its term-'considerable hesitation' an increase in salaries of 7 per cent from 1 October this year. That increase in the salaries of members of parliament, I remind the House, is an effective increase for this financial year of 5.25 per cent. The Tribunal, in handing down its determination, also stated that it would keep salaries under review.

Such is my deep concern for wage restraint that I, and other members of Parliament, intend to send a letter to Mr Justice Mahoney, Chairman of the Remuneration Tribunal, advising the Tribunal that we wholeheartedly support the Government's request for wage restraint in respect of parliamentarians' salaries and the views put to the Tribunal by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. We consider that wage and salary restraint in the present economic climate is of paramount importance to Australia and we wish to provide leadership in this area . Accordingly, we wish to advise the Tribunal that it is our firm view that there should be no further increases in parliamentary salaries during the current financial year.

Some companies have followed a similar course. Western Mining Corporation Ltd, Myers and others have publicly stated that some salaries have been frozen and some employees have been asked to increase their working hours. Some unions have also adopted an extremely responsible attitude. By way of example, I refer to the members of the Australian Workers Union in Western Australia, who are reported to have dropped their claim for a 38-hour working week in an effort to save jobs. This is just the lead which I believe more of the unions ought to follow. In the face of large increases in the cost of labour, some industries have sought further assistance from the Government or increased protection in an effort to meet competition from the now cheaper imports. This action, of course, does not remedy the basic problem. It may temporarily forestall further unemployment in the industry seeking assistance. However, it could well lead to more unemployment in other domestic industries affected by the increased cost of goods and it will certainly adversely affect our export industries. As Maximilian Walsh recently stated:

It is now more than a decade since the Tariff Board demonstrated what was theoretically obvious, that when it comes to feeding wage push inflation, the highly protected sectors of the economy are the main culprits.

Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is currently seeking increased assistance which will cost steel users, primary producers and other exporters dearly. When I learnt of BHP's request, I asked it what hours its employees were working and I discovered that its steel works administrators and supervisory staff are working 38 hours a week and its waterside workers 35 hours a week. If other unions are prepared to drop their claims for shorter working hours in an effort to save jobs, I believe that BHP ought to approach its own workers to do likewise. When BHP opened its case for assistance in Melbourne last week, at the same time members of the Federated Ironworkers Association employed by BHP in Newcastle went out on a 48-hour strike. The situation is absolutely intolerable. To suggest that the rest of the community should be expected to bear the cost of such union folly, I believe, is irresponsible.

When I made similar comments last week I received a letter from the proprietor of a small country newspaper. I believe it is a good example of the community attitude in this matter. The letter stated:
Dear James,

I support your comments. I am amazed that a recent agreement between printing employers and unions that provided for 37 1/2 hours immediately with 35 hours coming into effect in December, accompanied by big wage increases, has gone virtually un-reported and un-noticed. The bargain was struck with the aid of a 24 hour general strike of print unions. Employers caved in weakly. The big shops obviously bought industrial peace. I personally regard it as a sell out to industrial muscle and a stab in the back to industries trying to fight the 'less work for more pay' syndrome.

The sentiments expressed by the author of that letter emphasis that not only must the unions moderate their wage claims but also employers must do all possible to contain their cost structures. The proprietor of that small country newspaper has subsequently made the point to me that many printers receive a book bounty. He suggested, against his own financial interest, that if printers are to agree to unreasonable wage demands he could understand if the Government were to review its position regarding the bounty. However, I make it clear that I am not saying that the bounty is currently under review. Let me conclude by saying that wage restraint is now more crucial than ever before. If it is not practised in the forthcoming year I fear for our future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a correspondent in the Melbourne Age pointed out yesterday, the 1982-83 Budget is a repeat of the 1977 situation. In that year there was also speculation about an early election which was fuelled by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and Liberal Party strategists. Then, as now, the Budget was weighted down with goodies which trigger the hip-pocket nerve of the floating voter. Mr Fraser went on to win the election and then reneged on all his promises. Will he get away with it again? It is even possible, as I speak, that the decision has already been made that in order to end the uncertainty there must be a September election. More likely, however, in order that the Government can capitalise on the income tax reductions and the increase in welfare payments, the election will be called for November. What a cynical exercise. Does the Prime Minister really believe that the electors will be fooled once again?

SPEECH.PARA: One group of people who will not be fooled are the many thousands of young unemployed people. With 60 young people competing for every job vacancy they are looking into a hopeless future because there is no promise in the Budget of an improvement in the worst unemployment position since the Great Depression of the 1930s. The grim situation facing young people was brought home to me quite starkly when I was visited yesterday by a delegation representing young unemployed workers from my electorate of La Trobe. For them, the increase of $4 from $36 to $40 per week for unemployment benefit for the under-18 year olds is an insult. It is appalling that after seven years with no increase, with inflation eating away the real value of the benefit until it had become a pittance the Government has offered only a 10 per cent increase.

Of course, it is clear why the Government has adopted this callous atitude to unemployed people. Government members have the quaint, paternalistic view that 16 and 17 year olds should be enfolded in the bosom of their families. Since it is obvious that nobody can live independently on $40 a week it is obviously the intention of the Government that it is the parents who are expected to provide the additional support. Any idea that such a policy promotes family cohesion and strengthens family ties can be dispelled by any social worker involved with young people. With the parents strugling to survive themselves, an unemployed teenager is seen only as an encumbrance. Tensions and stresses arise in the family, particularly when the parents who in their youth experienced periods of full employment fail to understand why their son or daughter cannot get a job and attack them for being lazy or lacking initiative. The youngsters try to explain that for every job they apply for some 40 to 60 other young people are seeking the same job. They point to the unanswered job applications, the impossibility of seeking work without independent transport, the dead end and temporary nature of many of the jobs on offer. Forcing unemployed teenagers to seek the financial help of their families, far from promoting cohesion and stability is, in fact, causing tension and stress and creating social upheaval in all our major cities.

It must also not be forgotten that some teenagers, either because they have been reared in institutions or because their parents are separated and are leading different lives, do not have a family to whom they can turn for help. The attitude of the Government towards the very people who constitute the future of Australia is appalling. To make matters worse, when teenagers in desperation pool their resources and live together in groups, they are accused of immoral living and bludging off the community. We on this side of the House have constantly been urging the Government to mount a manpower planning program which would include job creation schemes. Any municipal council in any State in Australia will tell us of the potential in its municipality for job creation if only public funds were provided. Government members constantly criticise the job creation intiatives of the Australian Labor Party Whitlam Government. But the evidence of the valuable community projects which those initiatives created abound in every shire and city which took part in those schemes.

Apart from the need to increase the unemployment benefit for those under 18 years to the adult level, there are two allied problems which require government attention. In my electorate the lack of public transport, particularly in the hills area, is a disgrace. Years of neglect by Federal and State Liberal governments cannot be remedied overnight, although the Victorian State Labor Government has begun an upgrading of the public transport system throughout the State. For some young people in my electorate even the weekly visit to the employment office by public transport is a costly financial outlay, quite apart from the difficulty of obtaining transport to aid their job seeking efforts. By far the greatest problem of all, however, is the lack of cheap rental accommodation in my electorate.

A recent opportunity by the Government to assist local municipalities in the provision of funds to increase the rental housing stock was lost despite a request which I made to the appropriate Minister. Over 43 hectares of land owned by the Defence Service Homes Corporation in Kilsyth, Wantirna and Croydon was recently sold for $1,618,000. Another 137 hectares of land in Lilydale, Mooroolbark and Craigieburn still remains on offer. The sale proceeds of this land could well realise $3m. The opportunity was deliberately lost by the Federal Government to use this land for public housing purposes or to use the total potential proceeds of sale, over $4.5m, to assist municipalities in my electorate with their housing accommodation problems.

A number of community-conscious people who are concerned about the problems of homeless youth have set up an organisation called the Outer East Youth Emergency Accommodation Service. Over the past two years this service has received 1,277 calls from young people requiring emergency accommodation. Of this number, the service was able only to accommodate only 364 in the area. The remainder had to either stay in an intolerable situation of overcrowing or sleep in abandoned cars or other unsuitable public places. Many had to leave their families and friends and move to another area. Community workers, with the assistance of the Sherbrooke Community Youth Support Scheme, have also perfomed a magnificent job in helping homeless youth who have participated in projects organised by the CYSS committee, with the help of the Maroondah bond scheme. This scheme received 321 calls for assistance in the period 1 June 1981 to 31 May 1982. Unfortunately , of that number the scheme was able to allocate only 72 bonds to the value of $ 20,559. The community workers involved in this scheme have reported that the rental market in the outer east has contracted dramatically during the period under review. Each phone call the worker gets tells the same story-the continual round of estate agents and the frantic scanning of rental columns in the newspapers. Estate agents advise that there is no rental accommodation on their books and they are receiving dozens of inquiries each week. There are 50 inquiries for each advertised vacancy. This figure relates to the average vacancy rate of 1.2 per cent calculated for the Melbourne metropolitan area in September 1981 by the Real Estate Institute of Australia. This figure becomes significant when it is appreciated that in past years the average vacancy rate was in the vicinity of 3 per cent to 4 per cent. Accommodation becomes available only as a tenant moves out and the fortunate person on the spot gets the prize. Few properties remain vacant for more than four hours.

As a result of the lack of accommodation rents have risen dramatically. When a house becomes vacant and the rent is $95 a week, unemployed young people are automatically eliminated. The Outer East Youth Emergency Accommodation Service and its allied projects such as the bond scheme are doing a magnificent job, but they are starved of funds. A number of the clients who have contacted the Maroondah bond scheme have advised that after having paid their rent and current debts they did not have sufficient money to purchase food. There are also two women's refuges serving my electorate. They have informed me that, as a result of the lack of rental accommodation, the only hope they have of housing many of the women and children who pass through their refuges is to place them in high- rise housing commission flats. Accommodation of this type is totally unsuitable for such women and children. It means that their rehabilitation is virtually impossible, particularly as they would prefer to remain in the outer eastern region where they have established their roots over a number of years.
At this stage I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard seven schedules which indicate the present accommodation situation in the Outer Eastern region of Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Tables 2, 3 and 4 detail the dwelling prices and table 1 details the accommodation requests received from homeless youth. Tables 5, 6 and 7 give details of rental housing in the region. Even a cursory appraisal of these figures indicates the urgent need for funding from the Commonwealth Government to prevent the continuation of extreme social dislocation which the appalling lack of rental accommodation is causing. The situation is worse than serious; it has become desperate, particularly for single mothers and young unemployed people. All three levels of government-local , State and Federal-must join to find an immediate solution to this most pressing problem. I call on the Federal Government to take the initiative and convene an urgent conference of representatives of all three levels of government to draw up an emergency plan to deal with this tragic problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity in the grievance debate this morning to make some comment on a number of Budget matters that I think are of particular concern to country people and also to people in my electorate of Calare. The first point I raise is that relating to the proposed scheme for rebating diesel fuel excise. Under the old scheme an exempt user, by production of a certificate, could claim the exemption of the excise at the point of purchase. This scheme was apparently abused, which was the main reason why the new rebate scheme was introduced. Indeed, it would seem to me to be the only reason why it was introduced. I acknowledge that there are many opportunities for abuse of such an exemption scheme, but I have doubts as to whether the remedy that has been proposed in the Budget will be effective in stopping the abuse and, indeed, whether it will not bring an additional burden on some diesel fuel users.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I turn to the very good news in this proposed measure of rebating diesel fuel excise for private truck operators, private truck owners and private contractors. For many years they have been at a very significant disadvantage in competing with State instrumentalities concerned with transport, such as railways, which have been exempt from diesel excise. They will now have to pay it and that will put the private contractors on a much more equitable footing with the public transport services. That is something that I hope the industry will welcome, particularly in New South Wales, where the Wran Government has placed an additional 5c per litre tax on diesel fuel to help bail out its budgetary problems. What concerns me is that people who are exempt under the new legislation will have some delay in being able to get their rebates. Many people may say at first that it is not a very important matter.

But let us look at the situation of the agricultural industry or-a case I will cite later-the fishing industry, whose excise has increased very dramatically, although it will be rebatable at a later time. The old excise rate of 5.155c per litre of distillate has now increased by a further cent to finance the roads program. I welcome that increase. I believe that there would have been no hope of getting an effective road system throughout Australia if we had not found additional sources of revenue. I welcome the increase from the point of view that it is to be collected and administered through a trust fund, which means that there is no doubt that the additional cent per litre will be used for roads . Nevertheless, that is a one cent increase that will have to be paid in the first instance by all diesel users. On top of that is the Wran Government's increase of 5c a litre, so total excise and State charges in New South Wales for diesel users amount to 11.155c per litre. On my information, that increases the price, in round figures, from about 28c per litre to nearly 40c per litre in one hit.

Let us look at the time it may take for the rebate to come through. I think it is fair to say that it may take three months from the time when the claim is made for a rebate cheque to arrive. Additional staff will have to be put on in the Department of Industry and Commerce and there will no doubt be a shakedown period, so I feel that three months is a reasonable estimate. With current intrest rates there will be about a five per cent loss to the consumer. In the case of big consumers this amounts to a very significant sum of money. For example, my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) told me that the Ulladulla Fishing Co-operative consumes about one million litres of diesel a year. The Commonwealth excise alone is $61,500. If we apply that figure over four months, being the period that it might take for a fishing co-operative to get its rebate-at an interest rate of, let us say, 15 per cent for ease of calculation-we find that the co-operative is immediately disadvantaged by this system to the tune of $3,000.

So far as the agricultural industry is concerned, those figures would be much lower for individual farmers because there would be perhaps none who consume that amount of fuel. Nevertheless, at this time, with, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) pointed out this morning, one of the most serious drought circumstances facing Australia, and with no end in sight to the drought conditions, this is an additional burden which I am sure rural industry will not be happy about. I understand that already there has been some fairly violent reaction to the system. I for one have yet to be convinced that the old system was necessarily so ineffective that it could not have been tightened up to prevent the abuse that was apparently occurring. I for one would like to see a restoration of the old certification system whereby those who were exempt were able to take that exemption at the point of purchase.

The second point I would like to raise relates to students and particularly to those at the Mitchell College of Advanced Education which is in my electorate of Calare. First of all, I welcome the Budget announcement that Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowances are to be increased by 20 per cent as from January next year, that some additional 12,000 students will benefit, that the income test arrangements for the receipt of TEAS will be relaxed by about 11 per cent and that post-graduate awards are also to be increased by a very significant 48 per cent. There was much speculation and debate at the time of the announcement of a student loans scheme as to whether it would be a substitute for TEAS. That is not the case. It is a supplement to other support schemes for students. The loans scheme will involve initially some $50m that the private banks have agreed to lend. This apparently has placed some limitations on those who can be eligible for the scheme. It is proposed that those eligible will be students in receipt of TEAS and students who meet a means test on their individual income from all sources. The limit on that means test will be $5,000 per year. There are further means tests for students who have dependent children and the like.

However, my concern is that we are apparently denying external and part time students the opportunity of being eligible for the loans scheme. People may say that they should not be eligible because they normally have other means of support and are in many cases receiving salaries, but I do not think that is sufficient justification for saying that external or part time students should be totally excluded from the loans scheme. I do not see why they cannot be given the opportunity of receiving a loan on the basis of an income test, as are the full time students. Many people who are studying externally are in difficult financial circumstances. People who have been retrenched are having to upgrade their qualifications and skills and to change their career aspirations. In many cases single parents who are facing great economic difficulty see that the only way out of their dilemma is to be retrained or further trained in a particular area. In so many cases they are undertaking a second or higher degree course which, of course, attracts fees. I for one would urge the Government to reconsider the decision that external and part time students are not eligible for the loans scheme. Perhaps we could see whether the banks are able to find additional loan accommodation so that if external students were to be included in the scheme it would not be to the disadvantage of the full time students who it is presently proposed will be within the scheme.

I welcome most other aspects of the Budget. Of particular interest to my area is the easing of the additional income limits that are applicable to pensioners. Indeed, pensioners and the aged should be very satisfied with the provisions that have been brought forward in this Budget. I look forward to producing a brochure for use in my electorate which will explain the changes and the additional pension levels, the additional tax exemption limits and the additional limits that have been introduced for the receipt of fringe benefits and the like. I look forward to distributing that information as soon as possible to pensioner groups and to other interested persons throughout my electorate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on behalf of those in the community, the homeless youth, the unemployed and pensioners with little or no private income, the Australians who are unrepresented in this chamber and who have been trampled on by this Government in its rush to win swinging voters. They are not tainted with some infectious disease which has isolated them in this Budget as society's untouchables. Their only misfortune is that they have not been identified in Liberal Party opinion surveys as swinging voters. As such they have been denied the tax cuts and rebates, interest rebates and the dividend rebates doled out selectively by this Government. Who here believes for one minute that the Government did not allocate its handouts in anticipation of winning votes? Who here does not know for one second that assessment of real social needs is the last thing this Government would have referred to when preparing its Budget?

SPEECH.PARA: The irony, I believe, is that this Government has misjudged the swinging voter. Those people whom I know in my electorate are as concerned as anyone else about the 2.8 million Australians who are living on or below the poverty line. The desperately needy, homeless and even starving members of our society-I do not exaggerate-have been kicked in the teeth by a polished black shoe reflecting the used car salesman smile. The question many Australian families must now be asking is: Would the warranty be honoured should the used car salesman clinch the deal he is obviously seeking? The problems facing the unemployed in this country were outlined in this place yesterday by my colleague the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). It strikes me as the height of arrogance and shows a chilling lack of understanding of the economy for a government to bring down a no-growth Budget which does nothing to offer hope for more jobs at a time when statistics show that this country has record post-war unemployment. In fact, as yesterday's Australian Financial Review states, we will be lucky to see a rate of unemployment under 10 per cent by the end of the financial year. So much for the Liberals' economic management.

What has this Budget given the unemployed? With weekly rents rising by $10, with increases in power costs and a host of sales tax increases, the Government has magnanimously allowed an extra $4 per week to trickle down to unemployed kids not yet 18 years old. With no forecast growth in employment, particularly in 1982-83, it has increased its standing on job training schemes. What an irony ! Talk about a treadmill leading to nowhere! We have job training schemes with no jobs. The Special Youth Employment Training Program has been proven unsuccessful, yet we have to listen to members on the Government side calling on families, on middle and low incomes, who are striving to keep their heads above water, to practise wage restraint, presumably to cure the unemployment problem. This Government does nothing about this matter and does not talk about job creation schemes.

Let us focus more closely on the plight of the 15, 16 and 17-year-old people in our community and in particular on the large proportion of those kids who have left home for one reason or another. The Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare recently found that over 12,000 youngsters were roaming our streets homeless in the year to last September. Clearly the situation will be much worse in this coming year. Yet the Government's response to this trend is hardly discernable. Total outlays by way of subsidies to voluntary organisations for the construction, purchase or maintenance of night shelters, reception shelters and hostels for homeless persons will be increased by a grand total of $400,000 this year from $6.3m to $6.7m for the whole of Australia. The $1.7m allocated to the Youth Services Scheme which supplies emergency accommodation and emergency service for homeless young people is only a $500,000 increase on the previous year's allocation. This covers emergency accommodation throughout Australia. If it were to be allocated only to my home city of Brisbane wherein, according to the Senate report, nearly 2,000 homeless youngsters roam, it would not do much more than cover the increased running costs of the present shelters. In other words, there has been no effective response by this Government to the desperate plight of homeless youth. That plight is growing; let there be no mistake about that.

The Brisbane Telegraph of 17 August reported that the number of homeless young people seeking help in Melbourne has jumped 30 per cent in the past few months. A spokesperson for the Melbourne City Mission was reported as saying that most were under 18 years old and unemployed, kids on the streets. He said it was almost impossible for young people to survive independently on the dole and that the Mission has been subsidising these people in private board at a rate of up to $20 a week. The Government, in its infinite wisdom, sees fit to dole them out an extra $4 a week. It is disgusting.

The Telegraph of 16 August also reports that many poverty stricken people were turned away each week from the Gold Coast's only hostel for the homeless. The manager is reported as saying that most of the hostel's residents are between the ages of 16 and 25 and are still missing out on the essentials of life, such as clothing. He said: 'I do not know how the young 18-year-old unemployed kids survive'. I presume, however, that Mr Fraser does, otherwise he would have done something to help them in this Budget. People under 18 do not vote. Furthermore, many who are homeless may not have parental support, parents who will respond in anger to a government which neglects them. This Government gives them a paltry $ 4 a week rise; a total of $40 a week in all. This still represents a figure of $ 37.25 a week below the single pension and less than half the poverty line. The Government refuses to pay supplementary or rent assistance to unemployed people paying rent. Do honourable members realise what this means to a human being?

Rent assistance is being paid only to the poorest pensioners, those with almost no income who are paying rent in the private market. The assistance will rise on 1 November from $8 a week to $10 a week. With weekly rents in Brisbane ranging from $50 to $80 for the most meagre accommodation and weekly rent for housing at $100 and over, the Government grants a $2 increase to $10 a week. This is while rentals at the bottom of the market are rising at an annual rate of more then $ 10 a week. This $2 increase will cost $24m in the full year-only $16.7m in 1982- 83-and that is an appallingly low amount compared with the allocations to home owners, needed as those allocations are. This is a gross injustice which could only be perpetrated by a privileged, comfortably housed, blinkered government.

A further glaring discrimination is the refusal to pay any supplementary allowance to unemployed people paying rent. They face the same costs as pensioners in private rental accommodation but are given no rent relief by the Department of Social Security or State housing authorities. They are given no access to fringe benefits. No wonder this sterile, unprincipled Government is forcing invalid pensioners into the dole queue, ruling them less than 85 per cent incapacitated and sending them, as I have seen in the Division of Lilley, at the age of 50 to the Commonwealth Employment Service to register for jobs which do not exist. This is to save money.

This does not mean that invalid pensioners are living a life of riotous dissipation on their modest allocation. To the contrary, they also have been let down in this Budget. We have been told that the limits of their pensions income test have been relaxed. We have been told that the tax threshhold has been raised. That is good as far as it goes, but sick and frail people and many people in today's job situation cannot get that extra income and so they are not being assisted in the least. Pensioners who are too frail to work have received nothing. They do not pay tax, so rebates and raised threshholds do not help. They do not receive private income, so relaxed income tests are no help either. However, they still must cash their cheques at banks and purchase goods. They are hit by the banks' transactions tax and the high rate of sales tax.

I conclude by making a strong protest at the manner in which these Australians, without a power base and without political clout, have been abandoned by this Government. To trample on the weak is no basis for a decent Budget. This is no way for one set of human beings to treat another no matter how elite they mistakingly consider themselves. It is certainly no way to run a nation. It is not a dream to say that these poor are here and these poor are being neglected; it is a reality and what we have seen is a cynical, totally unacceptable way for an Australian government to run a country and base a Budget. If a nation's humanitarianism is to be judged by the way in which it collectively treats its weakest citizens our country is presently in a moral trough as well as in a financial trough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The electorate of O'Connor encompasses a very large percentage of rural Western Australia. Flying a light aircraft I regularly traverse this area. Such flights give me a clear indication of the large quantities of previously productive rural land that have been lost to salt encroachment. The Western Australian Department of Agriculture has recently completed a salt land survey based on returns submitted in 1979 by farm owners. The survey showed salt encroachment increased by 35 per cent per annum. A total of 263,752 hectares of previously arable land is now salt affected, which is 1. 75 per cent of the cleared farmland in Western Australia. A further 378,000 hectares of land is classified naturally as saline.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to discuss the causes and remedies to this threat to the future of dry land farming in Western Australia. There is no argument that the original cause was the clearing of trees and shrubs from the land. Honourable members should note that I am not saying over clearing. This creates other problems, such as wind erosion. From this point opinions and theories as to cause commence to differ considerably. However, they split broadly into two main areas. Firstly , there is the view of the Western Australian Department of Agriculture. It states that the lack of trees and/or excessive clearing no longer provides for the dissipation of ground water. Consequently it says that watertables rise to the surface at low lying areas bringing underground salt layers to the surface. The salt then kills the growth, whether it be crop or natural bush. The Department consequently argues that the remedy lies in substantially reduced clearing and replanting of trees and salt tolerant bushes. This remedy has had limited success in displacing the salt. At the best, if growth is established, the areas offer minimum productivity.

I believe our reclamation efforts should be aimed at returning the land to full food production. I am further not convinced by the core of the departmental argument that watertables rise and bring up salt. The districts concerned generally have annual rainfalls of below 10 inches. No underground water supplies are to be discovered even at substantial depths and even in the low- lying salt affected areas. How then can a non-existent watertable rise? My constituents, the men who have been committed to this land, have evolved quite different theories of cause and remedy. Over 30 years ago Harry Whittington of Brookton was confronted with the need to find solutions or ship out. His property was so badly salt affected that even his homestead was at risk. Mr Whittington took the view that the lack of trees allowed excessive water run-off to the low lying areas. He reasoned that this land became waterlogged with resulting soil compaction which further aggravated the problem. Much of this water was prevented from escaping by previous interference to the natural drainage system caused by urban and road development. According to Whittington, the appearance of salt was the result of evaporation of the water which had lain on the surface. He queried whether the salt or the compacted soil was the greatest inhibitor to germination and growth of plant life.

To replace the function of the trees and retain the productivity of his land, Whittington constructed low-contoured interceptor banks which intercept the runoff and retain it on the higher ground or direct it into storage dams where, being fresh, it is excellent and needed stock water. This eventually allows the salt land to dry out and to be ripped up, thus allowing natural rainfall to leach out the salt and eventually return the land to a level of productivity. The Whittington system has enjoyed considerable success. This can be measured both by the many miles of Whittington interceptor banks now in existence and the 1,000-plus members of the society known as WISALTS, the Whittington Interceptor Salt Affected Land Treatment Society, which was formed by interested supporters of the system. The Society has an active executive and trains surveyors and advisors to assist new members to protect their properties from salt enroachment . Considerable knowledge and construction skill are required to ensure the banks function as expected.

Another group of farmers living in the Watheroo area to the north of my electorate have applied a different approach suitable to their area, but which still involves the removal of excess water. The innovators concerned are the Scott brothers and the Sutherland family. They used large excavators to deepen the existing watercourses on their properties. When water commenced flowing into and along these new drains the impurity levels were up to 2,000 grains of salt. In a relatively short period these levels dropped to 800 grains of salt. In some watercourses freshwater crustacea and trout were introduced, and these are thriving. Pasture now spreads over what was hundreds of metres of salt scald right to the edge of the drains, thus proving that both land and water can be reclaimed just by allowing the water to flow away.

Both the WISALTS group and the Watheroo farmers have invested large sums of money developing their theories. This has included overseas travel to countries such as Canada where substantial advances in salt enroachment technology have occurred. The Canadians have developed a special technology in the area of subsoil drainage which is a natural extension of the work of the Watheroo group. The advances relate to the use of a plastic drainage pipe that can be installed by a ploughing tool so as to direct subsoil water to the major drainage system. The advantage of this pipe is that it is manufactured and packed in a flat form. It is created into pipe shape by the ploughing tool, and the edges are so made as to zip together. This is a major advance when compared with the previous use of heavy and fragile clay agricultural pipe in remote areas.

The new pipe is presently manufactured in Japan and New Zealand and, because of its compact design, freight charges would be minimal. Notwithstanding that, the pipe is sold in Australia at four to five times the price charged in the United Kingdom and Canada-that is, a 100 millilitre pipe is $2.63 per metre in Australia, whereas it is 51c per metre in the United Kingdom and 66c per metre in Canada. One reason for the increase in the price is that our Government imposes a 15 per cent Customs duty on the pipe of Japanese manufacture. Whilst salinity continues its rapid increase in Australia it appears plainly silly that a government should tax an item which could contribute to relieving the problem. However, this does not explain the huge discrepancy between the cost of this product in Australia and overseas. I hope the Government will inquire into this matter.

In 1981-82 the Federal Government provided $1.3m to the Western Australian Government to assist in salinity research. Unfortunately, in my view, most of this money is used by the Department of Agriculture in Western Australia in experiments relating to its unsuccessful and unproductive theories. The farmers have demonstrated more practical solutions, yet except for generous taxation deductions provided by this Government they receive little support. I am convinced, from my observations, that if grants were made to the WISALTS and Watheroo groups for research purposes considerable advances would occur in the area of salinity control at a cost to the Government well below present expenditure. Both groups need funds to purchase items of experimental capital equipment which could greatly reduce the cost of installing the protective measures I have described today. Australia would profit greatly from such an investment, coupled with the innovation and energy of the people involved.

Finally, all governments and all development authorities must also look to the comments I make. Urban developers and road construction authorities must take a national view of development, as it has affected and will affect the natural drainage systems of the Australian continent, particularly as our topography seldom shows these drainage patterns clearly. Anybody who has made an observation of salt encroachment will be surprised at how often they see salt encroachment alongside our national highways. This is clearly because our national highway construction people have been far more concerned with protecting their roads than protecting the surrounding land and the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 12.15 p.m. In accordance with Standing Order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Fraser Government's inadequate response to the serious decline in Australian manufacturing activity.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Australian manufacturing industry, like the rest of Australian business, wants more than anything else at present is customers. What those in manufacturing want-workers, management and shareholders -is government leadership to stimulate our economy, to create the necessary demands so that they have customers and to engender that confidence in new investment that is so vitally needed if jobs are to be maintained, leave alone the new jobs that need to be created. But wherever we turn to examine the Fraser Government's activities today we find a tragic lack of the vital leadership needed even to maintain the existing stock of jobs, leave alone add to them. Sadly, to make my case that there is this serious decline-in case anybody was in doubt-I must detail the litany of woes and the terrible record of retrenchments which we as Australians are suffering around this country today. Unless we face these facts and acknowledge the collapse that is taking place around us we shall not adopt the correct policies that we need to overcome these grave problems. Let me emphasise: The policies we need mean a real change of direction-a U-turn- on the part of the present conservative national government. We do not want just a cosmetic change which alleviates some of the hardship caused to the many who are suffering from the low level of economic activity. I repeat: We need a real change of direction.

SPEECH.PARA: As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am prevented by the Standing Orders-I suppose it is more important that you should know that I know this-from anticipating the Budget debate. But what I am referring to when I refer to the Government's failed economic policies is the 6 1/2 years of monetarism which has been suffered by this country. We have suffered 6 1/2 years of this so-called fight inflation first policy, and yet we now have an anticipated inflation rate for 1982-83 of nearly 11 per cent. We have suffered 6 1/2 years of tight money, the rationing of credit and the high interest rates that go along with that, and yet no hope is given to us by any Liberal or National Country Party Minister of any alleviation of these problems of high interest rates. We have had 6 1/2 years of a wages policy which can best be summed up like this: 'Keep economic activity low and create more unemployment because that is the only way we Liberals-we conservatives-know of dampening down wage claims'. We have had 6 1/2 years with no prices and incomes policy and no real attempt to sit down with trade union officials and employers to work out an equitable policy, which we should have in place at present. Instead we have had such a confrontationist approach. We have had decisions such as abolishing the prices justification machinery that we used to have in place.

In case I need to make a case that there is a decline in Australian manufacturing activity, let me come back to that sad litany of woes, that list of redundancies, which I mentioned earlier and outline just from a few daily newspapers over a few of the last days the retrenchments that have been taking place around this country. I start with the little provincial city of Bundaberg. Bundaberg is in a state of shock. The sackings of workers at Versatile Toft Ltd are only part of the story. They are the world market leaders in sugar cane harvesters. However this is just one example of valued men of many years employment in that one firm being out of work at the present time. If we just focus on Bundaberg we see that Massey-Ferguson (Aust) Ltd, in the same relatively small city, is another example of a firm which has retrenched workers . The transport giant Thomas Nationwide Transport which roams this country is slashing its overnight express division. As a result of manufacturing activity being at an insufficient level for that express activity to continue 150 jobs have gone. ICI Australia Ltd has also announced plans to reduce markedly its work force.

Valued workers live in fear of their income security, wondering whether they will shortly be forced to live on the miserable unemployment benefits provided by this miserable Fraser Government. That problem was well expressed in the grievance debate, which this debate is following, by the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling). The polls paid for by the Liberal Party-I hope they are paid for by the Liberal Party; I would not be at all surprised if the money is not coming out of some back door Government fund-do not as yet show much sympathy for the unemployed. So for the most part they have been neglected in the recent welfare announcements.

The next newspaper headline which I draw to your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the attention of the House, states, 'Work force in metal industry down 2. 8 per cent', and that is just in recent months, leave alone over a reasonable period. Another headline states: '40 jobs go in Tasmania'. Another headline reads: 'BHP says it may cut its work force another 1,000'. Heaven knows, it has cut its work force by thousands already in Whyalla, Port Kembla, Newcastle and in Kwinana 600 jobs alone have been wiped out. Yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald stated: '146 sacked at State's last tyre factory'. Wherever we turn we see another announcement of that sort and it gives me no joy to draw attention to it . However I repeat that unless we face these facts squarely we will not persuade this miserable Government to adopt the policies that are needed.

So often the cry goes up from these conservatives, from all Government members- not just Ministers but also the parrots on the back bench as well-that all this is due to high wage rates. We have heard the cry again today in the grievance debate from the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). I believe-so too do my colleagues-that there must be wage restraint, that competitiveness is the key to the game. However we will not get that sort of approach from the confrontationist rantings of the Liberal-Country Party members whom we hear in this place and indeed from a lot of their supporters outside this place. To rest on wage rates alone as an adequate excuse is utter rubbish. It is misleading the Australian people. Let me say why. Men and women are retrenched by companies because those companies cannot go on bearing losses.

The collapse of the profits share in national income cannot and should not be attributable solely to the growth in wages as is so often claimed by the parrots . That excuse is a very small figleaf which barely hides the fact that the collapse in profits is more directly attributable to the collapse in company turnover, to those customers whom I mentioned earlier. It is also attributable to rising unit costs because there is not that demand, therefore there is less production and so overheads have to be covered by fewer items. The collapse in profits is also attributable to distress borrowing and painfully high interest rates which are the results of the monetarist policies being pursued by this Government. These are some of the causes; yet Government members parrot out that wages are the only excuse.

To go on like that shows that they do not recognise the proper causes of the lack of competitiveness. In addition we also get the cry from the same people that the problem emanates from the fact that there is a low level of international activity. The conservatives, of course, also use that as an excuse and I have no doubt that we will hear the same reason from the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) who is at the table. I am not suggesting for one moment that there is not a downturn in international economic activity. But the conservatives must not be allowed to escape a lot of the blame for what is going on internationally.

Firstly, let me make the point that in 1975 the same Liberal and National Country Party cohorts did not acknowledge then the effect of the world economy. As they misled the Australian public from one length of this land to the other to them the fault was all at the feet of the Whitlam Government. The same conservatives, seven years ago, in worse economic circumstances than prevail today, promised to turn on the lights, promised to restore economic confidence, promised to put sport back on the front pages, promised to restore full employment and even promised to reduce interest rates. Never in the history of any country has so much been promised by any government and so little been fulfilled in such a long period than applies to the Fraser Government in the seven years that it has failed this country.

Secondly, we are talking about international excuses-who is to blame for this low level of world economic activity? It is the monetarists of this world who are to blame. These same people are members of the discredited club of which the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his colleagues are foundation members. The Prime Minister struts around the world telling others what they should do. Sadly, even tragically for this country, some have followed his advice. So the evil monetarist policies were first tried here and we are still trying them with singular lack of success. Those policies were persuaded on to Mrs Thatcher by our Prime Minister and just look at what Thatcherism has done for the United Kingdom. Some 3,000,000 are unemployed and 13 per cent of the work force are out of work, with disastrous levels of economic activity in that country. Even one of Mrs Thatcher's senior ministers, Mr Prior, is now on record as saying that he is rebelling against those Thatcherism monetarist policies.

Our Prime Minister persuaded her to accept monetarism and now she has persuaded Mr Reagan. Disastrously for the world President Reagan makes President Nixon look good by comparison. Reaganomics has brought the great United States of America economy which is the engine of the world economy to its knees. Prime Minister Fraser and his conservative colleagues cannot escape blame for what is happening on the world scene. So let us not allow excuses from them to the effect that it is international economic activity that is the reason for what we are suffering here. We have to discard these excuses and apply our minds again to what is the truth about the local scene and what should be done about it.

What we need so desperately is a growth strategy for Australia. We have not got it even in the announcements that were made this week. We need a growth strategy in order to be able to get our people back to work. To get that growth we need specific industry policies in the non-farm product area.
