Gross non-farm product over the last year has experienced such a lack of growth rates that it has fallen from the national average to only about half the national average. It is no wonder that we are in such a terrible position. We have a number of factors and interest rates is one that I have mentioned and also the woeful deficit on external account. I could spend some time on that. Also we have the exchange rates which I could focus on. Despite the recent marginal depreciation of our rate of exchange it is vital to note that it is still almost 10 per cent above the 1980 exchange rate level. In other words because of the over-valuation of our currency and because there has not been a satisfactory formidable depreciation imports are correspondingly cheaper than they would otherwise be, thus causing retrenchments in local industry. Exports are dearer than they would be thus causing a relative downturn in exports. That results in less export income and all the lessening of employment opportunities which flows from that.

I will summarise that point. With the poor economic circumstances into which Australia has been led by the Fraser Government we find that we have unprecedentedly high interest rates. This is partly due to the Government's fetish for deregulating and partly due to the Government's monetarist ideology whereby it believes in imposing stringent limits to money supply growth rates. Of course, those high interest rates are also designed to attract capital inflows to this country. Because of the woeful trading performance too many imports are coming in and not enough exports are going out. Outflows are also due to the invisibles because we are not doing enough in this country about our own freight, insurance and so on. Superimposed on this are the problems for our whole economy, including our manufacturing sector. I draw attention to the deterioration which, as I indicated earlier, has stemmed from six and a half years of contractionary monetary policies which have seriously impeded improvements in Australia's industrial competitiveness. As I have shown, this deterioration principally is the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government- this Fraser Government. Domestic policies could and should have done so much more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I express from the outset amazement at the absolute hide of this socialist matter of public importance which I submit is exceeded only by its utter baselessness and total lack of substance. To have socialists preaching to the Government, to private enterprise and to Australia at this time is a recipe for disaster. It is the same old gang with the same old act. They are the very same prophets of doom with policies of disaster. They are the successors of the economic vandals who nearly brought this country to the brink of bankruptcy in the dark Whitlam years of 1972 to 1975. Before any of them squirm out of the definition of 'socialist' I will remind them of the words of their own leader. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) said on 7 June:

SPEECH.PARA: Let's not be coy about this: We are democratic Socialists.

The socialist recipe for disaster in the three Whitlam years brought about a trebling of inflation, a doubling of unemployment and a two and a half times increase in interest rates. Let the private enterprise sector of Australia in particular never forget that it was Whitlam Government policies-in particular one of the most outrageous government decisions ever taken, which created a 25 per cent across the board tariff cut-which put 100,000 Australians out of their jobs. If ever a government stood indicted by policies which are the death knell of private enterprise it is the Australian Labor Party. But the matter does not stop there. The question of how the Australian Labor Party would fund its policies has to be asked. In all fairness to the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) we did not hear any policies today. We did not hear any suggestion for a Labor Party remedy. We did not hear any Labor Party policy proposals at all, but others have been put from time to time.

I take the time of the House for a moment to remind the people of Australia that in the ultimate government policies have to be paid for. Effectively they have to be paid for out of taxation and taxation has to be raised from the people of Australia. Of course, the Labor Party knows all about taxation because in the three dark Whitlam years, 1972 to 1975, income tax receipts increased by a massive 48 per cent. I suggest that with the policies the Labor Party has in mind we would be looking at a 60 per cent or 70 per cent increase if it got control of the Treasury benches. Certainly its economic spokesman has made this very clear. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) in June 1978 said:
If Labor does not gain office next election-
That was prior to the 1980 election-
then by 1983, when we could next hope to gain office, we would face a mammoth task in rebuilding the public sector-
I emphasise the words 'rebuilding the public sector'-
and maybe an equally mammoth task in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable us to do so.

There it is in black and white. The Australian Labor Party is the high tax party . Labor is the party which does not understand, has never understood and will never understand private enterprise. It is Labor's philosophy that if there is not a public servant involved in the act it will not succeed; if the public sector does not get its finger in the pie of private enterprise then private enterprise has no future at all. In a moment I will detail some recent Labor Party initiatives in respect of what it would do to private enterprise. Accepting the problems that we have in Australia today, I simply say to private enterprise that when this wolf in sheep's clothing, the honourable member for Adelaide-I concede that he is a pleasant and amiable man-comes amongst your ranks, never forget that he is the emissary of the socialists and of the party which if it got into power would put more fingers in the pie of private enterprise than any party in the history of Australia. Indeed, this acknowledged socialist party has made it abundantly clear that one of the things it will do will be to amend the Constitution to give itself the power effectively to nationalise Australian industry. I will quote from the Australian Labor Party platform. It states:

Labor will seek to amend the Constitution 'to provide the Commonwealth Parliament with such powers as are necessary for national planning and the achievement of the Party's economic and social objectives'.

This clearly means that Labor will try to change the Constitution to allow a Labor government to pursue its democratic socialist objectives. The Labor Party has not forgotten that the Constitution was the only barrier to the Chifley Labor Government's legislation to nationalise the banks. Labor's commitment to nationalisation depends upon the removal of these constituational barriers.

Before outlining the proof positive of this Government's commitment to private enterprise and recent Government decisions I again extend a warning to every employer in Australia to consider what happened to private enterprise in the three dark Whitlam years and to pass the message around the ranks that the Labor Party in its time of opposition has learnt nothing; if given the opportunity it will do it all again, only more so.

On the other side of the coin, the Government's response to the difficulties being faced by manufacturing industry has been both positive and timely. All credit is due to the Government and the best Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) that this country has ever seen. On 19 July we announced a major package of measures unreservedly welcomed by industry and acknowledged to be a significant step in helping industry to be ready to capitalise on the economic recovery as well as improving the long term competitiveness of Australian industry. I will say more about this a little later.

I do not anticipate the debate on last Tuesday's Budget, but with its continuing anti-inflationary thrust the Budget is further evidence of the Government's conviction that a strong manufacturing base is absolutely essential as a pre-requisite for a balanced, viable and independent national Australian economy. Direct budgetary assistance to industry has been increased by $49m to a magnificent $472m-the fifth year in succession that we have increased outlays of relevance to industry development. Specifically, export development programs will receive $225m; industrial research and development schemes and related technology programs, $51m; and bounties and other assistance programs, $160m. Rather than dismantling the system, as the honourable member for Adelaide suggested, we have dramatically increased the Government's tangible support for the manufacturing sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a very good and effective way.

—As the honourable member for Macarthur has interjected, in a very good and effective way. Private enterprise knows that. Industry will also continue to derive considerable benefit from the taxation system as well as from certain new initiatives, in particular taxation of company groups, retention allowances for private companies and the rebate on dividend income. The Government believes that an essential characteristic of industry policy is that it be flexible and responsive to the changing needs of Australian industry which result from a dynamic domestic and international economic environment. This responsiveness has been a feature of the Government's industry policy since it returned to office in 1975. That industry policy has sought to create a predictable basis upon which business, large and small, can grow and become strong and self-reliant. The Government's approach has been to reduce regulation , government intrusion into the economy, and to reduce government expenditure to leave scope for the expansion of private sector investment.

SPEECH.PARA: We have achieved-I say this with pride-a large measure of success, unlike the thousands of bankruptcies, the thousands of liquidations and the tens of thousands of people out of work which came about under the Whitlam Government's policies. Over the last two years Australia has stood out amongst the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as an example of growth and stability. Together with its responsible economic policy the Government has employed a judicious mix of industry assistance measures to enable industry to respond more effectively to changing economic circumstances. It must be said today and over and over again that the situation we have now reached in this country is such that one man's pay rise is another man's dismissal notice. We cannot ignore the fact that average weekly earnings for male employees rose by a massive 17.1 per cent in the 12 months to March 1982. That is one and two-third times the rate of inflation.

I now turn to the recently announced industry assistance package. As positive evidence that the Government is attuned to the needs of industry and is indeed responsive to the difficulties being faced by industry the package of measures is designed to restore the competitive edge of Australian industry, encourage new investment and improve employment prospects. The package has several dimensions. The depreciation provisions vastly improve the environment for investment and offer positive encouragement for firms to renew and, indeed, increase their productive base. Five-thirds depreciation of plant means a more rapid write-off and a reduction in tax bills for those firms which modernise and extend their facilities. The greatest benefit will be to longer-lived assets where the more difficult decisions often need to be made. The 2 1/2 per cent building depreciation applauded widely in the private enterprise sector offers an incentive to firms to ensure that their buildings are more up to date and better meet the needs of improved employee conditions and productivity. The decision not to proceed at this time with a further program of reduction in protection recognises the difficulty of proceeding with a unilateral program during depressed economic conditions.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know the Government has also decided to maintain the industrial research and development scheme which offers incentives to firms entering into IR and D and for those firms which are prepared to increase their IR and D activities. It is very important that encouragement be given to innovation if Australian industry is to improve its international competitiveness and provide opportunities for the work force to utilise fully its skills. This brings me to a key aspect of the Government's policy. The Government sees a continuing role for the encouragement of export and the need to foster a more internationally-oriented industry sector. Only through such means can we achieve the better integration of Australian industry with that of the rest of the world and therefore maximise our productive potential.

Following the Industries Assistance Commission findings it has been decided to strengthen significantly the export market development grants scheme which provides an impetus for firms-especially newer exporters-to seek out and develop new markets for their products. With this package we have greatly improved the environment in which Australian manufacturing industry operates. We believe it will have an early impact in retarding the present downturn. For the medium and longer terms, the package creates an improved platform on which industry can plan with confidence and it will mean more investment, more jobs and higher income levels. There is no doubt that this Government firmly believes that a strong manufacturing base is an absolutely essential prerequisite for a balanced , viable and independent national economy.

Australia's trade unions for their part must now be willing to adopt a more responsive and realistic approach to their demands on industry for improved wages and conditions. I applaud the recent statement by Mr Nolan on behalf of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We believe that the taxation assistance and other family assistance contained in the Budget announcements made on Tuesday night provide a good basis for the exercise of wage restraint on the part of the union movement. This is the key which will either open the door to opportunity and growth or lock us into a lower growth path with its adverse impact on living standards and employment creation. The Australian Labor Party has never understood and will never understand private enterprise. The whole basic thrust of its philosophy is pubic sector activity, bigger government, more regulation and higher taxation to pay the bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're getting worried now. You realise they're on my side now.

—The honourable member for Adelaide again says that we are getting worried. Let me tell him that we are not worried about his policy or lack of policy in respect of the manufacturing sector because all we have to do is to remind the hundreds of thousands of employers around Australia of what the Labor Party did to private enterprise from 1972 to 1973. Its policies for industry demonstrate beyond any doubt that it is bereft of any cohesive approach to the problems besetting Australian manufacturing industry. Labor Party policies read like an unremitting litany to bureaucratic intervention. They are based on unexplained and highly improbable prices and incomes policies made in consultation with trade unions which would further squeeze company profits. The Labor Party would bring in the dreaded capital gains tax. It would bring in a resource rental tax.

SPEECH.PARA: At least the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), an honourable member amongst the ranks of the Opposition, has had the honour to say that Labor's policies would mean higher taxes. The matter of public importance brought into this House today by the honourable member for Adelaide is a sham and a fraud. It will be seen to be such not only within this Parliament but also throughout the Australian nation and, most importantly, in the area of private enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: University of Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The students and staff of the University of Queensland express their dismay at the lack of adequate federal government funding to our University, which has resulted, interalia, in the erosion of our library facilities-we note that:
1. The opening hours of our main library have been reduced from 93 1/2 hours a week in 1975 to 72 hours a week in 1982.
2. The number of new books purchased per year has fallen from over 50,000 in 1976 to under 23,000 in 1981.
3. The number of books in storage and inaccessible to students and staff has risen from none in 1977 to over 40,000 in 1981.
4. The number of books discarded in 1976 was over 6,000-by the end of 1981 over 70,000 had been discarded.
We believe this to be educationally retrograde and economically wasteful.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that government funding levels be increased to a level sufficient to allow the University to restore our previous library facilities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Sir James Killen,Mr McVeigh,Mr Millar and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That whereas the current rates of personal income tax are onerous and destructive of personal incentive, particularly since the cessation of income tax indexation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call upon the Parliament assembled to legislate such changes to the current taxation law as will:
raise the minimum level at which income tax is first payable to at least $4,500 .00,
proportionately increase the figures at which the higher rates of tax attract,
allow taxpayers to claim the full amount for each item within the Concessional Expenditure Rebate, and
adjust the rates of tax payable so that no higher rate of tax is payable than fifty percent of income earned.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Armitage,Mr Carlton and Mr Jull.

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that wine is a beverage of moderation whose use especially in conjunction with food may be beneficial to the consumer.
(b) that per capita consumption of alcohol in Australia has stabilised at 9.6 litres per head, the same as the average over the past eight years.
(c) that the low retail price of wine in Australia has been brought about by a number of factors including an oversupply of grapes and grape products.
(d) that if the price of wine is increased due to factors outside the control of grape growers, wine makers and retailers, sales of wine will be reduced.
(e) that the consequent fall in the demand for grapes coupled with the reduced wine production will affect employment and incomes, particularly in rural areas.
(f) that Australian brandy continues to lose market share to other spirits.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Government consider and appreciate the complexities of the widely-spread Australian Wine Industry and be aware that any Government impost will cause further imbalance between the supply of and the demand for grapes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Chapman and Mr Jull.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Armitage and Mr Carlton.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The heart-rending loss of homes by home purchasers, due to an expanding holocaust of interest rates caused by, and to quote the manager of a leading bank (26.04.81) 'with the growing competition for savings, depositors are looking for higher interest returns on deposits. In order to retain our depositors and to meet the increased costs payable on deposits and operating expenses, it is necessary to raise income from loans of all types, including House Loans.'

Therefore it becomes transparently clear that the constant edging up of interest rates for investors by banks, lending institutions, and banking consortiums are collectively responsible for the monetary explosion, lack of employment and all that that entails and is causing grave social disruption to hundreds of thousands. Behind it all, the absence of control that is now politically essential in the interest of justice and fair distribution of burden .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.
Presented by: John Knight, 11 Ryans Rd, Parafield Gardens, South Australia 5107 .

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That in recent years thousands of families have lost their homes, the building industry and employment is at an all time low, with social disruption a serious factor.
All this, in our opinion, is due to extortionate interest rates that have passed the bounds of all reason and void of equity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.
Presented by: John Knight, 11 Ryans Rd, Parafield Gardens, South Australia 5107 .

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Wine
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That any sales tax or excise on Australian wine would adversely affect employment in the wine industry, place a disproportionate burden on grapegrowers and ensure a larger future surplus of grapes.
The reduction in the demand for wine will also threaten the existence of many wine producers and reduce the range, quality and variety of wines offered in the market.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will reject any proposal for a sales tax or excise on Australian wine.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Falconer.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Student Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the introduction of a comprehensive student loans scheme will:

1. Restrict Access to Education People from poorer backgrounds will be deterred from studying by the prospect of incurring large debts. These people, if they enrol, will be forced to amass loan debts. Richer students do not face this handicap.

2. Undermine the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme TEAS should cover the basic living costs of students. Currently the scheme only assists 38% of full- time students and the maximum level of TEAS is a mere $49.67. Government statements indicate TEAS will be further downgraded if loans are introduced.

3. Disadvantage Women Women students would be disadvantaged by a loans scheme as they have a lesser ability to repay loan debts, because on average women earn less and have a higher unemployment rate.

4. Disadvantage Mature-Age Students Usually mature age students forego income to study and already have large financial commitments. They could not return to study if it meant incurring substantial debts.
5. Distort Educational Choices Mounting loan debts would force students into studying shorter courses or not continuing with post-graduate study.

6. Result in Massive Attrition Rates Students will attempt to undertake extensive part-time work or overload courses to minimise their loans. Increased failure rates will result forcing students to ''drop-out'' rather than continuing study and increase their debts.

7. Cause Administrative and Financial Difficulties Overseas experience shows high default rates will occur on student loans. Government money will be channelled away from TEAS to paying off banks. The government will also bear the administrative burden of pursuing defaulters.
Therefore, the proposed student loans scheme will have disastrous effects on tertiary education, which we believe benefits the whole community, not just the individual student.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject the introduction of a student loans scheme. And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dawkins and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Ethnic Broadcasting
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia do humbly pray that the Australian Government extend the services of Channel 0/28 to cover in the first instance the metropolitan area and ultimately the rest of the State of South Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That adequate Federal funding be provided for children's services and that this funding be increased to cover increases in the cost of living.
That policy decisions about the future of childrens' services only be made in full consultation with the providers and users of these services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia.
And this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the Twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That owing to recent rises in the interest rates of Home Loans, intolerable burdens, both financial and social, have been and are being placed on numerous families in this country. These burdens can and will result in many families facing mounting hardship-even the loss of the family home.
Your Petitioners therefore pray:

That the Federal Government limit Home loan interest at the present level-as on this day, 7th of July 1982, and that the government take constructive steps that will lead to the immediate reduction in home loan interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Returned Soldiers: Commonwealth Public Service Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that the Commonwealth Public Service Act, Section 47A (3) be amended as follows:

(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, a returned soldier may be appointed to the Service or to any office in the Service, although he is not free from physical defects due to service in a war or any other service by virtue of which he is a returned soldier, provided he is not in receipt of the special (T. & P.I.) rate of pension.

If the Board requests the advice and expert specialist medical opinion, then that advice and opinion should be suffice. If any doubts are cast as to the physical defects that would incapacitate him for the efficient discharge of the duties that he would on appointment be required to perform, the benefit of the doubt should be interpreted by the Board in favour of the returned soldier. If appointment should be rejected the returned soldier should be permitted to remain employed on a temporary basis.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The petitioners' fear and condemnation of Australia's chronic decline from a land of prosperity, generosity and peace to a strike-torn, minority controlled and broken country. This is due to Union corruption and interference which is applied using undesirable methods including black banning and threats.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Prime Minister and the Members of the House of Representatives will introduce legislation to ensure the following:

1. That the Union system is revised to encompass the secret ballot which is the only fair and just indication of what the people really want. Wives or de-facto wives names should be included on their husbands' or de-facto husbands' Union ticket at no extra cost and they should be entitled to a secret vote on all issues which involve their breadwinners. This is a valid request as in a strike action women and children are usually the deprived parties. Household and often financial management is frequently left to the wives and therefore they should be entitled to a vote in any Union dispute directly affecting them before having hardships imposed upon them.

2. That the Unions are restricted to fulfilling their original purpose which is to negotiate fair wages and conditions for their members and not to interfere in external affairs outside their immediate employment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are concerned that an increasing number of Australian families are facing financial burdens beyond their capacity to meet.
2. That we are concerned that the amount of financial assistance being afforded to families is inadequate.
3. That there has been no increase in family allowances for most families for some years.
4. That family allowances in all instances have declined in real value since 1976.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will:
1. Ensure that there is an increase in family allowances in the 1982 Budget so that family allowances are at least restored to the real money value of their 1976 level;
2. Ensure that provision is made for the automatic and regular indexation of family allowances;
3. Ensure that proper consideration is given to the introduction of a Homemakers Allowance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing townships, tourist resort, airstrips and lighthouse reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of the existing townships, tourist resort, airstrips and lighthouse reserve .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. The Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. Then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal by-products, including the Harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegation in the United Nationsl General Assembly the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for the experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Child Care Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That a Federal government subsidy for the recurrent funding of Laurel Tree House, a child care centre at The University of Sydney so far denied Federal funding, should be granted immediately to make use of the centre more possible for those on low and moderate incomes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Independent Schools in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned on behalf of concerned citizens respectfully showeth:
That it is important that there be freedom of choice in education in the Australian Capital Territory.

Your petitioner, therfore, humbly pray that the Federal Government provides adequate funding for Independent Schools in the Australian Capital Territory and more particularly for the establishment of a Third Grammar School in Canberra.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.

2. Any further increase in excise on beer in the 1982 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community .
3. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

4. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State License Fee taxes , which are directly linked to excise rates.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism. And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proserpine Post Office, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Dawson Electorate of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
That Post Offices are the responsibility of the Federal Government,
The Proserpine Post Office has inadequate access for a large number of the community,
Mothers with prams, babes in arms and toddlers, invalid and old age pensioners, and paraplegics, are further incapaciated by the steep gradient of the Post Office steps.

Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament will allocate sufficient funds to allow tenders to be called for the design and erection of a ramp in a suitable place adjacent to the Post Office for the unlimited access by the Proserpine community and its visitors, within the next 12 months.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Northern Highway, Kimberley Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned residents of the Kimberley humbly petition the House of Representatives to urgently allocate funds for the immediate upgrading of the Great Northern Highway in the Kimberley to an all weather sealed highway and pray that the following matters might be considered in relation thereto:

(a) The grave hardship caused to the many residents of the Kimberley due to the Great Northern Highway annually being impassable by road transport resulting in the towns of Kununurra, Wyndham, Halls Creek and Fitzroy Crossing and the community of Turkey Creek being without adequate food supplies for periods of sometimes in excess of one month.

(b) That this portion of the Great Northern Highway is the last portion which is unsealed and which does not provide an all weather link and we are, therefore , the only residents of Australia who are on a major highway system which is regularly inundated.
(c) Current allocations and plans do not provide for the upgrading of this highway to be completed in under six years.
(d) There is great defence and stragegic importance in having all weather highway system into the North of Western Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable members of The House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian Immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the exportation of live animals for slaughter to overseas.
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to ban the export of live animals for slaughter overseas.
2. That the export of live horses to Japan for slaughter for human consumption be banned on the grounds that it is cruel and unnecessary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth. That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon M.P.-

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25% and that at the 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embassassment due to high interest rates.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964 to increase the maximum rates of levy which may be prescribed to finance the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, meat and livestock research and cattle disease eradication. Concurrently, I will be introducing a Bill for parallel amendments to the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977. The two Acts to be amended raise funds from the meat and livestock industry for the same purposes and are similar in structure and rates, but one applies to livestock slaughtered and the other to stock exported live. The proposed increases covered by this Bill have been recommended to me by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation after consultation with industry groups. The Government accepts that the Corporation will need an increase in levy income in order to avoid operating at a deficit or cutting back on its activities and service to the industry and that this will first necessitate an increase in the maximum rates currently provided in the legislation.

The levy is imposed on slaughterings of cattle, calves, bobby calves, sheep, lambs, buffaloes and goats. It has separate components for the financing of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, meat and livestock research, meat processing research and cattle disease eradiction. There are comparable rates for each component in respect of each class of livestock. The Act specifies maximum rates only with operative rates being prescribed by regulation. Separate maximum rates already exist in the legislation for the research and disease eradication components. In addition, the operative rates set for the research and AMLC components must not exceed a specified maximum. Hence, the highest level of AMLC component is limited by the level of the prevailing research components. Currently, this difference is insufficient to enable the AMLC component to be increased to the level considered necessary. It is therefore proposed to double the aggregate maximum rates which govern the size of the AMLC component. The existing and proposed levy rates are:
Maximum Rates (c/head)
Current Proposed
Cattle and buffaloes 150.0 300.0 Bobby calves (40kg and less) 15.0 30.0 Calves (40kg and up to 90kg) 52.5 105.0 Sheep, lambs and goats 15.0 30.0
The effect of the proposed changes is to enlarge the scope available for increasing the AMLC component while preserving the existing relativity with the research components.

I now turn to the changes proposed for the cattle disease eradication component which were announced in the Budget. This levy apply only to bovine animals. The current rates are at the maximum level permitted by the Act. Finance for the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign has been falling behind costs. Whilst the Government has announced in the Budget that it will write off the outstanding industry debt of $23.5m it is anxious to ensure that the continuing program does not result in the industry building up a further debt. This Bill is therefore providing for an increase in the current maximum rates by two-thirds- from $3 to $5 for cattle and buffaloes, $1 to $1.67 for calves and 30c to 50c for bobby calves. It is not, however, intended that the disease eradication component be immediately set at these new levels. As stated in the Budget the operative rate, with effect from 1 October 1982, will be raised from $3 to $4 a head for cattle with corresponding increases for other classes of livestock. This increase follows a thorough review of the eradication campaign and its financing and must be seen in the context of the package of assistance offered in the Budget to the cattle and meat industry. In addition to these amendments, opportunity is being taken to bring references in the Act to the Meat Exporter and Abattoir Consultative Group into conformity with the change title of that group. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is a companion measure to the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill just introduced. It proposes similar amendments to the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977. These were explained in my second reading speech on the earlier measure. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a new ceiling on the export charge leviable on currants, sultanas and raisins now that the operative rate of the charge has been increased by regulation to the maximum allowed under the existing Act. Opportunity is also taken in this Bill to redefine procedures applicable to increasing the operative rate in the future and to remove from the Act certain unnecessary words.

Moneys collected under the dried fruits export charge are used to finance the operations of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation which controls the export marketing and overseas promotion of Australian dried vine fruit. The Corporation has been under financial pressure due in part to a poor 1981 harvest, with a consequent sharp fall in receipts in the 1981-82 financial ear, but more importantly to steadily rising costs. Action to improve its current financial position has already been taken, with industry agreement, by Statutory Rules 1982 No. 100 proclaimed on 29 April 1982. The Rule provided for an increase in the operative rate of the charge from the $4.50 a tonne which has applied since 1976 to $7 a tonne of dried fruit exported, the new rate being equal to the maximum allowed under the current Act. The Bill before the House seeks to raise the maximum permissible charge from $7 ro $15 a tonne in order to enable the operative rate to be increased beyond $7 a tonne when this becomes necessary. It is expected that the new ceiling will obviate the need for further amendment to the Act for a reasonable number of years. The main industry organisation, the Australian Dried Fruits Association, has been consulted in the past on matters affecting the funding of the Corporation, the operations of which play an important role in contributing to the viability of the industry. It is proposed that these consultations will now be formalised under the provision in the Bill for discussion between my Department and the producers' organisation on any suggested change to the operative rate of charge on the export of dried fruits.
This Bill also seeks to remove a provision of the originals Act which, I am advised, is unnecessary. The clause in question refers to sub-section 3 (3) which states:
All moneys payable under this section in respect of any dried fruits shall be paid on or before the entry of those dried fruits for export to such officers in the respective States as are prescribed.

I am advised the the words 'to such officers in the respective States as are prescribed' are superfluous as the identification of the officers to whom the charge is to be paid can be dealt with administratively. Accordingly it is proposed that a new provision be substituted for the existing one. It is proposed that the amendment Act will come into effect as soon as it receives royal assent. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories presented its report on the future of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, to the Parliament on 9 March 1982. This statement responds on behalf of the Government to that report. On 7 July 1982 I announced that the Government had decided that the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, would continue as a government factory. The Government made that decision after considering a single expression of interest for the lease of the factory following public advertisements inviting expressions of interest for the sale or lease of the factory with a closing date of 11 June 1982. Honourable members will recall the history of this matter which, however, I will shortly recapitulate. One of the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions announced on 30 April 1981 was that the Government proposed to endeavour to sell the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, as a going concern to private enterprise. In consequence of that decision expressions of interest for the acquisition of the factory were invited with a closing date of 12 June 1981, which was later extended to 8 July 1981. Before that process could be completed, the Senate resolved to refer the Government's decision to sell the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. Subsequently, on 23 September 1981, the Senate resolved that a select committee be established to report on the future of the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo . As I earlier mentioned, the Senate Select Committee presented its report on the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, on 9 March 1982. It is still to present its report on the future of the Government Clothing Factory, Coburg.

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the Committee were divided in their views on the future of the Ordnance Factory. Senator Martyr, the Chairman, and Senator Crichton-Browne recommended the sale of the factory as a going concern; that if efforts to sell failed the possibility of sale of various sections of the factory as going concerns be investigated; and that if all efforts failed the operation of the factory be wound down and closed with appropriate assistance being given to apprentices and employees thereby displaced. The other two members of the Committee, Senator Button and Senator Siddons, dissented.

On 17 March, 1982 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in answer to a question in the House from the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier), expressed the Government's position in the light of the Senate Committee's report. He said:

I have seen the report on the future of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The Government will be looking at the report quite closely. I note that the main part of the report recommends that the Ordnance Factory still be sold. That is consistent with the Review of Commonwealth Functions recommendation of a year ago and the Government's efforts since then which in a sense had been suspended during the Senate Committee inquiry. The Government will evaluate the various proposals, or offers of tenders and, when that process is finished, it will come to a final decision as to whether or not the factory will be sold.

The Government would much prefer that the factory could be sold to private enterprise so that new investment could be attracted to Bendigo and to the Ordnance Factory. This would provide opportunities for expanded activity. More money would flow through the factory and into the city.

In respect of the Committee's recommendation that if the factory could not be sold it should be closed down the Prime Minister advised the honourable member that the Government did not accept that part of the Committee's recommendations. The Prime Minister said:

The Government believed that its reaction to that part of the recommendations ought to be made known quickly so that the concern that would be felt as a result of that recommendation could be put completely and absolutely at rest.
The Prime Minister assured the House of the future of the factory by saying:

Having examined all the options and in particular the impact on Bendigo, the Government, if it is not successful in its efforts to sell the Ordnance Factory to a vigorous and vital private enterprise concern, will continue to operate the factory as a government operation.
The Prime Minister visited Bendigo on 22 March 1982 and, in the company of the honourable member for Bendigo, addressed the factory employees and repeated that assurance.

Thus, in order to bring the matter to a conclusion, the Government decided to explore the interest of private enterprise in taking on the operation of the factory, in the light of the Senate Committee report, by readvertising for expressions of interest for the purchase or lease of the factory. As I advised the House at the beginning of this statement, the Government had decided that the factory will continue as a government factory. An expression of interest was received from one company, Vickers Australia Ltd., to lease the factory. The Government did not consider that the company's proposal met the Government's requirements for the future operation of the factory or the commitments which had been made by the Government to the people of Bendigo.

In my public announcement of the Government's decision on 7 July 1982 I emphasised the responsibilities that lay ahead of the Government, the management of the factory and the whole work force in assuring the future of the factory. I said:

It remains for factory management and staff to work together with the Government to demonstrate that the Ordnance Factory Bendigo has an important part to play in the field of defence support and that cost and performance achievements in the future will justify the Government's decision to continue its operation as a government factory.

In view of this background I have, since undertaking the responsibilities of the new Department of Defence Support, been concerned to remove the uncertainties about the future of the factory and put in train action which will allow the employees to look ahead with growing confidence.

Prior to the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government had agreed that implementation of recommendations contained in a joint management review of the munitions factories should proceed. With the exception of Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, and the Australian Government Clothing Factory, the recommended changes in upper structure positions in the factories have been implemented and staffing of the positions is proceeding. Consequential changes for junior management are in hand. Now that the Government has made its decision to retain Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, action is in hand to implement the necessary management changes in that factory.

I would like to take this opportunity to indicate the investment being made by the Government in the factory and actions being taken to establish a better workload for it. In the 1982-83 Budget, expenditure of $947,000 is provided for. This includes $80,000 for computing facilities, $190,000 for rationalisation of production facility for 500lb bombs, plant acquisitions of $200,000 and repairs and maintenance of $477,000. Such expenditure of nearly $1m in this financial year is an emphatic demonstration of the Government's readiness to meet the commitment made to the factory's employees, to the civic authorities and to the people of Bendigo by the Prime Minister, myself and the honourable member for Bendigo. But more than that, there is included in the works design list of the Department of Transport and Construction for this year provision for a new electroplating facility at an estimated cost of $550,000 and it is planned to call tenders for extensions to the metrology laboratory-a key facility in meeting the precision requirements of ordnance manufacture-in March 1983 at an estimated cost of $415,000.

The factory has budgeted for 310,000 man hours of work in the current financial year, being an increase of 50,000 hours in defence work and an overall increase of 18,000 hours over the 1981-82 work load. The future of the factory is really dependent upon the volume of defence and commercial work which can be directed or attracted to it under the nation's defence program or the guidelines for engaging in commercial activity. Thus the work load of the factory will respond to the overall national defence effort in time of peace or the competitiveness of the factory to obtain commercial work. Nevertheless one of the most significant prospects for increased work load, as well as opportunity to acquire and apply new and advanced technology, lies with Project Hamel. This project is designed to equip the Army with the British 105mm light gun as a key weapon over the next decade.

It is anticipated that the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, will manufacture a significant proportion of components and the gun will be assembled at Bendigo. An executive engineer from the factory will play a significant role in the furtherance of this project. Dr J. Barclay has been selected to fill a new post in the United Kingdom as the liaison engineer for the project. Dr Barclay will leave Australia on 16 September 1982, to take up a three-year posting.

In another effort to open up new opportunities for Bendigo a factory respresentative has recently visited the United States to discuss the possibility of sub-contract work with United States firms. Discussions have taken place at officer level with the Victorian Government. It is to be hoped that the Victorian Government will be true to its public statements that it wishes to direct more of the major engineering work of its own instrumentalities to Bendigo.

Whilst the Government would have been happy to have been able to sell or lease the factory to a private enterprise purchaser, able to put new investment into the factory, to expand the commercial opportunities for the factory within Australia and overseas, and to secure and expand employment at Bendigo, it was not, in the events which have happened since the announcement of the decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions in April 1981, possible to achieve such a sale or lease within a reasonable time and with appropriate guarantees. Nevertheless, I am sure honourable members, the factory work force and the people of Bendigo will understand that by the actions which I have related, the Government will now do all that it reasonably can to improve the efficiency of the factory and expand the work load of it and thereby improve the prospects of its future operations. I present the following paper:
Report of the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories-Ministerial Statement, 19 August 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) and now move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate firstly that the Opposition is concerned that the Government has again decided to set aside the two-hour rule. This statement was delivered to us at half past twelve, a time when most of the people whom we would want to contact would not be available. The Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) has chosen not to wait the two hours, which is the general courtesy of the House, but to make a statement in the House at two o' clock-half an hour before that time has expired. That action is in line with the statement itself. It is a 'Save Bendigo for Bourchier' statement. It says very little about the future of Bendigo Ordnance Factory. It does not in any way apologise for the problems that have been created in the Bendigo area and, if I may say so, in many other areas of Australia by the incompetent, inefficient and impractical decisions which were hastily thrown together under what was called the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the razor gang or the Lynch gang, which made numerous recommendations which cannot stand up even to cursory examination and most of which have not been able to be carried out because they were stupid recommendations in the first place based on ideological nonsense rather than practical considerations. In Canberra, for instance, which is the responsibility of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), who congratulated the Minister for Defence Support on this statement, the Australian Capital Territory Motor Vehicle Testing Centre, which was making $2m a year, was listed to be sold because someone might make a bob out of it. That decision has been reversed. The Government will now pay someone about $1m to sell the Belconnen Mall. Other such decisions have been made around the country. It is unfortunate that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier) chose to support those decisions in this House and chose to indicate in advance, as the Minister has now, a conviction that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory should be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: Bendigo, like most provincial cities, has a limited range of employment opportunities which form the basis of its economy. If one of the major units of that economy is placed under threat, as was the Bendigo Ordnance Factory by the razor gang considerations, the town itself is concerned, investment is slow and there is a period of no activity or regressive activity. The threat over Bendigo has now been around for a couple of years. If we take note of the speculation about an early election we can better understand this statement. It is in stark contrast to a statement made within two months of the last Federal election when it was announced that $9m-worth of investment would take place at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The Minister has generously indicated that the Government has now decided to go ahead with certain projects in respect of the Ordnance Factory . I remind the Minister that if he reads the last Budget Papers he will find the same projects were announced 12 months ago. When asked why those projects were to proceed at a time when the factory was for sale, the Government said they were necessary irrespective of whether the factory was sold, to be operated by a private operator, or continued as a government operation. This statement reannounces last year's statements.

It is welcome that the Government has decided to go ahead with the 105mm light gun project. Like most of the Government's projects, it has been an annual announcement since 1976. It was announced in this House in the 1976 program for defence. It was stated in that program that the commencement date for the placement of orders would be 1978. It has started, but this is 1982. That work could have been going on at Bendigo for the last three years, had the Government met its undertakings to this House, as it very rarely does. In this year's Defence estimates-the Minister knows this as well as I do-the amount of increase for capital equipment for the defence forces over last year's appropriations for that purpose is less than 5 per cent. That is less than one-third of the inflation rate in defence equipment costs, so there has been a cutback in the amount appropriated this year for defence equipment. On past records we can guarantee that that amount will not be met. There has not been one year since this Government has been in office in which the full amount appropriated for defence equipment was actually spent. Last year less than 80 per cent was spent. When the Government talks about an advanced defence program, that is exactly what it does-talks, talks and talks some more. But it does not do anything. It does as little as it can, defers as much as it can and ultimately pays far more for much less that it ought. The consequences of this statement should be borne by any government and any member who supported it and who represents the area involved. Had the razor gang properly examined what it was recommending, no such recommendation would have been made. A recommendation to sell a major item of the economic base of a city such as Bendigo should not be made unless there is substantive evidence that that sale is practical and possible. No such evidence existed. Such a recommendation should not be made unless it is certain that the sale will benefit that community and benefit the taxpayers of Australia. That also was not true of the Minister's statement. There was no potential buyer, no potential usage, only an ideological conviction of a committee that the sale should take place because the factory happened to belong to the Government, and probably because the facility was losing money. That situation is not changed as a result of this statement, and it has not been changed by the two years of uncertainty which has been created in the Bendigo area. Life has its facts, and some operations are run by governments for the sole reason that they are not profitable and therefore not attractive to private enterprise. No private enterprise company is interested in running operations, no matter how necessary, if it does not make a profit. Why should it? It is in the business of making profits, not providing a public service.

This statement comes to this House because of incompetence and lack of consideration. What did the razor gang consider when it made this decision? What were the bases of its consideration? Who was the buyer? Who was the operator? What were the bases of the assurances that the sale would increase the activities of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory? There were no assurances; statements were picked out of the air, just as the decision was picked out of the air by people who had not done their homework but were pressed for decisions. They made decisions without proper and adequate consideration.

The situation existed, and still exists, in which educational institutions, for instance, were recommended for amalgamation on figures that were six years old. In the case of the Preston Institute of Technology, the razor gang report proudly and grandly announced-I know the honourable member for Bendigo knows about engineering as well as I do-that the Government would direct that no new students be taken in for 1981. The institution had made that announcement two years earlier and the razor gang did not even know about it. Talk about incompentence. The course had been cancelled two years earlier yet we had a Minister of the Crown tell us in this Parliament: 'We have directed them not to do what they told us they would not do two years ago'. That was nonsense, and this report is nonsense. It is the 'save Bourchier' report. It almost indicates that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has decided that he will have an election. Where is the $9m the Government promised in 1980? One million dollars is promised in the Minister's statement. It is the same $1m which the Government promised a year ago and, if the Government is returned, the same $1m will be promised next year. The Government is good at promising; it just does not do anything.

This Government should be censured for its incompetent management, its insincerity and for the fact that it has brought Australia to its knees because of decision making such as is reflected in this document and the razor gang document. Ideology of any type will not solve problems while we have a government that thinks the word 'practical' means an examination in a school. This Government is incompetent, it is inefficient and it lacks integrity, and this document shows it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourchier Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I say how pleased I am with the statement delivered today by the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) in response to the report from the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories. The Opposition has gone to great lengths to say that the Government made some sort of a rash and hurried decision when it decided to sell the Ordnance Factory. Members of the Opposition, who are obviously socialist based, overlook the fact that this Government is a private enterprise government . We, unfortunately for the Opposition, believe in the philosophy that has made Australia great; that is, that private enterprise is more capable of running organisations than are governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It is all right. I will continue when the yahoos on the Opposition side stop. The situation is quite clear. We believed-I supported the belief-in the initial stages that the Bendigo factory, which was running at about half strength and relying on outside sources for about 60 per cent of its contracts, would be well served if a viable operation could be achieved in the private enterprise sector. In the initial stages three or four top firms, large firms, expressed an interest in negotiating with the Government. That was prior to the appointment of the Senate Committee which held up proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: History now records that because of the long delays caused by the Senate inquiry, when ultimately the Government could proceed the expressions of interest dropped to interest from one firm. The Government, very wisely and properly, because of the emotive issue that it was and because of the concern at the effect it was having on the factory employees and the rest of the people in Bendigo-I requested that this be done-reached a decision very promptly. The situation now is that the Government has carried out the promise that it had already made-that if the factory could not be sold it would remain as it was. The Minister for Defence Support, within whose portfolio the factory is now listed, announced in Bendigo that the sale would not go ahead and that the factory would stay as it was. He also pledged that this Government would be doing its utmost to help the factory to expand.

The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) in his remarks mentioned that $9m was promised for the factory some years ago. The point that he well knows-I am sure that he made his remarks with tongue in cheek-is that the contracts associated with ordnance factories do not automatically arrive on the table the day that projects are listed. They just do not turn up quite that quickly. The F111 aircraft, for example, did not arrive on the day it was suggested we should buy it. The Leopard tanks did not arrive in the first year. I will come back to that subject in a moment because an interesting story relating to the factory is connected with it. The Hamel gun project was one of the projects to be financed under that proposal. The Government properly took steps to find out which was the best howitzer for the Army to have. The Army required that proper testing be carried out. There were two contenders for the proposed supply of this gun. One weapon was an American model and the other was English. It was after lengthy testing that the decision was made to use the United Kingdom model. Having made that decision the Government has proceeded with the contract for the Hamel gun and we have now had the announcement that the project is well under way. In fact , I understand that it will be a matter of only a short time before the gun is actually being produced in Australia at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.

In line with that and in line with the promise of the Minister, Dr Barclay, one of the top senior engineers at the Ordnance Factory, is being sent to England so that he can learn at first hand all the necessary technology related to the gun. Yet we have the honourable member for Corio deriding him through his suggestions that this Government has delayed the process. Dr Barclay and his staff know full well that the proper processes are being followed. I refer to the remarks made earlier by members of the Opposition. I remind members of the Opposition that in 1974 when the Labor Government proposed to purchase Leopard tanks-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—The honourable member should listen to this. I made the proposition to the then Minister for Defence, Lance Barnard, that parts of those tanks could adequately have been made in Bendigo. I refer to the turrets and guns which were not made by the Germans but were made in England. We could have made those turrets and guns here. What did Lance Barnard and the Australian Labor Party say? They said: 'No way; we can't do it. We couldn't set up for it. It is an impossibility'. They scrubbed it flat. It was in reference to that time that Mr Kennedy, the former member for Bendigo, commented recently that I said in 1974 that we should sell the factory. I did say that; I do not deny it. I said it out of sheer anger at the Labor Party refusing to do something for the factory at Bendigo. I said: 'All you are going to do is see this factory go down hill and close up. If that is the way you want to treat the people of Bendigo why don't you sell it?'. From that remark members of the Labor Party have elected to suggest that I wanted to sell the factory. I am just telling them the facts. The Bendigo people have not forgotten-honourable members opposite might think that they have-that the Labor Party would not give them one chance to make the gun turrets for the Leopard tanks; not one chance.
