The Labor Party gained no credit for itself in regard to what it did for the Ordnance Factory. While it was in Government it did nothing for the Ordnance Factory except let it run down . That is a fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to mention a matter that occurred due to my efforts. I read in the paper where the State Government of the day had let a contract to a firm called Demac Products Pty Ltd to supply huge dredges to the Loy Yang dam project for the State Electricity Commission. I was told that this firm called Demac had not allowed the Ordnance Factory to tender for the supply of the crawler tractor parts. I found out at the time that this was not true and that the firm had not received an approach from the Ordnance Factory. I approached the Minister on the matter. He very quickly organised a meeting with Demac. Despite all the controversy going on as to whether the Ordnance Factory was to be sold, the Minister promised and the Government gave an undertaking that irrespective of the results the Ordnance Factory would continue-hounourable members seem to have forgotten this-to supply defence contracts and it would be available to complete any contract entered into, including the one for Demac.

Under those conditions Demac was quite prepared to accept negotiations with the Ordnance Factory. What do we find? The Ordnance Factory made an approach and put in its very best price which was just slightly higher than the German quote which Demac had. The Minister for Minerals and Energy in the State Labor Government, Mr White, said: 'We will buy these crawler tractors overseas. We are not going to give them to Bendigo'. He had forgotten altogether what he, Mr Landeryou and Mr Kennedy said in Bendigo. They said: 'We will make sure that in Victoria any contract goods for State Government must be manufactured and supplied by Victorian companies.' Having said that, as soon as the first opportunity arose of deriding the Federal Government on the matter they turned around and were prepared to forget about it. Now that we have brought it out in the open Mr Landeryou has run hot-tail and is ready to negotiate and try to save face. I wish him luck because we are doing all we can.

The Minister at the table has organised a meeting between the State Electricity Commission in Victoria, Demac, the supplying contractor and the Ordnance Factory . The initial meeting was held yesterday. That meeting allowed further negotiations with the Minister giving full range to the Ordnance Factory and flexibility to allow it to negotiate a price. If anything can be done by this Government to help that Ordnance Factory get this contract it is being done. I suggest to honourable members that if that contract does not come to Bendigo it will be quite obvious that Mr White prefers to have the products made overseas. We will just wait and see what happens. I hope that he has enough sense to back off, because Bendigo needs that contract.

The situation that occurred in Bendigo was, in many senses, a very emotive issue; quite understandably so. One of the things the honourable member for Corio said which one cannot deny-in fact I totally agree with him-is that the Ordnance Factory is one of the largest wage payers or employers in Bendigo. If it were to close down it would be tragic. Unfortunately prominent people in Bendigo who are not associated with the factory took the stance that that was what the Government was going to do. This was never a fact. The Government always said that if it could not sell or lease the factory it would remain as it was. There was never any risk that that factory would close down. This was the tragedy which caused all the emotion, upset and unnecessary problems to the people who worked at the factory.

I am delighted that the matter has been resolved. I am delighted that the factory is staying as it is. I am more delighted that the Minister who is now in charge of the matter is taking such positive actions to try to provide more work for the factory. I only hope that the Opposition will lean on its State colleagues to ensure that that particular contract comes to Bendigo. I hope that the other proposition which I have put to the Minister in regard to project Hamel is acted on. The management of that project at some time should come back to Bendigo where I believe it belongs. I have put this matter to the Minister. He obviously has to consider that fact, but the project management of operation Hamel in my opinion should be back in Bendigo. I am pressing for that to happen. I hope it will happen and I believe that we will ultimately achieve that end. Now that this is behind us the important thing is that we must all work for the benefit of the factory in Bendigo. In doing so I suggest the Labor Party could do something positive instead of being negative as usual. It should encourage the unions to do all they can to help productivity at the factory. The factory relies a lot on its ability to turn out the huge type of manufactured products that it does for various industries. It must attempt to keep its prices competitive and keep the work up to schedule. The factory can do so provided it is given a fair go. I have no doubt that the workers of the factory have the expertise. The factory has some of the best engineers and tradesmen. I believe the future of that factory is totally ensured only with the support it is now getting from this Government. It is hoped that the factory does not stay as it is. It is my ambition and my aim, now that he decision has been reached, that that factory will expand.

Finally, I thank the Minister at the table for being so prompt in having the decision reached when it was obvious that there was a lack of interest in the purchase of the factory. The matter was not delayed unnecessarily. The people of Bendigo had suffered immensely as a result of the emotive campaign whipped up by others in regard to this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of those occasions when the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) comes into the House with a statement which reverses completely the whole trend of what was a thoroughly incompetent and dishonest decision made for and on behalf of the Government in the first place. By reversing that decision he expects to receive the plaudits of the House as he has received the plaudits of the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier). I say to the honourable member that this is the first occasion on which the question of the future of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory has been mentioned where the honourable member has been prepared to stand up in this Parliament and say one word on behalf of the future of the factory and on behalf of the work force. It is extraordinary that the Minister for Defence Support, who is at the table, is relying so heavily in terms of the future of this factory upon the fact that a Labor Government has been appointed in Victoria. It will be given the responsibility of finding the work to solve the problems of that factory.

SPEECH.PARA: It was pointed out by Senator Button in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories that one of the problems which has bedevilled not merely the Ordnance Factory but indeed the railways workshop at Bendigo is that they have been continually deprived of contracts and large capital works have been very significantly underutilised. If we look at the history of this factory one is entitled to ask the Minister, as one is entitled to ask the honourable member for Bendigo: Were the decision and the recommendations of the so-called Review of Commonwealth Functions which were supported by the Minister and supported loyally by the honourable member for Bendigo properly based? I believe that on any objective assessment of those decisions one will find that what occurred was that a number of senior Ministers virtually made a grab bag of proposals about where they could cut funds without any regard at all for the social and economic consequences of those decisions. It is no small decision to propose the sale or the closing down of a factory in a major regional centre which is such a large employer. The people of Bendigo believe, as members of the Opposition believe, that the decision to sell-as Senator Button pointed out-had been adopted simply to avoid the political odium that was associated with a Government decision to close it down. That is the political reality. What was the result of that in Bendigo? The result was a climate of economic uncertainty in Bendigo.

One cannot threaten the livelihood of so many people without casting an economic cloud upon the whole community. Economic uncertainty and a great deal of anguish were produced. That very difficult situation affected the whole community and led to very significant protests from every important economic and social unit within the community, including the Mayor, the councillors, the trade union movement, the employer groups and the commercial sector. Everybody's livelihood was touched by this decision. The people of Bendigo were entitled to turn at least to a voice in this Parliament which would express their sentiments and their hopes for the continuation of this operation. Did they have that voice from the honourable member for Bendigo? He talked today about his five-minute exercise in the corner with the Minister saying: 'What can we do to put pressure on the Cain Labor Government?' Where was the honourable member for Bendigo, the voice of the people of Bendigo, their one voice in this Parliament when this decision was made? Did he stand up, as I have heard other honourable members who support the Government from time to time do, and say: 'Look, although I am a part of this Government and although I believe that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is a man of proven vision and capacity, I am bound to say on behalf of my electorate that on this occasion the Government is wrong'. The honourable member for Bendigo is commonly referred affectionately to as 'Boots' within the parliamentary party because every time the Prime Minister bends over he can see his boots.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order!

—Let us look at the record of the honourable gentleman. In 1981, from the day when this decision was made, the voice of the people of Bendigo, the honourable member whom the Government is now trying to bail out, made four speeches in the Parliament. That was his total contribution in 1981. Two of those speeches related to House business. I have not included those occasions on which he moved the gag. One speech was to a condolence motion and one was in relation to a matter of public importance raised by the Opposition in regard to public housing finance. The honourable gentleman was also moved to give notice of motion on drug trafficking and he made a personal explanation. He also asked nine questions, none of which related to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.
—There would have been one, surely.

—I should have hoped so. I should have hoped that the voice of Bendigo would have spoken on behalf of his electorate, but not once in 1981 did he do so. He shed a tear when somebody died and he moved a gag to silence the Opposition, but not once did he ask a question of his beloved Prime Minister in regard to the future of this operation. In 1982-
—Tell us about Richmond Council. I have got all that on you and I will read that out.
—What was the activity of the honourable member for Bendigo, the man who in the last five minutes has become so desperately active?
—Wait till I tell them about you and the Richmond Council.
—Order!
—All I can say is that, at a time when the Prime Minister is talking about increased productivity, it is just as well the honourable member for Bendigo is not paid according to his productivity.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne Ports will resume his seat. I warn the honourable member for Bendigo against interjecting. If he persists, I shall have to deal with him.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I accept your criticism, but I query why you did not pull that gentleman up-
—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo will resume his seat .

—I assure the honourable member for Bendigo that I am not casting a single aspersion. I am quoting his record on behalf of the people whom he represents in regard to this issue. In terms of his productivity in 1982, the Parliament heard three speeches from the honourable member for Bendigo.
—But they know I work for them.
—Three speeches, one of which--
—Every one--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Bendigo.
—One of which had an actual reference to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory . When dealing with an interjection from this side of the House in 1982 he was still asserting that it ought to be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a member of parliament long enough to realise that not all the work that members of parliament do on behalf of their electorates takes place in this House. Therefore, in fairness to the honourable member for Bendigo, who would have to admit that according to the Hansard record he does not seem to have done too much on this issue, I thought I should check the level of activity within his own electorate. Surely, within the heart of Bendigo, we would expect the honourable member to lead deputations and delegations regarding this problem, again as the elected voice of Bendigo. All I can say is that I hope that the Parliamentary Library's Press cuttings are inaccurate or are not as complete as they could be. After exhaustive research we could not find much reference to the honourable member for Bendigo in relation to this issue. On 22 May 1981, he was referred to in the Bendigo Advertiser following a very large meeting of just on 2,000 people at the Bendigo Town Hall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Led by Halfpenny, one of your mates.
—I do not know who it was led by, but the honourable member for Bendigo was not--

—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne Ports will resume his seat. I suggest to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports that he might like consciously to be a little more relevant to the paper before the House.
—I am very relevant, sir.
—Order! The Chair has been very--
— Do not forget the Nugan Hand Bank.

—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo will remain silent. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports has received a degree of consideration from the Chair in that exercise which was relevant to the challenge implicit in the remarks of other members but I feel that he is now going beyond the point of reasonableness. I ask him to address himself to the question before the Chair.

—The question was the future of this factory. I am saying that the promises of this Minister and this Government in regard to the future of this factory can no more be believed on this day in 1982 than they could be believed in terms of their past references. That is the point of my statement. I believe that the record will prove that what I am saying is true.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the subject of the meeting of 22 May. A large meeting was attended by 2,000 people. The leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was there but there was a telegram from the honourable member for Bendigo stating that he could not be there because he was at an important meeting in Sydney concerning commercial television stations. Mr Deputy Speaker, in deference to your injunction, I will not delay the House on this point. I simply say this: The Press cuttings and the parliamentary records show that on every occasion when this matter was brought before the Parliament the honourable member for Bendigo's voice was singularly absent. At every point he was a supporter of Government policy.

Prior to the 1980 election, this Government and the honourable member for Bendigo as its spokesman were happy to announce an $8m to $9m program of expansion. It has never taken place. The people of Bendigo were entitled to accept that as a truthful statement by the honourable gentleman. He was speaking on behalf of the Government. That promise was never fulfilled and he knew it would never be fulfilled. In its place they were given a promise of closure, the promise of sale and the promise of economic uncertainty. There was no more care for the truth on that occasion by the honourable member for Bendigo, who was speaking on behalf of the Government, than there is care for the truth in the statement made by the Minister and the honourable member for Bendigo in his speech today.

The people of Bendigo have been subjected to a period of anguish and economic insecurity as a result of this Government's inability to apply an effective policy over many years for the development of these factories. It compounded the situation by a stupid and irresponsible decision. It was a decision for which the honourable member for Bendigo became the mealy-mouthed spokesman in this place and everywhere else. On this occasion the record of the honourable gentleman, both in Bendigo and in this Parliament, means that the people of Bendigo can give no more credibility to the promises of this ailing and desperate Minister and this ailing and desperate Government as they desperately try to preserve one more seat and the neck of the honourable member for Bendigo, who, on his own record of credibility, will be rejected by the people of Bendigo at the next election.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sections 6 and 7 of the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973, I present the Remuneration Tribunal's 1982 review.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Newman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable members will by now be aware that the Government has accepted the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendations and determinations. In making its review , the Tribunal took into account the state of the national economy and, within proper limits, the effects which its decision may have on it. It gave careful consideration to the matters raised by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) concerning the necessity to achieve a moderation of the rate of wage and salary increases in the community in order to avoid an immediate rise in unemployment, to reduce inflationary pressures and to avoid further damage to our international competitiveness. The Tribunal was persuaded that exceptional circumstances exist and consequently made determinations and recommendations based on a general level of increase in salaries of 7 per cent. Remuneration directed at the reimbursement of outgoings and expenditure-for example, electorate allowance and travelling allowance-has been adjusted according to the Tribunal's assessment of what is necessary to achieve a proper reimbursement. It would be inequitable for persons within the Tribunal's jurisdiction to suffer a penalty in respect of expenditure made by them in carrying out their duties and responsibilities.

The Remuneration Tribunal's willingness to consider the national interest gives a clear lead to other wage fixing bodies. The Government hopes that wage fixing bodies throughout Australia will also be prepared to consider the wider ramifications of their decisions. At a time when wage rises are pricing people out of a tight labour market, wage fixing authorities have a responsibility to take into account the economic climate in which they operate. In accepting the Remuneration Tribunal's determinations, the Government has also sought to give a lead. Honourable members will be aware that there is considerable public support for the proposition that parliamentarians should practise what they preach with regard to wage restraint. The Government is greatly encouraged by decisions already taken by a number of large Australian companies to restrain increases in salaries. If the example set by the Government is followed by other employers and accepted by wage and salary earners generally, it will play an important part in achieving the levels of wage restraint that Australia needs.

I turn now to the Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill 1982. Part II of the Bill implements the recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to the salaries and allowances of the judiciary. I draw particular attention to clause 6 of the Bill, which changes the eligibility for the Canberra allowance payable to justices of the High Court of Australia. The Act as it stands provides for an annual allowance to be payable to a justice of the High Court who held office on 1 July 1980 and who has continued to have his sole or principal place of residence outside Canberra. The allowance is not payable to a justice who has his sole or principal place of residence in Canberra or to a justice appointed after 1 July 1980.

In its 1981 and 1982 reviews, the Remuneration Tribunal recommended that the limitation to justices appointed before 1 July 1980 should be removed. The Government has looked at the matter again in the light of the Tribunal's views and representations which it has received on this subject. The State governments , especially those of the less populous States, have been strongly of the view that the justices should not all be compelled to live in Canberra. The argument runs that justices who continue to live in their home States will keep in touch with the shades of thought and attitude around the nation which will help to keep the High Court in tune with the federal nature of Australia. The representations have come not only from the States but also from the Law Council of Australia, from bodies representing the legal profession and from individual members of the legal profession.

In the light of these expressions of opinion, the Government now believes that it would be appropriate to adopt the recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal and to remove the bar to the payment of the Canberra allowance to High Court justices appointed after 1 July 1980 who choose to retain their sole or princpal place of residence outside Canberra. It is not intended that the allowance be payable to justices who take up residence in Canberra, or to a justice who, having taken up residence in Canberra, then decides to return to live elsewhere.

Part III of the Bill proposes to amend the Ministers of State Act 1952 by increasing the annual sum appropriated for ministerial salaries to enable the increases recommended by the Tribunal to be payable. It is proposed to increase this sum from $452,000 to $575,000. The opportunity has also been taken to propose certain amendments to the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973 which are unrelated to the Tribunal's review. The first of these amendments is designed to remove Northern Territory and Norfolk Island public offices and members of the National Aboriginal Conference from the scope of the appropriation provisions of the Act. It is not appropriate, nor was it ever intended, that payments to the holders of these public offices be made from the Commonwealth Consolidated Revenue Fund, but rather that the responsible governments and the Conference respectively should provide the funds required.

The Bill also proposes to empower the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly to disallow determinations by the Tribunal in respect of its members. This power currently lies with the Commonwealth Parliament, but it is considerd to be more appropriately a matter for the Assembly. The disallowance power would not extend to variation of the Tribunal's determinations. It is also proposed to bring within the provisions of sub-section 7 (11) of the Act the office of member of the National Aboriginal Conference. The effect of this amendment would be to treat members of the Conference in the same way as full time Commonwealth employees. Sub-section 7 (11) provides that full time Commonwealth employees are not entitled to receive remuneration in respect of a part time public office unless a specific exemption is made by regulation. A further minor amendment proposed in respect of the National Aboriginal Conference is that it will now be included within the Act as a body the offices of which are within the Tribunal's jurisdiction. This has previously been achieved by regulation and the proposed amendment is of a machinery nature only.

Finally, the Bill seeks to extend the Tribunal's jurisdiction with respect to certain Commonwealth owned or controlled companies. The employees of Commonwealth companies limited by guarantee have been outside the Tribunal's jurisdicition but there is no reason why this should be so and it is now proposed that they be included. Few such offices are involved and existing arrangements would not be upset by the amendment as it would only make it possible for such offices to be referred to the Tribunal in terms of a specific request. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Young) adjourned.
BOUNTY (SHIPS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982
Bill presented by Mr Hodgman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 to enable fishing vessels which are over 150 gross construction tons but which do not exceed 21 metres in length to be eligible for bounty. The Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 replaced the Ship Construction Bounty Act 1975 and gave effect to the Government's decision, announced on 29 November 1979, to continue the assistance arrangements for certain ships, boats and other vessels. The 1980 Bounty Act was introduced to simplify the administrative arrangements and it was the Government 's intention that the same size vessels should be covered by the new Act as were covered by the 1975 Act. The definition of 'bountiable vessel' in the new Act however, has the effect of excluding fishing vessels that are 21 metres or less in length but over 150 gross contruction tons from the bounty. This was not the Government's intention.

It is expected that the inclusion of these fishing vessels for bounty will not have a significant effect on government expenditure. The Government has no knowledge of any locally built ships in this category which have been completed. The operation of the Bill will be retrospective to 1 July 1980 which is the date upon which the Bounty (Ships) Act became operative. In a few moments I will be tabling related Customs Tariff Proposals which propose to amend the Customs Tariff Act to provide for fishing vessels falling within the description of vessels which are now subject to bounty to be free of duties on importation into Australia. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 19 (1982).

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to a proposed alteration to the Customs Tariff Act 1966 which complements the Bounty (Ships) Bill which I have just introduced in the House. The proposals, which operate on and from 20 August 1982, provide duty free admission for those fishing vessels which become eligible for bounty under the provisions of the Bounty (Ships) Bill. A summary setting out the nature of the change has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hodgman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to provide bounty assistance to the production in Australia of certain fresh berry fruits used for processing. The decision to adopt this form of assistance follows the Government's acceptance of a recommendation by the Industries Assistance Commission in its report No. 276 of 24 August 1981 entitled 'Fruit and Fruit Products'. The report covered a wide range of miscellaneous processed fruit products and fresh and processed passionfruit and berry fruits. The Government's decision on the report was announced on 21 April 1982. The Government accepted the IAC's views that assistance in the form of a bounty rather than a tariff would be more appropriate in this case. A tariff on imports would have the effect of increasing the cost of locally produced jam and juice products using imported berry fruit and reduce the competitiveness of those jams and juices against imports. Furthermore a tariff was considered not to be an efficient means of assisting producers of berry fruits.

The Bill provides for the bounty to be payable at the rate of $100 per tonne of commercially cultivated fresh fruit provided to processors of the fruit. The bounty is to be paid directly to the growers of the fruit and bounty payments will be based on information provided in regular returns to be furnished by the processors. The scheme is to operate for a period of five years from 1 July 1982 and bounty payments in the first year are estimated to be $300,000. The bounty will provide a level of assistance to the berry fruit industry estimated to be equivalent to a tariff of about 10 per cent. This level of assistance is in keeping with that recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission, and accepted by the Government, for most other fruit and fruit products covered by the Commission's report. The Government expects that the bounty scheme proposed by this Bill will assist growers to adjust to newer technology and greater mechanisation so that they can withstand increasing competition from imports. The Government also expects that this assistance measure will ensure a greater uptake of locally produced berry fruits for processing. On behalf of all Tasmanian members of this House and indeed our Tasmanian senatorial colleagues I say this measure is very good news indeed for Tasmania. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hodgman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill applies to the whole of Australia and amends the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Act 1980 to extend the present arrangement under which a subsidy of $80 a tonne is paid on LPG use by certain consumers for a further twelve months until 28 March 1984. Provisions have also been included in the Bill to impose limit- ations on the amounts of subsidised gas available to industrial consumers after the first of October this year. The LPG subsidy was introduced for three years in March 1980 with the objective of providing sufficient time for household users to adjust to rapidly rising LPG prices.

The extension of the subsidy is largely to help the many thousands of householders, small businessmen and other consumers who depend on LPG, to cope through a period of uncertainty in the world LPG prices, expected to occur in the next year or two. On the other hand the Government does not intend that the subsidy encourage new large scale industrial use of LPG. This policy was clearly stated in 1980 when the subsidy was made available to industrial and commercial users in areas where natural gas was not readily available.

Over the last two years the competitiveness of LPG as an industrial fuel has created a situation where large industrial consumers with heavy reliance on fuel oil could be encouraged to convert to LPG. The Government does not wish to encourage such conversion for a number of reasons.

First, the resulting large increase in subsidy payments could not be justified. Secondly, LPG is a valuable transport fuel and petrochemical feedstock. Unconstrained large scale industrial use of the fuel could establish a demand imbalance leading eventually to a reduction in the amount available for traditional and premium applications such as small commercial and household consumers who, by reason of their location, do not have access to suitable alternative forms of energy. Thirdly, it would be in conflict with the Government's basic policy aim of minimising Australia's dependence on imported liquid fuels.

The considerations that I have just mentioned led the Government to announce on 25 September 1981 its intention to impose limitations on the amount of subsidised gas to which industrial and commercial enterprise would be entitled. At that time the Government also announced that a review of the subsidy scheme would be made prior to the expiry of the scheme in March 1983. Following that review, which culminated in the decision to extend the subsidy for a further 12 months, the administrative arrangements relating to the imposition of the limitations were finalised. The limits to be imposed on the usage of subsidised gas as proposed by this Bill, will apply from 1 October 1982. From that date most industrial enterprises will be restricted to the equivalent of 1,000 tonnes per annum of subsidised gas.

The Government does recognise, however, that on 25 September 1981 some users were already using or were committed to use LPG in excess of the equivalent of 1 ,000 tonnes per annum. The Government will not deprive such users of the benefit of the subsidy. For this reason the Bill provides a mechanism to permit the Minister to increase the limit if he is satisfied that certain contracts relating to the purchase of gas or equipment, or conversion of existing plant and equipment to gas, prior to 25 September 1981, would require the equivalent of an annual usage in excess of 1,000 tonnes per annum.

The Bill also provides for notifications to be given by industrial and commercial users to the distributors from whom they purchase the gas, and to the Minister, when they have exceeded their limit or they are about to reach their limit.

Penalties have been introduced into the legislation ranging from $2,000 to $50, 000 for offences associated with failing to produce documents or failing to notify or knowingly obtaining or attempting to obtain the benefit of a subsidy payment to which the user is not entitled. The Government will continue to monitor the impact of this subsidy on its energy policy and will conduct a further review prior to the new expiry date of 27 March 1984. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr McVeigh, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Northern Territory (Self- Government) Act 1978 to confirm that minerals in land acquired under section 70 of the Act are vested in the Commonwealth. As far as this provision is concerned I am speaking on behalf of my colleague, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who administers this section of the Act. Since land was acquired by the Commonwealth under section 70 of the Act there has been doubt expressed as to whether the terms of the Act actually provided for minerals in that land to be vested in the Commonwealth. It is therefore considered essential that any doubts on this issue should be removed to ensure the protection of Commonwealth land where mining and exploration would not be desirable from the Commonwealth's point of view-for example, defence facilities, airports or areas where there are essential navigational aids. It is for this reason that amending clause 11 is proposed.

I would now like to turn to the other minor amendments proposed in the Bill and to preface my remarks by drawing attention to the fact that self-government in the Northern Territory is now four years old and can be described as a success. I commend all Territorians on the enthusiasm and energy which they have applied to the conduct of their own affairs. The atmosphere of confidence created in the Territory indicates that the majority of Territorians consider the granting of self-government to have been the most significant milestone in the Territory's history. The Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act has served the Territory well but as with all legislation now requires some fine tuning. This opportunity has been taken to make some machinery amendments to the Act that will improve its administration. Each of these minor amendments has the blessing of both the Commonwealth and Nothern Territory governments and I will refer briefly to some of the proposed amendments.

The assent procedures have been modified to give the Territory Legislative Assembly a degree of flexibility, similar to that enjoyed by the Commonwealth Parliament in dealing with proposed laws returned by the Governor-General or the Administrator. In respect of the proposal of money votes in the Legislative Assembly it is proposed that the Administrator's message need only recommend the purpose of an appropriation rather than the proposed law itself. It is proposed that a casual vacancy in the Legislative Assembly should be filled only if it occurs more than six months before the last date for the next general election. The same clause confirms that a general election is not required as a result of a casual vacancy.

The Bill amends some of the terminology in the Act to conform with the practice of the Assembly and its Standing Orders. The Bill also provides for the simltaneous existence of more than one dormant commission as Acting Administrator to provide for the situation where both the Administrator and the holder of the first dormant commission are unavailable to act as Administrator. By these amendments the Government intends to improve the operation of the Act and I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952 which prescribes charges payable in respect of the use by aircraft of aviation facilities and services provided, operated or maintained by the Commonwealth. The Bill gives effect to the Government's decision to vary the rates of air navigation charges for all domestic sectors of the aviation industry. It was announced in the Budget Speech that air navigation charges were to increase by 20 per cent for both domestic trunk and regional airlines and by 12 per cent for general aviation aircraft. The Bill provides for the increased charges to apply from 1 October 1982.

Total revenue from air navigation charges in 1982-83 is estimated to amount to $119.3m, compared with $101.8m from this source in 1981-82. Of the $17.5m increase, $7.1m is attributable to the payment early in 1982-83 of amounts payable in respect of 1981-82; the balance of $10.4m relates to the full effect of the 1981-82 variations to the charges, industry growth and increased revenue resulting from the increases in charges now proposed. By themselves, the increased rates of charges for which this Bill provides are expected to yield additional revenue of $8.4m in 1982-83 and $12.5m in a full year.

Honourable members will be aware that since 1961 successive governments have pursued a policy of eventual full recovery of costs properly attributable to the aviation industry for the provision and maintenance of the aviation infrastructure. The decision taken by the Government to increase air navigation charges is in line with that policy. Overall, cost recovery in 1982-83 is estimated after adjustment from 1981-82 arrears at about 53 per cent. The 1981 Airlines Agreement formally recognises the Commonwealth's entitlement to recover 100 per cent of its costs. The 20 per cent increase in air navigation charges for domestic trunk airlines is expected to achieve a recovery rate approaching 90 per cent for this sector in 1982-83. The increases in charges for regional airlines and general aviation are expected to lead to 1982-83 recovery rates from these sectors of some 25 per cent and 15 per cent respectively.

There has been considerable public comment about the possible effect on air fares of the proposed increases in air navigation charges. I should make it clear that the 20 per cent increase in charges for domestic trunk and regional airlines is estimated to increase total airline costs by around only one per cent on the basis of information already published. I would therefore expect that any overall impact on air fares would be marginal. However, the determination of air fares for specific routes is, of course, a matter for the Independent Air Fares Committee.

Honourable members will be aware that there has been a high level of cost recovery from the international sector in recent years. It is, however, expected that the recovery rate will be reduced to around 100 per cent in 1982-83. Accordingly, there will be no variations in charges for international airlines this year. For the information of honourable senators, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a paper setting out the annual cost recovery rates for each sector of the aviation industry for the ten years to 1980-81.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The Bill provides also for amendments to the Air Navigation (Charges) Act which are necessary to ensure that charges can continue to be validly imposed on all aircraft when proposed revisions to licensing classifications under the Air Navigation Regulations are introduced early in 1983. This Bill now provides that the charging arrangements set out in the Schedules to the Air Navigation (Charges) Act will apply, as appropriate, to aircraft operating under proposed new revised licence categories. The amendments relating to the licensing categories are essentially of a machinery nature. No substantive change in charging arrangements currently applying to particular classes of aircraft is involved. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AIR ACCIDENTS (COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments-
(1) Page 3, clause 5, sub-clause (1), proposed paragraph 8 (1) (b), line 3, leave out ''other'', insert ''higher''.
(2) Page 4, clause 8, sub-clause (1), proposed paragraph 14 (1) (b), line 3, leave out ''other'', insert ''higher''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills presented the tenth report on 18 August relating to the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Bill 1982. The Committee noted that the legislation provided for amendments in the future to the liability limits by regulation and that as expressed the regulations could vary the amounts downwards. The Committee considered that the legislation might more appropriately be permitted only to increase the liability of the airlines. The Committee noted that the potential for removing a pre- existing right by regulation might be regarded as trespassing unduly upon personal rights and liberties. The Government has noted the comments made by the Committee and considers that the amendments to vary the Bill to this extent would be appropriate. Amendments to this effect have been recommended by the Senate in returning the Bill to the House of Representatives along with consequential amendments to the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability ) Amendment Bill with which this Bill was debated cognately. I commend the amended Bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just register my objection to the manner in which these amendments have been presented. I had my staff try to get a copy of the amendments from the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) earlier in the day. It and his comments on the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill were not available. From my understanding of the amendments and the fact that they have been considered by a committee of the Senate I feel that they improve the quality of the legislation that left this place. I make this point: This legislation is very serious legislation. It is very important to anybody who is unfortunate enough to be a victim of an aircraft accident. The current limit of liability is $45,000; it ought to be $130,000. The Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Amendment Bill and the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill raised the amount to only $100,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Amendment Bill was introduced into this chamber on 24 March. It left here on 6 May. Today it is 19 August and now there are late amendments. We accept the amendments made by the Senate. They improve the quality of the legislation. But this is a most unsatisfactory state of affairs. This Government is good at promises, promises, promises but it is leading this country into economic disaster and it is leading the airline industry into disaster. Here is another example of the cavalier way in which air travellers and their protection are being treated. This matter goes to the very heart of the worst event that can occur to anybody involved in air travel; that is, to be unfortunate enough to be injured. Now, in come the amendments. They are thrown on the table. The Opposition is expected to consider them and take on trust the Senate's recommendation that they improve the quality of the Bill. We are most dissatisfied with the manner of presentation.

We believe the legislation is most deficient. The limit of liability under the provisions of this Bill and its companion Bill should be at least $130,000. We believe that, as the Government has rejected this proposal during a division on 6 May, that adjustment to the limit of compensation for people unfortunate enough to be injured in air accidents should be by regular and automatic review- not at the whim of a Minister. Exactly the same thing happened to this legislation when it was introduced in 1976-the last time that similar Bills were debated. They went across to the Senate, sat there for part of the winter recess , came back and then had to be amended-not for this reason but for another that arose during the period the Senate was sitting. We support the amendments proposed. We deplore the fact that the limit is totally inadequate. We deplore the fact that the review of the limit is not automatic and regular as we have proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two points I wish to make very briefly in reply. Firstly, I refute what was said and offer no apology to the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) in relation to the availability of the amendments. The amendments were, I am advised, circulated in this House this morning and therefore were available to the honourable member and to other members. The second point I wish to make is in relation to the delay that the honourable member has complained about. It is a matter of regret to me that the legislation was not passed in the last session of parliament. It did, of course, go through this House, as the honourable member has acknowledged , but unfortunately the pressure of business in the Senate was such that it could not be passed in the Senate prior to the Senate's rising for the winter recess. The Bills are now back with us. I hope that honourable members on both sides of the House will see that the Bills receive a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make the point that the reason the Bills were not dealt with in the Senate is not a matter of regret by the Government; it is a matter that arose from the disarray of the Government at the time and the haste of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to get this Parliament up weeks ahead of the normal schedule. That was the problem. It is much more serious than the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) said. I accept his apology. Let the record show his apology. But the record should show also that the real reason for the delay was the disarray in which the Government was at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

I will not delay the House as we want to see the legislation passed and assented to as quickly as possible. But, as I said in respect of the other Bill the limit is inadequate. It does a great injustice to air travellers. It will endanger their families and next of kin tremendously should there be some unfortunate happening, should the unthinkable occur.
