PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess I might repeat some of the sentiments expressed by my colleague the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) in talking about this Bill. I will not include the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), who is at the table. He has been more than kind to me in the last hour in providing me with some information for which I am appreciative. However, I think the whole record of the history of this Bill points out something of the inefficiency and mismanagement of the nation's affairs by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill was introduced in May. It relates to Customs and excise and the inefficient administration of various parts of the Bureau of Customs by this Government. I guess the reason why we are now debating it, having hibernated over the winter months, is that it has something to do with the television incident of unhappy memory in that period. As I recall, the Minister now departed introduced this Bill a week or so before that scandal arose. He spoke in deprecating terms in his second reading speech about the lack of proper penalties for evasion of duties which had a rather ironic ring when the matter was postponed. However, here we are in late August debating this Bill at last. I mentioned the courtesy of the Minister at the table in providing me with some information in the last hour or so. That does not minimise the fact that 10 pages of amendments-inconsequential, simplified, simple or otherwise-have been lobbed on the Opposition today after that break. That does not do much to increase our opinion of the efficiency of the Government.

Of course, the Opposition has been calling for a royal commission into the affairs of the Bureau of Customs since the unhappy days of the MacKellar-Moore colour television incident. The amendments that have been pushed up today and the Bill in its present form, while they in some way redress some of the inefficiencies that are very obvious in that department, do not convince the Opposition that its claim for a royal commission was not justified. In fact, since the demise of the previous Minister, the Bureau of Customs has now been shoved into the already overburdened Department of Industry and Commerce. The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, of course, has been dismembered so that parts of it find their way into many different departments. The Opposition is not very happy with that. Upon its assumption of office-be it in September or November of 1982 or December of 1983-that Department will be reconstituted because the Opposition at least understands just how important to the affairs of this nation is the Bureau of Customs, what an important arm of government revenue collection it is and what an important arm of protection it is to the Australian community in so many ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a fine bunch of people they are, too.

—I would probably echo the sentiments of the Minister at the table in saying that of course there are within this department very many fine servants of the public, not the least of whom are the Customs officers whose resentment and discontent with the administration of their department was very evident back in May and is still very evident now. In the course of my remarks I might refer to one of the problems to which they relate.

SPEECH.PARA: I get back to the main thrust of the Bill. It amends the Customs Act primarily by substantially raising the level of penalties for breaches of the Act including narcotics-related offences which, in fact, were separately dealt with in 1979 following the report of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. It is a fact that the penalties prescribed under the Customs Act have for a long period been far too light. It took instances like the kangaroo and horsemeat scandal-also of unhappy memory-to highlight the inadequacy of the penalties that were provided under the Act. So, let me tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the Minister at the table, that the Opposition supports the provisions which increase these penalties to a reasonable level.

The inadequacy of the current penalties is highlighted by several facts. Firstly, the penalties for narcotics are now dramatically higher than for other prohibited imports and exports. We probably do not argue with that but at least other penalties should be brought up to a somewhat similar level. This Bill seeks to do that. Most narcotics penalties have not been varied since 1967 when a typical maximum fine was only $1,000 and, for some offences, only $50. That has been redressed. The horse and kangaroo meat scandal revealed that penalties were just not adequate to deal with offences of the magnitude of those offences. They involved not only the evasion of duties but also the destruction, to a great extent, of Australia's very important export meat industry. If proper penalties had been available under the Customs Act people would have been discouraged from taking the simple moves they took to circumvent the rules.

The proposed penalties include the provision that where revenue is evaded the penalty will be at least two times and up to five times the amount evaded. We do not quibble about that. Where prohibited imports or exports are moved, the maximum penalty will be three times their value; that is also reasonable. Where the value of the goods that have been moved in some illegal fashion cannot be ascertained, the maximum fine will be $50,000; that is reasonable also. Offences which strike at the basis of Customs control-for example, interfering with a container before clearance by Customs-will also carry a penalty of $50,000. I commend the Government for making that move. Lesser offences will carry penalties of $1,000 to $10,000. Surely they will be a source of discouragement to people who try to circumvent proper Customs procedures. These penalties do not seem to us to be unreasonable and in the circumstances appear to be appropriate to the offences concerned. Gaol terms are not specified in the Bill, unlike the penalties for the narcotics trade which involve fines and imprisonment. Avoidance of Customs duty and like offences can involve large sums of money and, as I pointed out earlier, scandals which go beyond the evasion of duties. Some offences already carry a penalty of three times the value of the goods involved. I am quite happy to see that that is retained.

Consequent to the increased penalties, other amendments increase the jurisdictional value of lower and intermediate courts. Previously, most fines were under $1,000 and were dealt with by courts of summary jurisdiction and intermediate courts. But the amendments to the Act allow courts of summary jurisdiction to deal with offences where the fine is up to $5,000 and intermediate courts to deal with offences where the fine is $20,000. Provision will also be made to enable offences involving duty evasion of less than $500 to be dealt with administratively, as are small offences committed by arriving international travellers, crew and, may I say, politicians. Other changes in the Bill include a new Part which provides for the licensing of depots which hold goods prior to examination by Customs. These provisions are virtually identical to existing provisions relating to licensing warehouses. Of course, we support that provision.

A variety of other amendments update the procedures and other matters. Such amendments are made virtually every year as circumstances and practices change following continuous reviews of the Act. We have no quibble with all of those amendments. In fact, we are very happy to support them. But there are other matters that I would like to touch on in the course of my remarks. As I understand it, some amendments are to be introduced by the Minister at the conclusion of this debate. As I understand it, the Committee that will deal with those new amendments will not meet until next week. Am I correct in saying that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is later tonight.

—I am informed that they will be dealt with later tonight. However , there is another area upon which I would like to touch and which may well be looked at by the administration of the Bureau of Customs in its present home in the Department of Industry and Commerce. It relates to shipping containers. At the inception of overseas container shipping in Australia in the 1960s it was recognised that freight containers could be continually imported and re-exported over any period and also that imported containers would normally be brought into Australia for re-export rather than for sale or disposal within the country. In other words, when a container came in from overseas with goods it would normally be re-exported. Accordingly, the Customs legislation was amended so that under section 162A provisions were implemented that ensured, firstly, that shipping companies would lodge a security in which they undertook to re-export any imported containers within 12 months of the import date or, secondly, import duty on foreign-built units would be waived until or unless they remained in Australia for a long period or were to be disposed of or sold under arrangements notified to Customs.

SPEECH.PARA: Shipping carriers saw this provision as equitable because most or all of their equipment was acquired overseas due to either higher manufacturing costs in Australia or the granting of tax incentives in other countries for those to be built. It was expected that container movement history data would be maintained to prove whether or how containers were re-exported; that random inquiries from local port Customs on containers would be sampled if they were here for more than 12 months after the import date; and that these inquiries would be answered to demonstrate compliance with the law. These samples were expected to be small in volume, having regard to the effort that would be imposed on Customs in selecting units from old import manifests and mailing these to shipping companies; the effort, which would not be too hard, for shipping companies in retrieving history for the queried units and responding with lists of re-export details; and the effort for Customs in checking these responses and in some cases requesting further re-documentation on re-export.

However, it appears that random selection by Customs of those units to be verified was seen to be an effective check that shipping companies maintained adequate records for this purpose. Firstly, it demonstrated their control and also it had a deterrent effect against abusers of section 162A of the provisions . It is important to note, however, that this entire checking process can potentially detect any ommission or abuse only more than 12 months after a container is imported because until then it is futile for Customs to query containers which have remained in Australia for less than that time. Its detection and deterrent value is therefore extremely limited against any conscious breaches because of the great time lapse. It should also be noted that the provisions of section 162A were drafted on the assumption that all containers would be re-exported by the shipping companies which had imported them. The small number of shipping carriers which operated such container services into Australia in the 1960s did not contradict this, and probably that reflected their intentions at the time. However, since then there has been a great alteration in the pattern of shipping throughout the world. Subsequently the world-wide freight shipping industry has moved heavily towards the use of leased-in equipment from lessors, such that the lessors now own the majority of the world's containers. This trend reflects the seasonal and cyclical nature of many shipping routes, changing shipping business market shares and container traffic imbalances, leading to surpluses and deficits as opposed to stable, balanced trends in which an all-owned fleet might be economic.

While many leased containers used by shipping companies are maintained on long term leases, many are also used on a spot or trip basis. For Australia this results in many difficulties. Firstly, imported containers are unpacked and later off-hired to the lessor company's agent. This terminated the shipping company's ability to control such units or to maintain records of their subsequent movements. In particular, the companies cannot effect the re-export of those containers. Containers being newly-leased in Australia and re-exported also presented another problem, the new lessee having no record of the containers' previous time in the country since import, nor details of that importation or its intervening movemements. From 1982 the level of Customs inquiries directed to shipping lines has increased heavily in New South Wales, some companies receiving lists of 400 to 500 containers imported 15 months to 24 months previously. The effect imposed on the shipping companies is considerable. No doubt it is also considerable on the Bureau of Customs in New South Wales when it receives and processes the replies. The Bureau appears to me to be unnecessarily bureaucratic when it is considered that the Bureau has already been notified of an actual container export at the time of shipment, the notification being via a container list provided as part of export manifests submitted by shipping companies. The whole process becomes extraordinarily tenuous in tracing the position of the containers once they have been imported, how long they have stayed in Australia, what they have done when they have been here and what is eventually their destiny. It highlights to me the total inefficiency of the tracing of the containers within Australia. Unless something is done to streamline the procedures we will never be able to trace them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are very fine officers and they are doing excellent work.

—I do not disagree that they are very fine officers. The system under which they operate as maintained by the Government does nothing to help the fine efforts that these people put in to protect the Australian people. So the Customs Bureau already holds the information that would enable the matching of imports to re-exports and for which data processing could be readily used to eliminate the majority of containers which have already complied with section 162A. Instead of that, sampling is based on the total range of containers imported. The shipping industry, and the Customs officers themselves, become engulfed in wasteful clerical effort each year. New South Wales Customs are currently sampling about three per cent of all containers imported. For New South Wales alone this requires checking on something of the order of 2,000 to 3 ,000 units each year. This level of sampling is believed to be the statistical minimum needed to detect the predicted levels of containers which justify investigation, that is, through being regularly sold, lost or retained for over 12 months. The New South Wales Customs are understood to be proposing that his level of sampling be adopted for all Australian ports.

SPEECH.PARA: It has become recognised that the existing legislation and regulations make no allowance for the leased container problem which I have already described. Where containers are leased it is much more difficult to trace them. It is believed that various Customs officers differ in their reactions to this. Some believe, strictly correctly to the letter of the law, that off-hire of any container by an importing shipping company does not terminate the company's responsibility regardless of the container's subsequent movements. These officers pressure shipping companies to pursue such onward information about container movements after the containers have left the shipping companies' control. Some officers recognise the inadequacy of the existing law and ask only for reasonable proof that a container has passed to another reputable party such as a lessor's agent. Some officers, in fact, avoid the subject altogether.

The inconsistencies of Customs offices' practice on this matter causes doubt and concern in the shipping industry and it is another case of whether a bureaucratic sledge hammer is being used to crack a business nut. Perhaps more seriously, though, the varying practices applied by Customs offices may invite corruption in attempts to reduce pressures on some companies. That is not a sling at Customs offices and I would not like it to be interpreted in that way. I just point out that the inadequacy of the system enables those accusations to be made. Some Customs officers appear to be sensitive about discretionary application of inadequate regulations in the light of the colour television affair. I think that is a reasonable statement to make.

It cannot be denied that the import of containers provides great potential for the illegal movement of narcotics and that Customs officers are concerned to show that the most effective use of their resources in countering this would be to improve the system whereby containers can be traced. However, the real problem is not assisted by the undoubted efforts now expended by Customs officers and shipping companies in re-export history checking. I have tried to point out to the House-it is a rather involved story, I must admit-that the efforts to trace the history of the movements of imported containers from the time of import to their sale, disposal or re-export is a very tenuous affair. Tracing the movements of these containers involves Customs officers in an almost impossible task. I suggest to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Hodgman), who is at the table, that there needs to be a reorientation, a reassembling of the conditions under which these officers work in order that they can do this job properly.

This highlights to me one of the problems that the Opposition pointed out at the time of the debate in the House on the colour television affair. We said that the systems, the regulations and the administration of the Customs Bureau needed an in-depth look by government. That is the reason we suggest the setting up of a royal commission at the time. We said that we wanted a royal commission to look at all the activities of the Customs Bureau. As I said earlier, the Customs Bureau has now been shifted to another department, but that does not alter the fact that there is still enormous unrest among officers.

I agree with the Minister that these officers are a fine bunch of men-a courageous, sincere bunch of men-who are very anxious to see that their job is done properly. But they can only do the job properly within the confines of the regulations under which they work. I repeat that these regulations are not adequate. They are not efficient and they are not clearly defined. The quicker that the Government-or as we suggested, a royal commission-has an in-depth look at the Customs Bureau to steamline the operations of this most important arm of government regulation, the better. The response from the Government has merely been to appoint an inquiry under a man for whom everybody has great respect, Mr Mahony. Nobody would quibble with Mr Mahony's integrity, honesty or dedication to his task, but the guidelines which he was given by the Government-only that he look at how Customs operate at the airport at Mascot-to me seem totally inadequate. It was a very inadequate response-perhaps a convenient response-to the colour television affair, but from our point of view it was not a correct response to all the problems that exist in the Customs Bureau. I suggest very sincerely to the Minister at the table that he take this matter up with his colleague the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), under whose jurisdiction the Customs Bureau now operates, to ensure that all of the problems of the Customs Bureau-particularly the problem that I have just outlined with regard to the importation of shipping containers-are looked at more adequately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Amendment Bill is a very important measure. Its being before the House today has nothing to do with the alleged inefficiency of the Government as the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr John Brown) has just stated, but with the general priority of the Government' s business in the last session and the need for the provisions of this Bill to be very carefully considered. It relates, as the honourable member has suggested , to a crucial area of government responsibility-the detection of the import of prohibited goods, especially the evils of the drug trade and the collection of Customs and excise duty. It was important that this be looked at carefully. I suggest to the honourable member that if he had looked at it a little more carefully himself, many of his latter remarks would be seen to be irrelevant. Very important clauses of the Bill are precisely concerned with making provision for setting out in detail regulations for the standardising of procedures and the tightening up of procedures in relation to Customs matters. Further, some of the strictures of the honourable member concerning the Department were totally unwarranted and unworthy of him. In respect of the involved story-to use his own words-about the empty containers I say only that section 162A of the Act implements international conventions in respect of the free movement of containers into and out of Australia and is outside the ambit of the Bill presently before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that it is an important measure. The honourable member has conceded that. Its principle purpose is to increase very substantially the penalties provided for various breaches of the Customs Act. The need for this certainly became apparent during the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs-the Williams Inquiry-which pointed out the inadequacies of penalties for breaches of the Customs Act. The matter of penalties in the context of drug offences has previously been dealt with, so I make it clear that those penalties are not before the House at the moment. I will make a further reference to them in a moment, as they are very important.

That Commission drew attention to the inadequate level of penalties for breaches of the Customs Act. Also the unlawful exportation of horse and kangaroo meat last year to the United States was referred to. As a result of these and other factors a general review of all the provisions for penalties in this Act was undertaken. It took into account the matters to which I have just referred, also the difficulties faced by Customs in supervising the growing flow of goods into and out of Australia, the need for Customs to rely to a significant degree on the integrity of importers and exporters, and the magnitude of the rewards-if I can use that word-that can be obtained from revenue evasion or unlawful import or export activities. It was concluded that these penalties should be increased and, indeed, substantially increased. I think the history of the matter is that penalties were originally written into the 1901 Customs Act. There was something of an indexing of those penalties in about the mid 1960s, but no cognisance was taken of the gravity of offences, particularly some of the offences of more recent note. The Bill now before us provides, as the honourable member for Parramatta pointed out, that the penalty for revenue related offences-that is, the evasion of duty-should be up to five times the amount sought to be evaded and not less that two times that amount. For the offences of importing prohibited imports or exporting prohibited exports a maximum penalty equivalent to three times the value of the goods is proposed. Where the amount evaded or the value of the goods cannot be ascertained, the proposed maximum penalty of $ 50,000 should apply. That should be a very significant deterrent. I think that the penalty for such offences, and some others, was until recently $1,000. This order of change underlines the significance of this measure. The penalty of $50, 000 is also prescribed for other offences which strike at the very basis of this important matter of Customs control.

Included in that category are offences such as failure by the master of a ship to permit the ship to be boarded, the failure of the pilot of an aircraft to land for boarding, the bringing of a ship or aircraft to an unauthorised place in order to effect a clandestine landing to escape Customs attention and the unlawful interference with containers or goods-note that, in the light of what the honourable member for Parramatta was saying-between the time of landing and their clearance by Customs. In respect of some offences, which while serious are not amongst the most important, a maximum penalty of $25,000 is proposed where previously the penalty was of the order of $500. Examples of such offences are the unloading without permission of imported cargo or cargo that has been loaded for export. A maximum penalty of $10,000 is proposed for offences such as failing to comply with conditions attached to permission for the importation, exportation or movement of goods. Significant penalties for breaches such as these are essential for the effective discharge of this heavy responsibility for the detection and prevention of unlawful imports and exports and the assessment and collection of appropriate duty.

I stress that in this measure no action is proposed in respect of penalties for narcotic offences because those penalties were reviewed and substantially increased by amendments in 1977 and 1979. The penalties already provided in that context, in section 235 of the Act, range from $2,000 or two years imprisonment or both for simple possession of imported narcotics up to a penalty of $100,000 or 25 years imprisonment or both for trafficking in narcotics. There is further provision for imposing a penalty of life imprisonment in the most serious cases. I stress to the House that this underlines the uncompromising determination of this Government to combat the evils of the drug trade.

As the honourable member for Parramatta has mentioned, with the increased penalties I have referred to there are consequential adjustments which have become necessary to ensure that Customs prosecutions may be brought in an appropriate court. At present the Act provides that only prosecutions involving a pecuniary penalty not exceeding $1,000 may be instituted in courts of summary jurisdiction and in intermediate courts but the application of this provision now becomes very limited, so these limits have been raised. For the intermediate court jurisdiction penalties of up to $20,000 can be contemplated and for the courts of summary jurisdiction the limit is $5,000.

Another and very major part of the amendment of the Customs Act proposed in this Bill are clauses which deal with the report, the unloading from ships and the placement and movement of imported cargo. This is a crucial area for Customs control. We are looking here in particular at times when cargo has been quite undocumented, is being unloaded from a ship and is being moved from a ship to a depot or some place of storage. As I said this is a very crucial area. It is an area where there is the need for the most stringent controls. I do not suggest that the Department has not had effective procedures in this area, but they have been of a discretionary character. Clause 12 relates to the movement of goods from one ship to another and clause 14 relates to the movement of goods off ships. Clause 24 sets up a new Part VA of the Act relating to depots where goods still in this undocumented state can be stored. Clause 7 deals with section 40AA of the principal Act and the movement of goods generally which are still subject to Customs control but have not yet received documentation. It is very important in these areas that the procedures involved be clearly thought out, fully specified, standardised and tightened up in a way which can make this crucial activity of the detection of illegal imports and the collection of duty most effective.

I think honourable members will see that these clauses are indeed providing for just the spelling out we were referring to earlier, in close detail and by regulations, of the procedures necessary in this crucial area of control. What was satisfactory in an Act which was originally passed in 1901 needs this further spelling out in the circumstances of 1982, in the circumstances in particular where much cargo is shipped in containers and by new procedures. That is a major part of this Bill. I make brief reference to clause 10. I draw attention to this clause as it has been considerably misunderstood.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the honourable gentleman's attention to the fact that the House is debating the second reading. Whilst he may make some allusion to the contents of the Bill, I request that he not do so on a specific clausal basis.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is a provision in the Bill which provides that a person who is in a position to do so, the ship owner or the master, if requested is obliged to provide the ship's manifest or other information to the Customs authorities.
—That is quite right.

—As the Minister said, that is quite right, because it is very important, particularly in the area of drug trafficking, that the authorities can look at this manifest and make risk assessments so that they can more effectively discharge their obligation to try to detect unlawful importing. This clause imposes an obligation, where a party can do so, to provide information about a ship's cargo to the Customs officials for the more effective discharge of their duties. To the extent that a ship's manifest or other information is provided in this way in advance this is not put down as an imposition on the shippers or the importers; it is introduced as something designed to be of assistance to them and considerably to minimise the sort of delays which could otherwise occur if the manifest of a ship arriving in port has not been viewed by the Customs officials beforehand. I stress that it is a provision which is designed to assist the import agent and the ship owner to minimise their costs and to make more effective the work of the Customs officers.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important measure. Reference was made earlier to the fact that certain amendments to the Bill will subsequently be moved, and that underlines the hollowness of the claim of the honourable member for Parramatta that this measure has been delayed allegedly owing to the inefficiency of the Government. It has given the parties, Customs agents and other bodies affected, the opportunity to study the provisions of the Bill in detail. In particular, one of the amendments that will be considered later is designed to write into the Bill and to give legal backing to procedures currently adopted by duty free shops.

There are certain procedures whereby an intending overseas passenger can make purchases. It is his responsibility to board the aircraft and, in effect, export the goods. In fact this procedure has not hitherto had effective legal backing. The period during which this legislation lay before the House gave the parties concerned the opportunity to bring the matter to the attention of the Government and to include it in this measure, and there are other such significant amendments. Mr Deputy Speaker, this Bill, as I said, is a very important albeit rather mundane measure. Subject to those further amendments to be moved at a later hour this day, I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill and particularly to the sections that refer specifically to the collection of duty. The honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) explained that the Opposition's view on this legislation is to support the various clauses of this Bill. I endorse that proposition. Particularly, I endorse the increase in the disciplinary provisions outlined in this legislation. I only wish that all the disciplinary provisions of the Customs Act be consistently reviewed because I find that very often the time lag in getting legislation introduced into this Parliament makes a joke of the disciplinary provisions in relation to the collection of duties.

SPEECH.PARA: The section that I should like to deal with emerged from Part V of this legislation which provides for the introduction of a new system of licensing depots for holding imported goods and goods for export prior to their examination by Customs officers. Honourable members will be aware that this section will allow a licensing scheme to be modelled directly on that scheme now applying in respect of warehouses. Several matters were raised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards). He spoke about the tightening up of collection matters. It is very important that I point out to this House some of the work that has already been done regarding the need to tighten up these provisions, as stated in the report of the Auditor-General. This matter and other related matters referring to the collection of excise are currently being examined by the Joint Public Accounts Committee. I should like to refer now to some of these sections in the report of the Auditor-General in order to indicate to honourable members some of the other areas in the collection of Customs that need to be examined by this House and which are currently being examined very seriously by a joint committee of this Parliament.

I refer to some aspects of the efficiency audit carried out by the Auditor- General into the collection of Customs duties and deferred Customs duties by the then Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. I shall refer to some aspects of that report to give a broader understanding of some of the weak links in the collection of both excise and Customs duties in this country. Basically, this efficiency audit was carried out to look specifically at excisable goods and imported goods upon which the payment of Customs duty is deferred because the goods are stored in bonded warehouses. This involves a considerable amount of revenue to the Government, and after last Tuesday's Budget even more revenue is to be collected from these sources. As the report points out, the amounts of money in the previous financial year were enormous. Excise duty on major excisable products-beer, spirits, tobacco products and petroleum products-in 1980-81 terms amounted to $2,731m. Customs duty on imported goods held in licensed warehouses amounted to approximately $430m for the year ended 30 April 1980. Diesel fuel tax, when purchased free of duty and subsequently used for a dutiable purpose, amounted to $190m in 1980-81. I point out those amounts of money so that honourable members can comprehend the need for very tight controls in this area. It is important that the Government-whichever party is the government of the day-receives the maximum amount of money set out in the legislation and the Customs provisions.

There was considerable criticism about the administration procedures relating to the collection of excise and Customs duty on imported goods held in licensed warehouses. This is not meant to be a criticism of the departmental officers. In fact what has emerged from the inquiry of the Public Accounts Committee is that the officers of the department responsible for this area-the Inland Services Division-have in fact had incredible work load pressures put on them by not only this area of their responsibility but also the narcotics side of their responsibility. So what the Auditor-General is looking at and what the Public Accounts Committee has subsequently been looking at is not any criticism at all of the officers but rather criticism of the techniques involved. The main criticism they have is the application of the commodity control where the onus for verification of the goods has been on the companies themselves. Currently the situation is that the companies have had to provide verification of the goods but the whole question is whether there have also been independent checks. There have been grave doubts about how effective those checking procedures have been. This really has been the basis of this detailed audit finding report on the excise of beer, duties on spirits, tobacco, petroleum products and diesel fuel.

The Public Accounts Committee is well into that investigation. It has looked specifically at what the Auditor-General's findings have been. Probably the Committee will not always be in agreement with that but that will be the subject of a subsequent report to this House.

However I think it is important that that matter be raised in the context of looking at this whole Customs collection area because we will see legislation emerging from the findings of that inquiry. I think it is important that, as this area is such a vital one for the collection of revenue for any government, we do see consistent amendments being made to keep the fines up to realistic amounts and also keep the legislation under constant review.

Before I conclude, I refer to the administration of bonded warehouses and the findings, again of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit, into bonded warehouses. As honourable members will be aware, bond stores are essentially the means whereby the duty payable on imported goods or excise on domestically produced goods may be deferred until they are released for home consumption. A calculation undertaken during audit field work showed that, for the year ended 30 April 1980, Customs duty on goods released from bond stores in Australia was, as I stated earlier, $435.8m and about 75 officers have taken responsibility for administrating this area as of 30 June 1981. This whole area of staffing the former Department is now being reviewed by the Public Service Board in light of the heavy demands within it. I refer to the criticism that has been made about the system of inventories within the administration of bonded warehouses. The report of the Auditor-General on an Efficiency Audit states:

The overall control structure-granting of licences to approved persons, requirement for payment of duty before goods are released for home consumption, right of access to company records-is adequate in principle.

The ADP systems currently in use have the potential to maintain a record of inventory on hand and consequently the contingent liability for duty but this facility has not been fully developed. The systems independently record goods entered into and cleared from bond. A logical extension of this transaction- based approach would be a merger of the systems to facilitate routine oversight of inventories, their age (or dwell time) and their duty potential. Such information would facilitate management and review. The Department has advised that some redevelopment of the ADP systems is taking place but that technical problems have yet to be resolved.
The report goes on to state:
These findings suggest that control over revenue from bond stores could be improved by the following measures:
regular review of 'continuing permissions'-
That is a system that operates-
merging of the present ADP systems for entries and releases
a more discriminatory approach in documentary and physical checking towards stores attracting higher revenue, recognising risk factors, and
monitoring of cost effectiveness to assess continued need for the level of control resources.

I think it is important that honourable members read that. I hope that an opportunity for further examination of this legislation will come before this House so that we can ensure that we do get exactly the sorts of revenues that any government of the day has forecast and that very tight controls are imposed and continue to be imposed on Customs collection in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak on the second reading of the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill. I have noted the second reading speech of the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs which felicitously, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Customs rely to a significant degree on the integrity of importers and exporters . . .

During the winter recess I was in the Kimberleys with an Opposition committee and I was appalled to learn that in the Kimberleys there are 1,000 air strips left over from the war which are completely unmanned and unpoliced and, on any of these airstrips, drugs or illegal immigrants can be introduced into this country. This gave me a very bleak picture of the Australian situation and the possibilities of smuggling and other forms of unlawful importation into this country. As mentioned, the legislation before the House deals essentially with penalties under the Customs Act. I, too, am pleased that Mr Frank Mahony, a former senior Commonwealth public servant, is reviewing procedures at Sydney Airport under the Customs Act. It is my opinion that no government could have obtained the services of a more competent person to review the Customs Act. I served my articles of clerkship for two years to Mr Mahony when I worked in the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's office. I know his ability and his breadth of vision. I wish him well in his inquiries.

The penalties that mainly concern me are the penalties that, according to the speech of the former Minister, relate to the comings and goings of passengers at international airports. This is the area where most Australians and most tourists come into contact with our Customs officers. These officers have a great tradition of service to the community. They work long hours and get just as tired and cross as I am sure the passengers do. People are weary when they arrive in Australia after a long flight. My concern today is with one particular group of Australians of ethnic origin who go overseas, perhaps to Italy, Greece or Lebanon, and who stay for five or six months. They stay with relatives and during that visit speak any language other than English; perhaps they speak a dialect. On returning to Australia, they have forgotten their English. This is not uncommon. People tell me that they have been away for a while and have not spoken English. English is very difficult to pick up all of a sudden.

Many people came here after the war to build up this country and have done a marvellous job. Through no fault of their own, they have very little understanding of reading and writing English. Perhaps they read and write their own language but they have never mastered English. They may speak English well but these people read foreign newspapers here and they do not read English. I know that the Bureau of Customs makes some endeavour to cater for Australians who do not read English as a first language. I believe that much more effort is needed on the part of the Bureau of Customs to cater for the returning migrants. They comprise one of the biggest groups of people in our nation who are now travelling. These migrants are going home to visit, having made good in Australia or having saved up enough money to take themselves and their Australian born children to Italy, Lebanon, Yugoslavia and the many other countries from which people have come to enrich our nation.

Unfortunately some of these people who return to Australia in the early hours of the morning become the court room fodder of the special Commonwealth courts of petty sessions in Sydney. They are often dragged before the courts for very petty offences. They are people who have led blameless lives, never having come under notice, and who because of some petty infringement or misdemeanour in relation to the Customs Act when they enter Australia are hauled before the courts. I feel that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) and the Government of the day must take responsibility for this insensitive attitude towards Australians returning from overseas who inadvertently break one of the Customs regulations or transgress the Customs Act.

I draw the attention of the House to two cases that I have been involved with. One concerned a man who really speaks no English. He was seriously injured at work and with his compensation he went back to Italy. On coming back to Australia he brought a number of silver and gold chains for his five daughters and his wife. Clearly from the statement of evidence he gave to the Customs officers he had to get the lady seated next to him on the plane to fill out the declaration form. He said: 'Just put a cross there against cigarettes'. He admitted he had cigarettes. He also had these chains and he did not try to hide them. he had them sewn into the lining of his clothes by his sister in Italy because he was frightened that they would be stolen.

This man was apprehended-this was the big catch-and dragged before the courts. He was a very sensitive fellow. He was appalled by what happened. The members of his family were all honest people. His daughters attended high school in my electorate. They were absolutely dismayed at his arrest and interrogation, which obviously went on for a long time basically because the man had no written English and perhaps also had no written Italian. I have a long four-page statement which was read over and over to him. Before I became the member for Lowe, fortunately Senator Mulvihill in another place made representations on this man's behalf and common sense prevailed. I do not believe he was eventually prosecuted but had representations of a political and parliamentary nature not been made this man would just have been another court statistic.

The other matter I will touch on concerns a sadder case, if that is at all possible. It concerns an Italian speaking constituent well known to me. Her husband was seriously injured at work in an accident and will never work again. In fact he cannot talk. The compensation proceedings took a long time and out of the compensation money this lady and her husband had the big return trip to Italy just to see their people. Coming back they knew there would be an eight- hour stopover in Rome to get the plane to Australia. This lady's old aunt of 75 years with whom she was staying packed some fruit, pears, artichokes and nuts. This lady did not even know they were in one of the bags. When she arrived in Sydney she was apprehended. I can only imagine the distress and shock she must have felt because she had in her care a husband who was totally incapable. The man can walk but he cannot talk or comprehend any situation.

This lady likewise was taken and interrogated. Whilst the Customs officers do their job there has to be some better system. I hope that Mr Frank Mahony, in his deliberations, can truly comprehend what is going on out there when people arrive early in the morning very tired, perhaps half asleep, and find that an elderly aunt in Italy has placed some fruits, nuts or other prohibited imports in the baggage. This lady was not as lucky as the constituent mentioned previously. She did not get to me quickly enough. She was proceeded against in the Court of Petty Sessions, in Sydney in a special court convened under the Customs Act and the Quarantine Act. She was a woman of blameless character who was well known in her area and who had never had a conviction. She was proceeded against, charged and convicted. This matter also gave me great concern.

Without delaying the House too much, I feel these matters should be brought to the attention of the Minister and of the Parliament because not all Australians who travel are in the jet set league. Many of them are ordinary people who have worked hard all their lives. Perhaps they have never been in an aeroplane because they came by ship many years ago and have totally forgotten the Customs and import regulations. Perhaps they are given certain information in Italy, Lebanon or some other country and believe this to be correct when in fact they have been misled. It is essential that the Customs Bureau also recognises that we have a multicultural society and that Australians who do not read English be catered for as well as Australians who read English. I trust that during the consideration of this legislation the House will bear these important matters in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill I will make some particular comments about the information provided to passengers departing from Australia about Customs and quarantine matters. I will also comment on the form that incoming passengers, particularly aircraft passengers, are required to fill out. Firstly, I will make mention of the fact that the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) saw fit to make some comments on the so-called colour television affair in the course of his remarks on this Bill. I think that was unfortunate. I really do not believe that this Bill has anything to do with that affair. I think the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar ) did the decent and proper thing under the Westminister tradition of our parliamentary processes. I think they gained great standing in the community as a result of that. I do not think there is much mileage to gain by any honourable member in raising that issue again.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments we are dealing with relate largely to penalties for non- narcotics Customs offences. It has become necessary to increase those penalties largely as a result of the proceedings of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking where severe inadequacies in our system and in the Customs Act were highlighted, and the inadequacies that came to light in the meat substitution scandal when Australian horse and kangaroo meat was found in the United States of America. Perhaps it is just as well that those events occurred because they did prod the Government into taking a general review of the Customs Act into increasing penalties and otherwise tightening up controls over the loading and unloading of cargo, the licensing of depots for short term and interim holding of goods and other provisions which were obviously necessary .

The success of measures to counter illegal importation of Customs dutiable items and quarantinable items must always lie ultimately with the reliability of the person who is bringing in those goods. No amount of rigid and stringent regulations and, indeed, severe penalties can ever substitute for a willingness on behalf of individuals not to breach the regulations and the requirements.

I say that by way of introduction to a discussion of some of the information provided to people coming into Australia. I believe that to some extent people are encouraged to hide items merely by the format of the declarations they are expected to fill out. The penalties for breaches are quite severe. They are up to five times the value of what was sought to be evaded. I think the term ' sought to be evaded' is important. It should be remembered that in many cases, as the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) has just pointed out, there was no direct intention whatsoever to evade the law. I think a distinction needs to be made between a person who intentionally goes out to evade the law and a person who happens to commit a breach of the law through accidental incorporation of goods, ignorance, or, indeed, as the member for Lowe pointed out, because of a poor command of the English language.

I totally agree with the provision, as does the Opposition, that severe penalties should be introduced when offences strike at the very basis of Customs control. Such offences would include a ship's master failing to allow officers to board the ship. Likewise, they would include the pilot of an aircraft refusing officers permission to board or the entry of a ship or an aircraft into an unauthorised place where no Customs controls were applicable. Australia is a country with such a vast coastline and such large areas of relatively uninhabited country that it is very easy to evade Customs and quarantine requirements if a person wishes to do so. I must relay a story about what happened to me when I came through Customs in Brisbane not so long ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be interesting.

—I am afraid that I am going to disappoint the honourable member for Parramatta because I think my experiences on this occasion highlight the difficulties that face many passengers coming into Australia.
—In Brisbane?

—Yes, this was in Brisbane, actually. Just for the point of the exercise I decided to look very carefully at what was required of incoming passengers when they filled out the pamphlet that was available. I took the pamphlet away with me so that I had the benefit of some weeks in which to be able to examine it. Firstly, if one wishes to follow the instructions for filling out the form to the absolute limit one should wind up ticking most boxes . For example, I looked at that section which dealt with prohibited imports of animal products or products made from, I think reptile skins. It could have been the section which refers to endangered species. I think it was that provision. I looked at it and said: 'No, that does not affect me at all. Of course, I do not have animals skins or items made from endangered species'. But when I looked and saw that snakes were included I realised that I had bought a snake skin belt. Being an honest and reputable citizen I declared the snake skin belt which, of course, I could have brought in Australia. It was not too much of a belt because it has since fallen to bits, but I declared that. I declared the fact that I had a packet of biscuits in my pocket that I had picked up on the aircraft. Also, I had bought a small packet of candies for one of the children and I declared that as well, as one would have to if one were following the requirements to the exact letter.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that on almost any overseas trip, unless a person spends 100 per cent of his time in cities, it is inevitable that he will come into contact with agricultural areas. Even if a person drives out of a city for a period and walks into a paddock he has, strictly speaking, been on a farm or in contact with farm animals. I believe that to some extent, if people read the requirements exactly to the letter, many of them are deterred from declaring exactly what they have and where they have been. It might be worth while for the Department of Industry and Commerce to consider including in the information handbook that is handed out, particularly on departure, instructions saying: 'We expect you to have those goods that you think may be doubtful and may be required to be declared available in your cabin baggage or in a particular suitcase so that there is no delay'. The Department could encourage people to declare the goods they have. That would not be so that they could be penalised for declaring the goods but simply so that the Customs and quarantine people could make an immediate assessment of whether the goods were dutiable or whether they came within the provisions of quarantine requirements.

I noticed with interest that one passenger on the flight I was coming in on said that he always handled the situation by writing an exhaustive list of everything he had purchased, handing it to the Customs person and saying: 'You sort it out'. That list could be two or three pages long and could include four or five tee-shirts, fancy biros, toys and all the other paraphernalia he had bought on the trip. I understand that he has been doing that for years. The Customs and quarantine officers have the onus placed on them of determining whether, in fact, the goods are quarantinable or dutiable. In most cases they take one look and send this person through. I think the Department has some opportunity to make the information available for departing passengers a little clearer in order to encourage them to say what they have rather than really providing an opportunity for them too easily just to cross the no box or whatever, as the case may be, which I think is what is generally done. There are many instances when people do have material that should be declared. In most cases that material will be passed on the spot by the officers concerned. The measures contained within this Bill are sensible. I understand that they have the support of the Opposition. I trust that they will have the support of the Senate. I see little room for contention on these measures. Perhaps they are somewhat overdue. I welcome this Bill.
