DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED STATES NAVAL COMMUNICATION STATION AGREEMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) confirms the United States Naval Communication Station Agreement 1963 as amended as an important element in the bilateral relationship between Australia and the United States contributing to the fulfilment of our obligations under the security treaty between Australia, New Zealand and the United States of America of 29 April 1952;
(2) confirms that this Agreement advances the security of Australia and of the Western alliance and that it contributes significantly to general Western defence efforts;

(3) asserts that no impediment should be placed on the use and operation of the base to meet the stated needs and requirements of the treaty partners; and recognises that free and uninhibited access to the facilities of the base by the treaty partners is essential to its effective use as a vital element in the Western deterrent especially in enabling the United States to maintain an adequate nuclear deterrent against the nuclear threat from the Soviet Union;

(4) agrees that the present consultative arrangements between Australia and the United States relating to the joint operations of North West Cape be preserved and recognises that those arrangements are fully adequate to meet the needs of the treaty partners;
(5) asserts that no impediment should be placed by either party on access to the facilities of the base in relation to the use of the base by the other party , and

(6) agrees that Article 6 of the United States Naval Communication Station Agreement 1963, which reads: 'The Australian Government will, jointly with the Government of the State of Western Australia, appoint a Civil Commissioner at Exmouth, who will have such functions as those Governments may vest in him and will represent them in such matters as they may determine.'
shall henceforth be excluded from the Agreement.

I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) for granting me leave to introduce this motion. On a successive number of occasions the House generally has had an opportunity to discuss the operation and continuity of what is one of the most critical of the defence arrangements between the United States and Australia, one that has had an effect way beyond that bilateral relationship.

Twenty years ago, on 17 May 1962, the then Prime Minister, Robert Menzies, told this House that the Government of the United States had formally requested permission to establish and operate a naval communications station at North West Cape in Western Australia. The Commomwealth approved this request. It had the agreement of the Government of Western Australia which had given considerable assistance and had expressed its desire to co-operate in the project to the fullest possible extent. Prime Minister Menzies told the House that the question of the establishment of the station would be embodied in a formal agreement between the governments of Australia and the United States. He pointed out very astutely that the establishment of this station in Australia would mark an important step in defence co-operation between our two countries. He observed that it would make a highly significant contribution to the general allied military capability in our area within the spirit of co-operation envisaged in the ANZUS Treaty, under which the parties agreed to co-ordinate their defence for the preservation of peace and security.

Twelve months later on 9 May 1963 the then Minister for External Affairs and Attorney-General, Sir Garfield Barwick, presented the United States Naval Communication Station Agreement Bill to this House. He announced that on that morning he and the American Ambassador, Mr William Battle, had signed an agreement for the station on behalf of their respective governments. The government of the day had decided to submit the agreement to the Parliament for approval before exchanging its instrument of approval with the Government of the United States. Under the Agreement, the Australian Government permitted the American Government to establish, maintain and operate a naval communication station at North West Cape for a minimum period of 25 years. The station was to be a United States communication station under the control of the United States Government. The station was to have no capability other than to transmit and receive messages but it was to provide a very important link in communications with naval vessels in the oceans and seas around and adjacent to Australia and to the south and South East Asia. As Sir Garfield told the House:

. . . the deterrence of aggression in those parts of the world of greatest immediate significance to Australia, namely, the Western Pacific region and South East Asia-stretching from the Soviet Far East southwards through Korea and the islands of the east coast of Asia and westwards into South East Asia-depends to a great extent upon the capacity of the United States Navy to react against aggression.

The government of the day foresaw that changing technology demanded the capabilities which the station at North West Cape would provide. From the outset the communication station at North West Cape was seen as reflecting the spirit of the ANZUS Treaty. Under Article II of that Treaty the parties agree separately and jointly to develop their individual and collective capacity to resist attack. The North West Cape Agreement enabled two of the partners- Australia and the United States-to meet their joint responsibilities in this pact. With improved communication facilities the United States was able better to play its part in maintaining the peace and security of the world generally and in our region in particular.

Australia, by providing the site and agreeing to the establishment, maintenance , and operation in Australia of the communication station also made a significant contribution to the mutual purposes of the ANZUS pact and to peace and security generally. Further, Australian forces were to have the use of the facilities of the station for training and this enabled us to be better prepared to meet our obligations under ANZUS. In introducing the agreement in this House, Sir Garfield Barwick stressed seven broad principles which the two governments had recognised in the course of their negotiations. They were: Firstly, that the agreement and the obligations it creates should respect the sovereignty of each; secondly, that the control of the station should rest with the United States; thirdly, that when desired by either there should be consultation between the two governments as to matters connected with the station and its use; fourthly, that the Australian armed forces should have the use of the communication services of the station; fifthly, that the Australian Government should not seek to make a revenue profit out of the American establishment, maintenance, or operation of the station and that, where possible, it should assist to minimise the cost of the station to the American Government; sixthly, that in the establishment, operation and maintenance of the station, the maximum practicable use of Australian resources should be made; and seventhly, that, without submitting to the jurisdiction of Australian courts, or compromising its sovereignty, the United States would conform to Australian law and its personnel would observe it. The Agreement carried out these principles and, with some necessary modifications to meet changing circumstances over the ensuing two decades, the principles have persisted.

The Agreement entered into force on 28 June 1963. On 16 September 1967 the station was commissioned as United States Naval Communication Station North West Cape. It was later renamed the Naval Communication Station Harold E. Holt. Up to 1974 Australia's participation was predominantly in the provision of the site. The station was an American facility available for use by our forces but over which at that stage we had no control.

On 10 January 1974 the then Minister for Defence, Mr Barnard, and the United States Secretary of Defense, Dr Schlesinger, issued a joint communique which announced their agreement that the station at North West Cape would be operated as a joint facility. The communique also announced that the United States had agreed to keep Australia informed of strategic and operational developments of relevance to the station. The Minister and the Secretary noted that strategic and political consultations between the two governments were already well established through bilateral contacts in the ANZUS forums. However, they agreed :

. . . to extend and strengthen their bilateral consultations to ensure that the Australian Government would have full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to the station and their significance for Australian national interests.

They agreed further that, with the use of the station as a joint facility and consistent with the agreement of May 1963 on the establishment of the station, Australia's servicemen would participate in the management and operation of the facility.

Subsequently, on 21 March 1974, an exchange of notes was concluded between Australia and the United States to amend the agreement of 9 May 1963. The exchange of notes provided for amendments to Article 1, Article 2 and Article 14 of the Agreement. The amendment to Article 1 provided that the station would henceforth be operated jointly and the amendment to Article 2 limited the United States Navy exclusive occupation of the station to a national room. The amendment to Article 14 provided that the Australian Government would meet costs directly associated with the presence of the Royal Australian Navy at the station. Since 1974 there have been regular consultations between Australian and United States defence officials in fulfilment of the obligation then accepted by Dr Schlesinger.
The basic principles of the North West Cape Agreement still stand. However, as a result of recent consultations between the partners, Article 6 can now be deleted. Article 6 provides that:

The Australian Government will, jointly with the Government of the State of Western Australia, appoint a Civil Commissioner at Exmouth, who will have such functions as those Governments may vest in him and will represent them in such matters as they may determine.

The position of Civil Commissioner at Exmouth should be abolished as it is no longer required. The role of the Civil Commissioner provided under the Agreement was to assist the United States Navy in arranging the provision of Commonwealth and State government services to the naval communication station and the associated community when the station was being established. Since the election of a local council in Exmouth in 1978, however, the Civil Commissioner has not been involved in State or local government matters affecting Exmouth and he has not performed any duties there on behalf of any Commonwealth agencies or departments other then the Department of Defence. Both the Exmouth Shire Council and the Western Australian Government want the position abolished.

Further, following a recent review of security arrangements at North West Cape, the Civil Commissioner's residual responsibilities as officer-in-charge of the prohibited area were transferred to the Australian Deputy Commander at the station. The Government of Western Australia and the United States Government concur with the proposal to abolish the position and in consultation with the Department of Foreign Affairs agreement has been reached with the United States on the text of the necessary exchange of notes. It is therefore appropriate in advising the House of the deletion of Article 6 that this House re-states the relationship between Australia and the United States in the broader function and use of the North West Cape facility. It is for this reason that I introduced this motion into the House this afternoon.

On 5 May 1981, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) raised in this House two demands for renegotiation of the North West Cape Naval Communication Station Agreement required by his party. These were demands he first stated when he spoke to the National Press Club on 14 April 1981. The demands were, firstly, that Australia's consent be mandatory for all orders to initiate military action which flow from the station and, secondly, that firm and convincing assurances be given that the station will not be used to send orders for a first strike nuclear attack or to initiate a limited strike. As I have set out in the motion now before the House, the Government believes those conditions would be totally unacceptable to the Americans and that they would frustrate the continuation of the Agreement in the manner necessary to preserve Australia's situation and to advance Australia's security. We believe the existing consultative procedures should be maintained and not extended. We believe under the existing consultative procedures the facility can continue to be effectively used in support of Australia's interests and indeed the interests of security in this part of the world. To modify the Agreement to give Australia a veto of United States orders in the manner suggested by the Leader of the Opposition would without doubt frustrate the purpose of the base as now envisaged. Certainly such a veto given to the United States over Australian orders emanating from the station to Australian ships or aircraft would not be acceptable to Australia.

The base is a communications facility. Its use facilitates the United States' military presence in our region with all the deterrent capability that that represents. The continued importance of this deterrent is apparent when taking into account the increasing Soviet presence in the Indian and Pacific Oceans and in Vietnam. To the north of the Indian Ocean, Soviet aggression in Afghanistan can be seen only as a potential threat to other countries in our region.

In Vietnam the increasing Soviet military and economic presence is a matter of concern not just to Australia but to all the countries in the Association of South East Asian Nations and indeed was canvassed with me over the course of the last few weeks. There have been noticeable increases in the transit and stationing of Soviet ships and aircraft, both numerically and in capability, through Cam Ranh Bay and Da Nang. This comes without any new factor to provoke that Soviet military build-up.

In the free world only the United States has the capability and national resource necessary to provide an adequate deterrent to Soviet military expansionism. No impediment should be placed on the use and operation of the base to meet the stated needs and requirements of the Treaty partners. Free and uninhibited access to the facilities of the base by the Treaty partners is essential to its effective use as a vital element in the Western deterrent. Any impediment placed by either party to access to the facilities of the base in relation to its use by either party cannot be accepted.

The North West Cape is of major importance in the United States' military presence in this region. It provides a communication capability important in the command function between elements of the United States forces. The Government rejects the suggestion of the Leader of the Opposition for renegotiation of the North West Cape Naval Communication Agreement in the manner he then proposed. It believes the existing consultative procedures adequate and appropriate. They cannot be amended without prejudicing the purpose of the base itself and inhibiting the maintenance of an adequate Western deterrent in our region. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion. It must disappoint the Government to know that it does. I cannot imagine why we have heard such a nonsense here about the North West Cape base when all we are doing is deleting the title of Civil Commissioner from an agreement. It is as though we have to report to Parliament every time we change the cleaning contract in the cafeteria of the North West Cape base. This motion is about as relevant as that. I am amazed to think that the whole Parliament has been keyed up for some massive statement that is going to affect the alliance between America and Australia when really all that is happening is that, because the local council at Exmouth took over the area in 1978, four years ago, rushed into this Parliament is an extraordinary motion to say that we are going to delete Article 6 because there is no Civil Commissioner there any longer. How ridiculous can we get? Now that the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) has opened the matter up and in the process made an unjustifiable attack on my leader who, he knew, was not here today--
—I didn't know that.
—The Minister should have known. An inquiry would have revealed that.
—He doesn't normally advise me of his movements.

—Well, just give us a chance to talk about it; it was a pretty rushed arrangement. Let us look at what has actually happened. The significant thing is that the Agreement was entered into in 1963. The relevant part of that Agreement is Article 3. We agree with the motion because it is subject to Article 3, which quite fairly says that, except with the express consent of the Australian Government, the station will not be used for purposes other than purposes of defence communication. It is as simple as that. So the proviso overrides the whole lot. My colleague the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) is in the House. I welcome his presence. Whilst the Minister today was anxious to tell us about the way in which Sir Garfield Barwick introduced the matter to the House in 1963, he did not say-it took my colleague the honourable member for St George to ascertain this in 1973-that at the same time as this Agreement was tabled in the House there was correspondence between him and Mr Battle, who was then the United States Ambassador, which he never disclosed to the House or to the nation. The correspondence virtually says: 'Never mind what Article 3 says when it says that we require your consent. We will read it on the basis that we need only consult'. As my colleague has said, that was the darkest day for Australia in its endeavour to retain sovereignty over its own land. Is it not despicable that even today the Minister could not advert to the fact that the correspondence has not yet been tabled and that it took my colleague, when Minister, to disclose that matter?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us also be mindful of the fact that in January 1974 when our Defence Minister Barnard discussed the matter with Schlesinger fair and proper arrangements for the base were made. If we look at what Barnard said when he looked at the base, we see that Australia had only one representative-a member of the Navy-at the North West Cape base. As a result of Barnard's proper and intelligent work and with the clear understanding and co-operation of the United States, because its people are intelligent, it became a joint facility. We should bear in mind that in those days-in the days of Sir Robert Menzies and others-members of the Opposition were excluded from even a chance to visit the base. I welcome the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen) here today. I applaud him because, when we asked him whether we could go to the base, he readily granted us permission to do so. We found the base to be working quite satisfactorily in a number of ways. The point that ought to be emphasised is that the base is a communications facility. Is it not important, in looking at Article 3, to understand what we are giving consent to? Our personnel have access to that base. We are able to co-operate very effectively because our submarines use the base. That is an intelligent position for us to adopt concerning our own communications. Our personnel there can readily say: ' Naturally, we don't understand each others' signals, nor should we'. That alerted my leader and me. I take the same responsibility as my leader for saying : 'That is a little unusual, is it not? We are given to understand that the base is to be used only for defence communications. Would you know whether a signal went through placing the base on alert'-apparently that happened on one occasion and nobody was told-'and if a signal went through that might initiate military action which would make the base automatically a target for a nuclear attack would you know what it was?' They said: 'No. We are not in a position'. My leader, quite properly, said something that does not in any way weaken our position when he said: 'We would like to see the position put on a sensible basis by way of renegotiation, saying that our consent is mandatory for all orders to initiate military action and that we will be given firm and convincing assurances that the station will not be used to send orders for a first strike or to initiate a limited strike'. What is wrong with that for Australia and an Australian Prime Minister? Would the Government not like to know that a country is going to war? Would it tell the Australian people that it did not want to know? The concept we believe in would be a great achievement in nuclear disarmament. Australia should adhere strictly to deterrents and deterrents only. That is what it is all about.

The Vietnam war got a mention. We should bear in mind that this situation arose at the time of the Vietnam war. I am delighted to know that the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) can now go to China and shake the hands of its leaders, welcoming them as friends. But from 1960 to 1963, the period about which we are talking, it was the downward thrust of China that Australia was worried about. Conscription was introduced, leaving 496 dead in Vietnam, because of that downward thrust. The base is important, from the point of view of confrontation in South-East Asia. Mention is made in the statement of Asia and its problems. Were there not problems? How about the Indonesian confrontation? How about the fact that when Barwick was in the United States urging some support from Dean Rusk it was made very clear to him that we would be on our own in such matters and that the Indonesian confrontation was a matter for us? Dean Rusk was obviously acting in accordance with instructions. I think he thought at the time that he may have been able to help us, but President Kennedy said: 'No, that is not the issue. The United States is a super power. It is very concerned about the world. We are not going to get involved in these local issues'. Barwick was very disappointed with that position. He will refer to it in his memoirs when he writes them.

Why does the Government carry on with this stupid nonsense of always trying to mortgage the American alliance for its own political advantage? Why does it want to dress up every American sailor with instructions around his neck on how to vote Liberal? Does it want to portray the Americans outside every polling booth? Let me make it clear that the recent visit by an American warship followed a special invitation to it by the Prime Minister to visit four ports-Brisbane, Tasmania, Melbourne and Sydney-in the hope that there would be confrontation. How stupid it is of this Government to think that it will ever lead the nation if it is always dividing it. All we are talking about is the fact that the Exmouth Council took over the North West Cape area in 1978. We welcome that move . We think that it is the best thing that ever happened. I hope it keeps the streets clean and the rates down. That is its important function.

Let us be understood. We have no objection to the Government's position but we put on record the disgraceful manner in which this matter was handled in the 1960s under another government of the same Liberal philosophy. It is deplorable that the Prime Minister wants to use the alliance for his own political gain. We will not accept that to any degree. I wish to place on record the Australian Labor Party's policy. It has been our policy for a long while. Our policies are formulated by fellow Australians who have no personal ambitions always to be in this Parliament. They are anxious to preserve this nation as a free and independent sovereign nation at peace. They respect the alliance. They know very well that in the Second World War Australians were fighting for their lives because Australia was a very valid ally of the United States. I have before me a cable from President Roosevelt to Prime Minister Curtin in July 1942 stating that Roosevelt thought it would be helpful if Curtin agreed with Prime Minister Churchill and did not want the return of the Ninth Division from the Middle East . He said that it was important to keep the Ninth Division in the Middle East because the United States wanted to win the war in the Middle East first and come and get Australia later. That did not appeal to Curtin at the time and I do not think it appealed to anybody in Australia. The President of the United States had this to say: 'I would like to remind you, Mr Prime Minister, that I have given you one of our best generals to defend you'. Curtin said: 'Thank you very much, Mr President. You have given us a great general. But could I remind you that of the 10 divisions under his control eight are Australian?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight?
—Yes. I suggest that the honourable member have a quick look at the number of divisions we had.
—How many fighting divisions did we have?

—The honourable member should have a good look at the number. Does he not know? Perhaps the honourable member is a little behind the times. I suggest that he have a look at the number of people who were mobilised at that time. He should consider the fact that Australia had the Sixth, Seventh, Eighth and Ninth Divisions. Let us be very clear about those in Australia-what we would call the militia-who were also involved. But let us not get too carried away. The point I was making related to the independence of our sovereignty, which is established by formulating policy from fellow Australians, such as the honourable members present. We should be proud of our country and its record and not subservient and servile to another country. The Americans do not respect that anyway. They welcome people who have some initiative and some courage. I spoke to Stoessel in the United States in 1981. I said to him: 'Would you have any objection to our having an appropriate officer in Washington who could be informed of your strategic policy so that there would be no doubt about the sorts of messages that went through the North West Cape base?'. He replied: 'I have no objection at all'. That is an intelligent thing to do, is it not? Naturally the United States wants to see us co-operating with it. It is important for Australians to learn to use the facilities at the North West Cape and to understand that in no way would they affect our sovereignty or involve us in a war without our consent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's policy is as follows: We want the base to be operated without any derogation of our sovereignty. We would like the Australian public to be informed of the general purposes and functions of the base. We want to ensure that the Australian Government is kept informed at the highest level of any changes in the strategic planning or policies of the United States which could in any way affect the nature of the base or the uses to which it would be put. We want also to ensure that the Australian Government has an opportunity to contribute to such strategic planning or policies as they evolve. Further, we wish to ensure that Australian personnel are fully involved in all aspects of the base's operations and have the relevant technical expertise to be so involved. I am delighted to note that that is made clear in the motion now before the House. Clause (5) of the motion states:
. . . that no impediment should be placed by either party on access to the facilities of the base in relation to the use of the base by the other party, . . .

That means that our personnel now have access to all the base, which is an improvement. That is fine. They have not had that access up to the present. There have been one or two rooms that they should not go into, but now they will have access to the lot. That is an impressive improvement. It accords with the principle of being fully involved and able to participate. I am certain that the Americans are delighted to know that that is the position. We welcome it.

I come back to the point: It would be rather futile for the Opposition to argue for the retention of the Civil Commissioner at Exmouth when his position was abolished four years ago. I cannot see how the Opposition would win any arguments about that. That is the whole extent of this motion and we warmly support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all welcome the fact that the Opposition has joined with us on this motion but thereafter there is a considerable difference of opinion as to where we should be going in this country. We have been listening to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). Some of the old questions have come up. He talks about sovereignty as though we were not sovereign in this country. We are sovereign. We can tell the Americans that we do not want the alliance. We can tell them to pack up and go home. We can tell them that we are not going to have them at the north west communications station in any circumstances at all, or we can impose circumstances and conditions on them that are such that they will never be accepted. This will mean the same thing and will amount to the same thing. It will mean that the Americans will go home. That is something which elements of the Australian Labor Party want. There is no doubt about that. Anybody who bothers to read the conference transcript of the ALP gets that message loud and clear. So that is the first thing that we can do. Let us make up our minds as to whether we are in or out of this alliance. If we are in this alliance let us make up our minds that we are going to stay in it . Alliances involve responsibilities and risks. So far as one can determine what does the ALP want? We must understand that it might never get around to understanding anything about foreign policy. If honourable members had listened to what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) had to say some few weeks ago they would have been perfectly staggered at the reversal which was seized upon by his loyal colleague the honourable member of Wills (Mr Hawke) as the basis for a little bit of a power struggle. He apparently completely misunderstood American policy which has been in place for years about the visit of nuclear- powered and nuclear-armed ships to friendly countries. Having been instructed on the subject he agreed that he was in error.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us return to the question of the base. Back in 1974 Mr Barnard made some inquiries. Let us remind ourselves of the answer that was given to Mr Barnard back in 1974. This appears in part of an interview with the Leader of the Opposition. It states:
The Department's views of North West Cape were given in 1974 to Mr Lance Barnard, the Defence Minister in the Whitlam Government.
The Department's view is this:

We have told the Ambassador in Washington that Australia might seek an undertaking from the United States not to use the North West Cape Station to transmit a nuclear firing order. It is unlikely that the United States would give such an undertaking given the importance to it of swift and secure communications with its nuclear ballistic submarines as part of its second strike capacity.
Nothing has changed and the world is not a better place now than it was then. The report went on to state:

Second, it would be impractical to verify compliance with an undertaking; and third, to demand an undertaking is, in important respects, undesirable. It would manifest indifference to the United States requirements with its nuclear strategy and to the common defence interest expressed in the ANZUS treaty.

That was the position then. No doubt it is the position now. All of us would have a sense of horror at any thought of the use of nuclear arms. It is something with which we must live as a possibility no matter how remote and no matter how potentially disastrous. We can make a decision here as to whether we want a special deal for this country which, no doubt, the Americans do not give to any of their other allies. We can make a decision as to whether we are going to have a foreign policy without risks and a defence policy without risks.

If one looks at the risks that are taken by some of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies, we see that the only risk we would seem to take is the risk that one station may be targeted whereas their entire countries are targeted in the dreadful event that there may be a war. What a cowardly approach to life that is. For those members of the ALP who constantly say, as the Leader of the Opposition has said on various occasions, that the ANZUS alliance is a one-way road and only a few people get any benefit out of it, let me just remind them of what their leader said at his conference. This was an answer to the proposition that the ANZUS treaty should be wiped. Of course he had to spring to the defence of the ANZUS treaty since he realised the ALP had nothing to put in its place. Indeed, he said so himself. He stated-this is the argument we always get: 'The Americans are picking up all the benefits and we have been paying just about all the premiums, but that can be changed'. Let me quote what he had to say on the subject of premiums and our picking them all up. When he was arguing against the wiping of the treaty he said: 'You do that and you will find an increasingly terrified community which wants a vastly increased spending on armaments-perhaps not wise, perhaps not well informed but an inevitable consequence of that historical sense of insecurity and vulnerability which has always assailed this nation right from its foundation day.' That is no doubt the case.

If honourable members by their actions slowly erode the base of the treaty they will find one of these days that we are going to have to face up to spending very much more money on defence than we have in the past when we have managed our defence on the cheap, thanks to the ANZUS alliance. I welcome what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has said on the subject of the motion. Had he confined himself to the motion it would have been unnecessary to say anything else. Since as usual he decided to traverse the countryside putting forward the old regurgitated views which the ALP has been peddling around for the last 15 or 20 years, and which have never been accepted by this country, it has been necessary to say something about those views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the period that I have been in this House and listened to debates in this chamber I have heard a lot of phoney debates, a lot of phoney sentiments and some straight out phoneys. This is a phoney debate. It has nothing to do with the security and defence of Australia. It has nothing to do with any suggestion that the defence or the security of Australia is threatened. In fact, the resolution authorises the discontinuance of a civil commissioner to run a community which has had a town council for four years, and a very effective town council if I may say so. Many of our colleagues visited there recently and so did the Minister. This debate is one of those stage- setting debates in which this Government and its predecessors have regularly engaged. They have used the rhetoric of traitor, treason, lack of integrity, threat to Australia's security and threat to Australia's alliances. Those of us who contested the election in 1966 remember the visible lie on which the Government of that day was re-elected. There was a pamphlet which showed great blood red arrows coming down out of China into Australia.
—This is part of the Western alliance.

—I understand that. That was what they sought. The pamphlet which they portrayed on that particular occasion as their election winner was that Chinese were coming. It was one of those convenient slogans that the world was later told arose from the fact that when one hangs a map up on the wall China is above Australia and everything flows downhill. It had about as much relevance to reality as most of the other rhetoric we hear in this parliament and the rhetoric we are hearing now.
—Nothing to do with Tibet.

—The honourable member has just recognised that China has sovereign rights over Tibet. This is something that other people have not done. If the honourable member knew his history and geography he would know that the regime in Taiwan that his Government supported for so long always claimed that Tibet was part of its sovereign territory, so he should not give us that rubbish. It is part of the nonsense and rhetoric that the Government uses as a substitute for real achievement and real policies.

SPEECH.PARA: What does this motion do other than bring about a debate in this House in which the Government feels it may be able to do some scene setting for a possible early election? The Government knows it will have to have an early election because of the incompetence of its management of the economy, its repeated policy failures and its self-admission of those failures in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) less than two days ago. That Speech acknowledged that one Australian in 30 who is now working will not be working next year. No wonder the Government wants to debate and to devote the next three hours of the sittings of this House to a motion which achieves the discontinuance of a requirement to appoint a civil commissioner to run the civil community at North West Cape. What sort of priorities does a government have that would engage in that sort of activity? They are phoney priorities, as the priorities of this Government always have been. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wants an issue with which he can frighten and divide the Australian nation. That has always been and always will be his type of politics. Let us look at his record in this type of exercise. There is nothing in the motion that any sane person could debate in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: — Stick to the motion.

—All right, I will stick to the motion. The motion states that the office of civil commissioner should be abolished because it is no longer necessary. That is all that is necessary to be said on the motion because that is all that is in the motion. But this Parliament will be asked to listen for the next 2 1/2 hours to the nonsense and rot perpetrated as part of Australia's national security. The Government has nothing more important to debate in the national Parliament. No wonder the troubles of this nation are growing daily when we have a government that looks for slogans, rhetoric and phoney debates as a cover-up for its ineptness, its incompetence and its failure to enlist the trust of the Australian people. Who could trust a government which does not know what the truth means and whose Prime Minister does not believe himself, let alone expect anyone else to believe him. If we are talking about defence-the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) is in the chamber; he introduced this phoney motion-let us talk about defence, not something which is meaningless. We were told--
—Confirm the agreement.

—The agreement is in existence in the form in which it was negotiated by my colleague the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) under a Labor government, and it is in no way altered by this motion, nor is there any suggestion that it will be.
—Do you support it?

—Do not be stupid. I thought you were supposed to be an intelligent person. No wonder the electors of New South Wales threw you out of your seat when you were the Leader of the Opposition. God help a State that was led by you .

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Corio will address the House.

—I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker; I was diverted. It is very difficult , under this pressure, to maintain one's concentration. If we are concerned and want to talk about the defence of Australia, honourable members opposite might ask the Government why real spending on actual defence has been significantly reduced in the Budget presented on Tuesday night. There is a 3 per cent drop, on the amount allocated one year ago, for the benefit of those members opposite, in the defence budget available for purposes other than to pay wages. No wonder the Government wants to divert attention. It is running out on its responsibilities in the defence area. In the equipment areas, the most critical and vital necessities of defence, it underspent by something like $200m last year. The Government appropriated moneys last year which it did not spend and actually reduced the rate of defence expenditure by deferring other items of expenditure which will have to be paid for at much higher rates at a later time.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is in the Parliament tonight not because there is any suggestion that the agreement with the United States is under threat, or because the Government wants to renegotiate that agreement or in any way alter that agreement other than to abolish the position of civil commissioner. It is in this Parliament for one reason and one reason only: The Government cannot find anything it can credibly talk about which has real substance and which should be before the national Parliament. The Government is devoid of ideas, lacks integrity and is incompetent in its administration of the financial affairs of this Commonwealth.

Why would the Government want to debate the real issues of the nation? It cannot credibly do so. The Prime Minister squirms every time unemployment is mentioned. What this phoney, meaningless motion does could have been done by Executive action, and it has been done by Executive action. We will have more of these phoney motions if this parliamentary session continues much longer. We will have more of them because we have a phoney government which is incapable of tackling the real problems of Australia, which is trying to tell the people of Australia that it has changed its policies, and which even tells the people of Australia that it is actually interested in the defence of Australia. Let me say this about defence: Throughout the 1930s statements like this were made by people on the other side of the Parliament. Throughout the 1930s they told us that we could depend on our allies. I do not in any way doubt the integrity of our allies, then or now. I say that absolutely. I know that statement will be misrepresented later because that is the way this Government works. In the 1930s the defence policy of the Australia Government was that the Royal Navy would protect Australia no matter what. The defence policy of this Government was mentioned quite intelligently by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). The present and past defence policies of this Government have been that we can afford to neglect real defence as long as we maintain the rhetoric!

TALK.START.PARA: —You said there would be no threat for 15 years.

—The previous Minister for Defence said it several times. This Government has made it clear both inside this House and outside this House that it believes that the defence policy of this country can depend on someone else, not Australians. Let me make this point quite clear to honourable members: If ever a situation arises in which we are required to defend this country again, we should be able to do that and be responsible for doing that ourselves. We have an obligation to plan on this basis. If that costs more, so be it. If we are not prepared to accept that, we must accept that we are prepared to neglect the defence of this country. Anyone who seeks to substitute defence by someone else for defence by ourselves is fooling themselves or is deliberately seeking to fool the Australian people. This Government has for some time been trying to fool the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: There are no commitments under the ANZUS treaty to the defence of Australia. There is a commitment which is qualified by a statement in respect of the constitutional processes. One would hope that the Australian Government has exactly the same qualifications. It is reasonable for any sovereign nation to reserve its right to make decisions on its own behalf. Australians would expect that any government of this country would have that entitlement; we are absolutely certain that the Government of the United States reserves that right. If it did not it would be thrown out of office because Americans believe in America. It is a pity more Australians do not believe in Australia.

We have a motion before us which is a stage setter designed to try to find some issue which can be exploited by a desperate government led by a desperate Prime Minister in order to justify an election for which he does not have to answer for the stewardship of himself or his Government to the Australian nation. The Government has failed and it will continue to fail. Its credibility in Australia and its capacity to lead this nation cannot be taken seriously by any person who realises what it is trying to perpetrate in this phoney motion. We will have a three hour debate in the national Parliament on a motion to terminate the appointment of a civil commissioner who has had no effective role since 1978. It is phoney!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Australian Labor Party have said in this House today that they are prepared to support the Government's motion in relation to the United States Naval Communications Station at the North West Cape; that is a charade. In this House today Australian Labor Party members are throwing a smokescreen over the ALP's real attitude because they know that the Australian Labor Party is hopelessly split on this issue of Australian-United States of America relations. Today the Deputy Leader of the ALP and the spokesman on defence came into this House, threw a smokescreen and tried to draw a curtain over the ALP's real attitude. But that will not fool the people of Australia because they know that the Labor Party is hopelessly split. They know that the vote at the ALP conference to retain the commitment to ANZUS was only 58 to 31.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is not speaking to the motion at all.
—Order! There is no point of order. Members on both sides of the House seem to be intent on engaging in character analysis.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the fallacious point of order only shows that honourable members opposite are scared of the truth that I am trying to give to the people.
—I raise a point of order. Is it correct to suggest that a margin of 27 in a particular ballot is an insufficient margin to demonstrate confidence?
—Order! There is no point of order. I caution members against raising frivolous points of order.

—I am happy to hear the point of order because the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) should know that if only 14 people change their minds at an ALP conference the ALP would abandon ANZUS. That is the answer to the honourable member.
—They are scared of the truth.

—The honourable member for Ballarat interjects and says we are scared of the truth. The truth is that the ALP is running scared on this issue. How can honourable members who sit on the other side of the House vote for this motion when their real policy is the one that was enunciated by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). However, we have not had it repeated today by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Lionel Bowen. I challenge the Deputy Leader to come into this House and say whether he agrees with his leader. Let us go to what the Leader of the Opposition has to say about the North West Cape. I am happy to read it to members of the Opposition; they will know their real position. In April the Leader of the Opposition said to the National Press Club:

SPEECH.PARA: We would seek to re-negotiate the North West Cape agreement to provide first, that Australia's consent is mandatory for all orders to initiate military action which flows from the station and second, that we (are) given firm and convincing assurances that the station will not be used to send orders for a first strike nuclear attack nor to initiate a limited strike. If the United States will not accept these reasonable provisions, designed to protect our national sovereignty , then-
I invite honourable members opposite to listen; Mr Hayden, the Leader of the Opposition, stated-
We would request them to wind down the operations of North West Cape as rapidly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again.
—The Leader of the Opposition said at the National Press Club in April 1981, and he repeated it in this House on 5 May 1981, that:

SPEECH.PARA: If the United States will not accept these reasonable provisions, designed to protect our national sovereignty then we would ask them to wind down the operations of North West Cape as rapidly as possible.
The Leader of the Opposition went on to say:
I make no apologies for that declaration of principle and policy.

I challenge the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to state to the House whether it is still Labor Party policy, as stated by the Leader of the Opposition in the House in May 1981, in the National Press Club in April 1981, and confirmed by a spokesman for the Leader of the Opposition in the Australian on 13 June this year, to wind down, close down and get rid of the United States participation at the naval communications station at North West Cape. That is the ALP policy; that is the policy of the socialist left in the ALP and it is Mr Hayden's policy . Opposition members will be completely hypocritical if they vote for this motion today because they have tried to throw a smokescreen over the ALP's real position. I challenge any member of the Opposition here today-I have challenged the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-to say in this House that he does not want to wind down, close or shut down the North West Cape naval communications station. That is what the ALP wants to do; that is its leader's policy. But no one in the ALP has had the courage to say in this House today that that is the ALP's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you serious?

—I challenge each and every honourable member who is interjecting. The honourable member for Hotham, who is trying to interject, is a member of the socialist left. Are socialist left members really going to vote for this motion? The ALP Whip has been very busy today. He is trying to quieten down honourable members but they know the real truth. The real truth is that the Labor Party wants to close down the North West Cape base. Honourable members opposite cannot with any conscience vote for this motion because in doing so they will, in fact, be deserting their leader.
—Did you fail logic?

—I did not fail logic. The honourable member wants to close the station down. Does the honourable member want to close the station down? The honourable member will not answer the question; he knows he wants to close the station down. I want to know whether the Deputy Leader of the Opposition agrees or disagrees with his leader? The socialist left and the socialist left unions control the Labor Party and they are controlling Labor Party policy. The ALP does threaten Australia's security; it has the death wish. Let me refer to Mr Cain, the Victorian Premier, because it is now known that he consulted the Leader of the Opposition about his proposed ban on nuclear ships in Victorian ports before the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was told of the plan. That report was in the Australian. A sudden quiet has come over Opposition members because the socialist left and the ALP--
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I ask honourable members on the Opposition benches to cease the continual interjection .

—Thank you, Mr Speaker, for your protection. The Labor Party is hopelessly divided and split. The socialist left is in control of the Leader of the Opposition. It has a concerted plan to close down the North West Cape station and to denigrate the United States at every opportunity it can. The Victorian ALP wants to repudiate ANZUS and the American alliance. The socialist left wants to repudiate the ANZUS alliance. The Leader of the Opposition and Mr Cain got together before Mr Cain made his statements about United States ships visiting Australian ports. The North West Cape is a naval communications facility which is important to the defence of Australia, the Western alliance, the United States and the free world. It is a communications station that communicates messages to submarines of both the United States Navy and the Royal Australian Navy. It is important for Australia's communications with its submarines and for United States communications with its submarines.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF ENGINEERING TRAINING CENTRE, PASADENA, SOUTH AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of an engineering training centre, Pasadena, S.A., for Telecom Australia.

This reference motion marks another stage in the Government's implementation of a co-ordinated set of public works procedures. These were announced by my predecessor, Mr McVeigh, in May 1981 when he responded to a report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure concerning alternative delivery systems for Commonwealth public works. As part of these procedures the Public Works Committee Act was amended on 9 April 1981 to make the major public works of most Commonwealth statutory and other authorities subject to review by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and their commencement subject to the agreement of this House. This is the first such proposal by an authority to be referred to the Committee and comprises building works and associated engineering services to establish a new engineering training centre for Telecom Australia on a site in Cashel Street, Pasadena.

The proposed facilities will replace unsatisfactory leased accommodation and inadequate portable buildings presently in use. A single storey development is proposed with appropriate landscaping and it has the support of local authorities. The work will comprise a complex of six linked buildings containing classrooms, practical training areas, staff rooms and staff amenities and an administration area, a separate block for external training programs, and associated roads, car parking, landscaping and engineering services.
The estimated cost of the proposal at June 1982 prices is $3.2m. I table plans of the proposed work.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED STATES NAVAL COMMUNICATION STATION AGREEMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was pointing out to the House that the Opposition, in saying that it would vote for this motion concerning the United States of America's Naval Communication Station at North West Cape, was in fact hiding its real attitude to the North West Cape facility, that in fact it is trying to put a smoke-screen over the Opposition's real position and that in fact there is substantial disagreement in the Australian Labor Party about the North West Cape facility. Today we heard in this House a statement from the Opposition which pulled the rug from under the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) made no reference whatsoever to the Labor Party's policy in relation to North West Cape. Labor Party speakers-the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in particular-have failed to repeat what the Leader of the Opposition said at the National Press Club in, I think, April 1981 and what the Leader of the Opposition repeated in this chamber on 5 May 1981. It is important. In relation to North West Cape, the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we would ask it to wind down the operations of the North West Cape as rapidly as possible.
The Leader of the Opposition went on to say:
I make no apologies for that declaration of principle and policy.
That is the Labor Party's policy.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) to say whether he agrees with the Leader of the Opposition. I ask the honourable member for Corio and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) to say whether they agree with the Leader of the Opposition.
—Order! Honourable members on my left will refrain from interjecting.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Higgins has asked me a question directly and has directed that I answer. He has selectively quoted and quoted out of context, which is the same as telling lies.

—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member well knows that the honourable member for Higgins is required, as is the case with all honourable members, to address the House through the Chair and is not free to engage in direct personal exchange with any other member.

—What I want to know from members of the Opposition who speak in this debate is whether they agree with the Leader of the Opposition or whether they agree with the real policy of the Labor Party, which is to wind down the operations at North West Cape. That is the Labor Party's policy. It has been stated in the House by the Leader of the Opposition but the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was very silent about it today. Labor Party members are trying to hoodwink the people of Australia. They are trying to throw a smoke-screen over their real policy. But they cannot fool the people of Australia because those people know that the Labor Party is hopelessly split on that issue. They know the power of the socialist left. They know that the Labor Party wants to dismantle that station and the Labor Party wants to denigrate Australia's relations with the United States.
—Why didn't you quote the leader instead of telling lies?
—I want to hear later from the honourable member for Corio whether he agrees with his leader. I want to know where Opposition members who are in the chamber stand.
—Let us hear the full quotation now.

—I want to know where the honourable member for La Trobe stands. Does he agree with his leader? I believe that a substantial number of the members of the Opposition who are in this chamber now and the Oppositon itself want to denigrate the United States and to close down this station. The North West Cape is important to the Western alliance.
—He is incapable of debate so he makes up fabrications.
—Are you in favour of the North West Cape continuing? Can I pin you on that in the chamber? Will you go on record as saying that?
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will address the chamber through the Chair.

—I see a smile coming over the face of the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). I would like to ask him-it is very pertinent that I do so- whether he agrees with his leader. Will the honourable member for Wills tell me? I will give you a second to say whether you agree with the Leader of the Opposition that it is Labor Party policy to wind down the operations at North West Cape. The honourable member for Wills has suddenly become silent because he knows that it is Labor Party policy, which he has to endorse, to wind down the operations at North West Cape.
—He is continually asking us questions.
—The honourable member for Hindmarsh knows that. I notice he is interjecting. Honourable members opposite are afraid to tell the truth in this chamber.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—The honourable member for La Trobe is another one. Let him tell us what he really thinks.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member keeps asking us questions. This is not the proper order of debate. I ask you to sit him down.
—Order! There is no point of order. I warn the honourable member against taking specious points of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for your protection. I am afraid that I have struck a raw nerve in the Opposition. The honourable member for Wills has become strangely silent while the socialist left rabble interject and try to put me off the point. The point is that this House knows-
—You have never been on it.
—Is the honourable member for Wills in favour of winding down the North West Cape facility, the same as leader? Yes, he is. I challenge the honourable member to speak in this debate.
—I am going to.
—Good. When he does, will he please tell us whether he agrees with the words of his leader in regard to winding down the operations at North West Cape?
—You know I am committed to my leader.
—What did the honourable member say about his leader?
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will ignore interjections.

—I am not too convinced about that and neither is the electorate at large. When the honourable member for Wills speaks will he agree with his leader and make no apologies for his declaration of principle and policies? It will be very interesting to see what the honourable member has to say about that. The North West Cape facility is important for Australia. It is an important facility for the Western alliance of which Australia is part. It is important in relation to Australia's relationship with the United States of America under ANZUS. Does the honourable member for Kalgoorlie accept the defence relationship under ANZUS ? Does the honourable member accept Australia's relations with the United States ? Yes or no?
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the honourable member for Corio seek to make a personal explanation?

—Yes. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), claimed that in my remarks I had failed to support the policy of my party and failed to support a statement which he claimed had been made by my leader. I have never suggested that I do not support the policy of my party. The honourable member did not quote a statement which was made by the Leader of this party, Mr Bill Hayden. What he did was take a selected portion of a sentence which is a part of a Liberal Party handout document and read it in this House. To read a statement which is not the full statement is the same as telling a lie . The honourable member has just misrepresented every member on this side of the House with a deliberate lie.
—The honourable member for Corio has made his point, but I must caution him against the use of a term which he knows full well is unparliamentary.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask for a withdrawal of that statement by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). I was quoting from Hansard of 5 May 1981.

—The honourable member will resume his seat. The honourable member for Higgins as is his right requests a withdrawal of the unparliamentary term. I call upon the honourable member for Corio to withdraw.
—I withdrew the unparliamentary expression. I have again been misrepresented.
—The honourable member for Corio will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for St George.
—I want an unqualified withdrawal.
—Order! The House will come to order. The matter has been resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess that it is a tremendous challenge to follow the brilliance of argument and the eloquence of presentation of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). This evening I want to allay some of his concerns and fears before he obviously has a heart attack. Tonight we are debating a proposition that has been put forward by the Government. To make the point very clear I will take point (1) of the motion put forward by the Government. That point is:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) confirms the United States Naval Communications Station Agreement 1963-
I underline this-
as amended. . .

In the details that were given by the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) in his speech he pointed out that the 1963 Act was amended. It was amended by the Australian Labor Party in Government. What this Government is doing today is really asking the Parliament, including both the Government and the Opposition, to reaffirm an agreement that was renegotiated by the Labor Party in government. Then, through this absurdity the Government asks why the Opposition is supporting the proposition. Of course, we are supporting the proposition because the Parliament is being asked to reaffirm the agreement that was renegotiated by the Labour Government. Can I get that through the heads of the Government members this day?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I rather doubt that, as the honourable member for Wills suggests. Is there anything very extraordinary about the fact that the Labor Party is accepting a proposition that is put up by the Government to reaffirm what the Labor Party stood for and renegotiated? That is the crux of the issue. Tonight I think this Government should be condemned. It is demeaning and making a mockery not only of this Parliament but also of the alliance with the United States. It is a shoddy, despicable tactic. It is a tawdry gimmick. I am sure that it is a matter of great embarrassment to the United States to be used as a gambit in the desperate efforts by the Fraser Government to manipulate an election before the Budget, which it brought down two days ago, falls apart. Tonight we are talking about this Government and the new Minister for Defence. I am sure that the former Minister for Defence would not have subjected this Parliament to this humiliation.

SPEECH.PARA: What are we discussing tonight? We have already said-why should we not say it- that we are reaffirming a negotiated treaty that the Labor Party put through. What is this big, momentous amendment that is being brought forward tonight?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a phoney.

—It is an absolute phoney, as my colleague the honourable member for Corio points out. All we are really doing tonight is accepting a proposition so that the Article in the Agreement which concerns the appointment of the Civil Commissioner at Exmouth is deleted. Of course, it should be deleted. But it should have been deleted four years ago because, as any Western Australian member in the Government knows, there was an election of a local council for the district of Exmouth in which the North West Cape is located. So, the notion of a civil commissioner is no longer relevant. Here is this great momentous decision with which the Minister for Defence walks in tonight. I am sure that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is listening, hoping against hope, that he will develop a trigger for his election which he sorely needs. All we are saying is that a position which was incorporated in 1963, which was still relevant in 1974 when we re-negotiated the treaty, is no longer relevant because of the election in Western Australia in 1978. I think it is very important for members of the Parliament to recognise that this happened in 1978. Why was this not brought in in 1978, 1979, 1980 or 1981? I think we all have the answer. It is because it happens to be the case that the Prime Minister is trying to trigger an election. So he brings this up in 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: We renegotiated the treaty. There were some very good reasons why we renegotiated the treaty in 1974. There was an exchange of letters that we brought in in 1975. I was very happy, as the Minister for Defence, to put the motion through the Parliament. The first reason we renegotiated the treaty was that we excised from the treaty. What I have said-I said it then as the former Minister for Defence knows-is that I regarded the treaty as an infamous text of the exchange of letters between Mr Battle who was then the United States Ambassador and Mr Barwick who was then the Minister for Foreign Affairs. That letter was a blatant and deliberate abdication of Australian sovereignty. That is why the Labor Party opposed the legislation in 1963. The Liberal Party in government then quite deliberately abdicated Australian sovereignty. So, in the renegotiations that were carried out in the period 1972-74 the major objective of the Labor Party was to excise that infamous exchange of letters. We were successful. I noticed that the Minister for Defence in putting forward his speech today did not even make one mention of that letter-as well he may-because that was a great humiliation for Australia. Article 3 of the Agreement provides for consultation. Effectively that letter stated that irrespective of what was in Article 3 it does not mean what it says it means. That is the record of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shoddy.

—It is shoddy. The Government completely abdicated Australian sovereignty and Australian responsibility. That was a shameful act. I was very proud to be associated with the excision of that shameful letter from the treaty between Australia and our great ally the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the renegotiation was that the Liberal Party, back in 1963- if one goes through the Hansard records one will see it-proudly asserted that the base would be under sole United States control. That is part of the provocation that was applied in 1963. This is the attempted provocation now. We set ourselves to remove that notion from the alliance arrangement with the United States. We turned the concept of a sole base into the concept of a joint facility. That is what the base is now. That is what we are being asked to reaffirm. Of course we will reaffirm it. If we were asked to reaffirm the 1963 agreement we would be thoroughly opposed to it. If the Government has any intestinal fortitude in what it is trying to do tonight it will come up with the proposition that we negate what happened in 1974 and go back to the 1963 agreement but it is not game to do that. What we are being asked to do tonight is to reaffirm the 1974 agreement. Of course we will reaffirm it.

When we took over in 1972 there were no Australian servicemen on the North West Cape. We had the Commissioner for Exmouth who was a clerk of works, no more and no less, but there were no Australian servicemen on the base. Australia itself did not have the facilities. Only one Australian was on the base because the Government of the day, the Liberal Government, had said it was a sole United States base. So we set out to change that agreement, the agreement we are confirming tonight. I want to read to the House the exchange of letters that took place between my predecessor as Minister for Defence and the United States authorities. I will read it very carefully so that even Government members are likely to understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to go slowly.

—I will go slowly. I have made a dozen speeches on the North West Cape in this House and the very same arguments come up from the other side. Perhaps tonight members of the Government will listen and we will have done with this charade. A Press release by the former Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister agreed that, with the use of the station as a joint facility and consistent with the agreement of May 1963 on the establishment of the Naval Communications Station, Australian servicemen would participate in the management and operation of the station.
The Australian Minister said that for this purpose, Australian personnel would commence moving into the station towards the end of the year.
These arrangements will place Australian personnel in key positions and establish a substantial Australian contribution to the management and operation of the station.
To coordinate Australian activities at the station, an Australian Deputy Commander will be appointed.

One would have thought that those propositions would have been incorporated in the agreement from the word go but they were not. The Government in 1963 was trying on the same gimmick as the Government in 1982 is trying on tonight. It did not have the guts to put forward to an ally the very simple proposition that any base on Australian territory should be a joint facility. We accept that argument. I think the former Minister for Defence can corroborate that I have expressed the proposition both as Minister for Defence and as a member of this Parliament since 1969. We recognise the role that is played by the United States in the deterrent capabilities of the Western allies. But this does not mean to say that Australia, in terms of a base on Australian soil, does not have a rightful responsibility to act as an intelligent ally; not an obsequious, subservient ally-to play an effective role in those facilities. In 1974-75 we turned the concept of a sole United States base into the concept of a joint facility.

One of the essential features of the North West Cape which was completely disregarded by the gentlemen opposite, even as far back as 1963, was the form of consultation that must take place between allies. I want to read from a speech made on 21 August 1975. It is a section of a speech that was quoted very recently by the former Minister for Defence. I have no compunction in reiterating it because it was my belief then and it is my belief now. At that time I said:

. . . the practical, realistic and effective mode of monitoring and control is certainly not a matter of intervention in the operations of the station. The proper focus of our effort is the United States global policy. If we know what that is about, we will have an accurate understanding of the type of message being transmitted through North West Cape. . . . Through discussions with the United States which form the basis of the legislation which we have here before us tonight-
This goes back seven years-
we made that consultation explicit. The substantial features are to ensure, to quote from the document:

. . . that the Australian Government would have full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to the station and their significance for Australian national interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad the honourable member for Wentworth agrees. This has been the continuing policy of the Labor Party in government and in opposition. Tonight the Minister is not even game to come into the chamber for the rest of the debate. I do not blame him because he should be humiliated by putting up this proposition. I am sure that the former Minister for Defence would never have come into the House with the charade that the Government is putting us through tonight. So what is the proposition tonight? The Minister comes in with a tawdry gimmick and Government members are then surprised that we in the Labor Party who renegotiated the agreement in 1974-the 1963 agreement that no Government members could be proud of this day-stand firm and will continue to stand firm on it.
—And on the ANZUS treaty?
—And on the ANZUS treaty. Honourable members can go back through the record; it is stated there explicitly. Our views are on the record and the propositions are clear.
—It is contemptible.

—The former Minister for Defence says it is contemptible. Of course it is contemptible. The whole proposition that has been brought into this House tonight is contemptible and it should receive the treatment it deserves. It is a contemptible, tawdry gimmick and I believe that the Government should be condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat . I direct the Clerk to stop the clock. I address the House quite seriously. Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner Mr Speaker addressed the House in appropriate terms acquainting honourable members of the requirements of them in the national Parliament. I know that a tactic is employed in this House by both sides from time to time based on interjections, in the knowledge that if the Chair intervenes, as it should do, the member with the call is denied the opportunity of concluding his remarks. In that respect the Chair in terms of simple justice is somewhat disadvantaged. I ask honourable members on both sides of the House to contribute to the dignity of this Parliament. By their collective actions they should not bring the place into disrepute.
— It was interesting and encouraging to hear the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) so vigorously reject the policies of his leader and I will come to that later.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I know this is not a point of order but, for goodness sake, can you not insist that the Government speakers at least be accurate?
—Order! There is no point of order. If honourable members deliberately set out to be provocative they must of necessity invite the response that is predictable.

—I will explain my point in the course of my speech. I am surprised at the reaction of the honourable member for St George. We have heard tonight from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen), from the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) and from the honourable member for St George. These gentlemen are very skilled, after years of bitter experience, at putting up the best front for that powerful group in the Labor Party which the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has described as 'a cancer eating at the heart of the Labor Party'; that is, the socialist left whose victory in the recent ALP leadership struggle has driven so many of their colleagues to despair . These are front of the shop men. We will not hear tonight from the socialist left speakers. We will not hear from the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) who, in the Sinai debate last year, distinguished himself by describing the United States as the greatest threat to peace in the world today. I do not think we will hear from the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) and so on. There are so many of them we will not hear from. We will hear from these front of the shop men. Nevertheless, despite their gifts and their cynicism, they cannot conceal the fact of Australian Labor Party policy, which is to impose such impossible conditions on United States retention of the North West Cape base that the United States must reject those conditions so that a Labor government will then close the base down.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic doctrine was given in the parliamentary debate last May by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). It was referred to and quoted by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). It is in essence that unless a Labor government has a veto on the orders to initiate military action from the base, it will close it down. That was stated with appealing candour, with a certain frankness, by the Leader of the Opposition.
