But as so often happens when Labor policy is stated frankly, the cosmeticians had to get to work to soften it, to blur the outline and to obscure the issue. Of course, one of the great masters of this skill is the Deputy Leader of the Oppositon (Mr Lionel Bowen). Very quickly they got to work to make their leader's doctrine obscure. For example, last April in a media release the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that Labor proposed to renegotiate the North West Cape base agreement-not to give a Labor government the right of veto or the possibility of closing it down if that veto was rejected-we got none of that; we got a more cosmetic formula-but to renegotiate the Agreement to include an Australian representative in Washington who would have access to United States strategic policy which might result in militarily strategic messages being sent through the North West Cape. We see the Morrison influence there or possibly the Barnard influence from earlier times. The next day the Leader of the Opposition quoted that again, but added something which I do not think the cosmeticians wanted. Referring to what Mr Bowen had said, he added:
This will serve as an interim measure.

Of course, the veto principle and the closing down principle are still there, but we have something cosmetic as an interim measure. But even that was not good enough. On 26 July at a colloquium on disarmament the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, getting back to the original Hayden formula albeit wiht a little more obscurity, when referring to the base said:
. . . a Labor government would insist that Australia be involved in-
That is a nice vague phrase-
any decisions, at the strategic level, regarding the type of signal that would be sent to United States submarines via North West Cape.

There is absolutely no point in being involved in any decisions unless there is a right of veto, otherwise what is involvement? So we are back to the right of veto, although it is in an obscure way. Of course, the veto would be rejected by the United States, so then a Labor government would wind the base down, according to the Hayden doctrine. Even a week ago-

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want it back?

—I am referring to the change of policy, not the policy to which the honourable member for St George referred. I am referring to today's policy. A week ago the same Deputy Leader of the Opposition plainly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A Labor government would ensure that . . . the Australian Government would be involved in the strategic aspects of the US communication stations work.

That is the right of veto, in obscure words, knowing that that veto will be rejected and then, in accordance with the Labor doctrine, the closing down of the base. This base is part of the most important alliance this country has and of the American alliance. The fundamental drive of the Labor Party or of a very significant element of it-it is not unanimous-is opposed to the United States alliance of which this Agreement is a very significant part. But members of the Opposition do not like to say this so bluntly. They prefer to dress it up. They turn to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to speak generally about the alliance. He has developed a technique of his own, and does it very well. The technique, which can be reduced to a rule, is this: 'Whenever the Labor Party criticises the United States of America, immediately follow it with a criticism of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, sometimes even a harsh one, giving the impression that you are dealing with equal impartiality with the two superpowers, implying that there is no difference between them. Then go on to hammer at the United States, whatever its policy-Japan, Vietnam, Latin America, wherever you like'. The result is not in so many words the socialist left posture. It is to adopt what we can call an anti-United States isolationism which will do the socialist left for the time being.

Honourable members should listen to the way the Deputy Leader of the Opposition does it. I refer to his general views on the American alliance because that is at the basis of this debate on the North West Cape Agreement. I refer to a speech he gave in Brisbane on 24 April. Many honourable members will be astounded. I was. He said:
The principal source of conflict between the US and the USSR is the control of strategic areas and of natural resources.
That is all the United States and the USSR are fighting about! He continued:
Australia has no immediate interest in this struggle . . .

It does not matter who controls the oil of the Middle East or who controls the world; Australia has no immediate interest in this struggle! It is not a struggle between democracy, or the free world, and the forces of totalitarianism or communism; it is a struggle between two superpowers for natural resources and strategic areas! That is the sort of picture he gives of the world conflict.

I refer now to a speech he gave at the Institute of International Affairs symposium in Sydney in May. I was also at that symposium. It was concerned with the role of Australia in Asia and the Pacific Basin and the power balance in the Pacific and Asia. In a quite lengthy speech the Deputy Leader of the Opposition managed to discuss the power situation in Asia and the Pacific without even mentioning the USSR or its expansion in the world-in Asia, in the Indian Ocean, in Afghanistan or in Vietnam. There was no mention of the USSR. That is his understanding of the power balance in Asia and the Pacific. If that seemed extraordinary, to balance it off he managed to make no mention of the United States or the Association of South East Asian Nations either. That is the sort of world he lives in. He deletes the United States from the world power balance, and then deletes the USSR too. That kind of crazy isolationism fits in with his leader's Institute of Public Affairs paper of November last year when he developed his Fortress Australia concept without an alliance-a dream, if members of the Opposition believe it, of a sort of Finlandisation of Australia. But they do not believe it; it is not a serious commitment. It is a cosmetic way of covering up the real thrust of the policy.

They are using the same technique in relation to the base. They do not say straight out: 'We will close it down'. That would seem unpalatable to some people; they might even lose some votes because of it. They do not say: 'We will close it down.' They say: 'We will insist on conditions and try to make them sound plausible'. Then, knowing that the United States cannot agree with those conditions, they say: 'If there is no agreement we will close the base down, but for goodness sake we have tried to be reasonable'. Exactly the same technique was used last year in the Sinai debate. They did not want to say straight out: ' We will not participate in the peacekeeping force in the Middle East'. That would seem to some people an unacceptable approach. So they said: 'We are prepared to participate in a peacekeeping force provided it is part of the United Nations force', knowing that the United Nations would not have such a force and that the Security Council was opposed to it. They said: 'We will be in a peacekeeping force under certain conditions', knowing that those conditions could not possibly happen. It is exactly the same with the North West Cape base. They say: 'Of course, America is welcome on certain conditions. We are very reasonable', knowing that those conditions are unacceptable. That proposition is absurd. It asks for what no other country asks. The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries do not have those sorts of rights and do not expect them. The United States certainly would not agree to them; nor would any other country with which America has this sort of alliance. The Labor Party asks the impossible and it knows that it is impossible. That is the basis for proceeding to close the base down. It was not always that way with the Labor Party. In 1963 , when the agreement was being negotiated, Senator McKenna, referring to this sort of demand, said:
The Labor Opposition has never asked that, with a nuclear missile hostile to Australia or to America on the way, we should be consulted as to what should be done. We have never put up such nonsense.

Of course, that is the sort of nonsense, in the changed situation 20 years later , that the Labor Party now demands. Twenty years ago it was different. In 1963 Senator Fitzgerald of the Labor Party said:
I welcome the establishment of the United States radio base. To be frank, I wish that we were ringed with such bases.

Of course, times have changed. Tonight the Labor Party with the sort of policy that I have outlined, with all its cosmetic changes, says that it is prepared to agree that this House confirms that this Agreement advances the security of Australia and of the Western alliance and that the present consultative arrangements between Australia and the United States are fully adequate to meet the needs of the Treaty partners. Members of the Opposition are prepared to support that. In a leadership riddled with cynicism, this is the most noisome cynicism of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As speakers on this side of the House have so rightly pointed out, this is a phoney debate over a got-up issue, in the form of a motion which in its entirety reflects the unconcern and incompetence with which it was drafted. I shall get on to one or two points about that later. It reflects the inexperience of the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) in the same way as his absence from this debate reflects his contempt for the House and for the issue. It is absolutely disgraceful, when the matter that he has determined as vital to the security interests of this country, that he should depart the House while the debate proceeds. There have been three speakers since the evening suspension and he has not been present to hear any of them. It is a pathetic performance which matches the pathetic performance he has put up since he has been Minister for Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: His pathetic performance has been exceeded only by the performances of one or two speakers on the Government side of the House. I am always depressed by the speeches of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) in this place when he discusses foreign policy matters. He is supposed to be the gun Government backbencher on foreign policy and defence issues. Whenever he appears in this House we hear mindless ranting; no more and no less than that. We had another performance of mindless ranting today. It is a shame that the Government cannot do a little better than that. It must be said that some of the other Government speakers put up a slightly better performance but they should have done something about their colleague a long time ago.

A couple of points have been raised about statements made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). We support this motion for several reasons. One of them happens to be that which was expounded by the honourable member for St George ( Mr Morrison). We are pleased to see that at last this Government has acknowledged that it approves of the amendments that we made to the Base Agreement between Australia and the United States of America in 1974. That is not what members opposite said in 1974-oh, no! To them then, Barnard going over to Schlesinger and putting upon him the things that Barnard put upon him then was an act tantamount to treason. But now, eight years later, we find, as is invariably the case, that the changes are part of conventional wisdom and so they now support the amendments to the agreement achieved by the Australian Labor Party. We are pleased to obtain the acknowledgement of the Government on this matter.

The second reason why we support the motion is that further down it refers to the question of deterrence. The fact of the matter is that the base is associated at present with a second strike capacity of the United States. A second strike capability is the essence of deterrents. The Leader of the Opposition has raised a couple of points on this matter which I think are important. He has said that the basic purpose of the agreement which, of course, supersedes anything within the framework of this motion is for the defence of the parties concerned. This is somewhat different from the notion of using this facility or anything else for first strike purposes. Even though there are shifts and changes in the doctrine of the United States-sometimes the doctrine develops in more dangerous ways than it does in others-it nevertheless remains essentially fundamental to that doctrine that it is founded on a conception of deterrence which does not envisage a first strike in either a tactical or strategic context. That is what the Leader of the Opposition was referring to. His views are firmly within the framework of the United States Naval Communications Station Agreement and firmly within the framework of this motion. But that is simply not comprehended by honourable members opposite, possibly because they do not get the sort of advice they ought to get from the people who are supposed to be their ace guns on the subject of foreign policy.

What has been engaged in here is not only just an attempt to tempt the Labor Party into a fatuous debate on the basis of a change that ought to have taken place four years ago in the arrangements associated with the base when a local council was set up; but also a concealment of the very considerable inadequacies in the performance of the Minister for Defence. Since he has been appointed Defence Minister he has wandered around this country and elsewhere like a one- man whoopee cushion sounding off in all directions on doctrines that he has utterly confused. One minute we hear from him that he is in favour of forward defence; the next minute we hear from him that he is in favour of defence self reliance; and the next minute we hear from him that he wants to put the FA18- that extremely expensive, extremely sensitive piece of military equipment-in the middle of Malaysia where it will rot in the tropics in the space of six months. This military genius now presides over our defence policies. One reflection of his whoopee-ness is to be seen in certain parts of this motion. I refer to paragraph (5). Some of the other honourable members on the other side of the House might like to extrapolate on it. Alternatively, when the Minister can grace this occasion again with his presence, he might, in winding up the debate, have a little to say on this topic himself. Paragraph (5) states:
Asserts that no impediment should be placed by either party on access to the facilities of the base in relation to the use of the base by the other party . . .

That could be interpreted in a couple of ways. One of the ways in which that part of this shoddy piece of drafting, could be interpreted is that permission should be granted by both parties to have access to each other's communication rooms. One reasonable interpretation of this sloppy and hurried piece of drafting by a sloppy and hurried Minister, who has just returned to the chamber, is that we have now unilaterally renegotiated the agreement to give ourselves access to the United States communications facility. I suspect that this is probably not what has happened, but that there is a degree of confusion in the motion. If it is to be renegotiated, if the Minister wishes to proceed with that that is fair enough. I hope he is a little careful about giving the United States the same degree of access to our communications room. The facility is, after all, on our territory. I do not think we on this side of the House would necessarily want a situation where the United States would intervene in communications with our submarines. Perhaps we could hear a little more about that later from this master draftsman of defence and foreign policy motions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the veto?
—It happens to be the case-
—Do you support your leader's veto?

—I have already explained our leader's policy to the House. If the honourable member listens a little longer, he might learn one of two other things about the facility. I wish now to look at exactly what purpose the communications station serves. It does serve a changing function. When the Labor Party renegotiated this Treaty-a renegotiation which at last Government members are catching up with, we welcome them to the side of those who are attempting to establish a sensible and mature relationship with our principal ally-the North West Cape facility was more essential to American submarine communications systems than it is now. All public documents associated with the deployment by the United States of the trident submarine state the intention that the submarines should be deployed principally close to the United States continent where the United States can be absolutely certain that the submarines can be protected from any developments in the Soviet anti-submarine warfare capability. When that happens the submarines' principal means of communications will be from the equivalent station to the North West Cape in Washington State. The purpose of the North West Cape, at least in terms of communications with ballistic missile submarines, will be largely redundant. In case this is not sufficient, the United States has also added to its capabilities for communications with submarines-in the experimental stage at least-an extra low frequency system which will be located entirely in the United States and which would subsume some of the functions of VLF systems.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing that the United States has done is to have in operation already a VLF capability which is airborne and invulnerable to a Soviet attack. In relation to the North West Cape facility-this causes some comfort to honourable members on this side of the House-the value and the centrality of it to the United States system of strategic deterrence is beginning to decline and will continue to decline. In those circumstances, of course, the likelihood that it will be a nuclear target in a general war also will be reduced. If honourable members on the other side of the House knew a darn thing about this subject, they would at least be able to appear in this House and debate it sensibly. Instead, we have heard the absolutely nonsensical argie-bargie which comes particularly from people like the honourable member for Higgins. He offers no help to our understanding of these considerably complex matters.

One of the things that we have constantly stressed in association with all the facilities in Australia, including this one, and is one of the reasons why we support their continued presence in Australia-it is not the only reason; we also acknowledge the defensive purpose associated with them-is that they are an entree to United States decision-making procedures. No thanks are due to members of the Government for our having that entree. That is a result of the negotiations of the previous government when it moved the process of consultation out of the context of the hurrah club that is the ANZUS Ministers council meetings and shifted it to the more solid basis of constant communications between civil servants at a middle level. That gave us not only more serious information on United States strategic policy but also a capability to intervene in discussions of United States strategic policy-a very welcome change. I am glad to see Government members acknowledging it at last in this motion, but I am not sure that they fully understood, when they put this motion forward, that that is in fact, what they are acknowledging. I hope this debate has been something of an education for them not only in political tactics but also in the issue itself. If they learn nothing else from that, the remaining weeks of this Parliament, will be well spent by those about to join the ranks of the unemployed.

The point about that access is that it gives us a chance to say some important things to the United States on matters of strategic policy which affect the future stability of this world. Fortunately when members of the Government move outside this House and outside the context of political debate in this House and go overseas they start to take the high road. On some matters on which they take the high road I commend them. A couple of them have taken the high road on matters of arms control arrangements. Recently, for example, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) put up a fine defence of a nuclear test ban treaty in the face of the opposition of our principal ally. In this instance the nuclear test ban treaty involved an agreement over whether all powers, particularly the United States and the Soviet Union, should abolish underground nuclear testing. The United States and the Soviet Union have argued that verification is not possible for such an agreement. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Department of Foreign Affairs have argued that scientific verification is possible because there is established in Australia a facility that does monitor tests. It is manned by Australian scientists. The Government did offer the good offices of those scientists to ensure that such a treaty could be verified. It happens to be a notable exception to the way in which the Government has generally treated its entree.

One thing that must be crystal clear from our association with the United States and the question of whether we wish to see stable nuclear deterrence is that we have a vested interest now in a way which we never had before in the sanity of the two super-powers-not just the one, the two of them. We have a vested interest in the sanity of the Soviet Union and we have a vested interest in the sanity of the United States. When we debate these matters in this House we ought to be able to debate them with the seriousness that that subject entails. It is a serious subject because we have influence. It is an influence that ought to be used for the prevention of nuclear war and the prevention of super-power tensions which may produce accidents which would result in a nuclear war. We never get that seriousness from the Government members because whenever election time comes around all they want to do is to stress that bipartisanship does not exist where it in fact exists in the hope, for electoral purposes, of breaking it down. They are contemptible. The Minister is contemptible in the way in which he has brought this motion into the House. It is a disgraceful motion serving disgraceful purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite what the Opposition may say in this chamber this evening, the fact of the matter is, and it is demonstrable, that the Australian Labor Party is in total disarray over the question of the ANZUS Treaty and Australia's defence arrangements. There are as many views in the Australian Labor Party as there are individuals. I just want to reiterate some of the points of this motion. I am speaking tonight in favour of it. What this motion says and what the ALP, through the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen), said earlier in the debate it was in favour of is that the United States Naval Communication Station Agreement is an important element in the bilateral relationship between Australia and the United States, contributing to the fulfilment of our obligations under the security treaty. It also confirms that the agreement advances the security of Australia and of the Western alliance. It asserts that there should be no impediment placed on the use and operation of the base to meet the stated needs-stated needs, not renegotiated needs-and requirements of the treaty partners. It agrees that the present consultative arrangements be preserved and that those arrangements are fully adequate. That is what the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) has moved by way of a motion in this Parliament tonight. It is what we on the Government side are supporting and it is what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition says the Labor Party supports. It is demonstrable, it is on the record, that that is not what the Labor Party supports. What Opposition members are doing in the House tonight is merely bringing forward a range of pious objections to the Government's motion which have no basis and are not supportable in fact. I want to mention a few of the matters that have been raised. In July of this year the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said of ANZUS:

SPEECH.PARA: Let's make it absolutely clear that ANZUS is not a pact, but a promise to consult in the case of an attack on any of the three signatories.
If that is not an attempt by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to downgrade the importance of ANZUS, I do not know what is. In June of 1982 the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) said:

The Labor Party will ensure that the presence of these United States facilities in Australia does not derogate from Australia's sovereignty, and that Australia is not involved in hostilities without Australian consent.
He also stated:
There will be no home porting of foreign warships in Australia, no storage of nuclear weapons on Australian territory, nor the launching of military operations involving nuclear weapons.
In July of this year the Deputy Leader of the Opposition stated:
The entire southern hemisphere should be declared a nuclear free zone.

If that is not an attempt to undermine the ANZUS Treaty, if that is not an attempt on the part of the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party to redefine in Australian terms what they think the treaty means, I do not know what is. The fact of the matter is that they do not see the ANZUS Treaty, the United States bases and the visits of allied ships to Australia in the same light as the Government. Yet tonight they are trying to tell us that they do not disagree with this motion. The statement on these matters of the Labor Party over the last year or two have been of great concern to Australians. Not only have they been of great concern to Australians but also they have been of concern to the United States. It is most unusual to find the United States Department of State making statements in relation to the pronouncement of shadow Ministers and alternative Government leaders in Australia. It is worth quoting for the record that the United States Department of State responded to the ALP's various statements, threatening ANZUS, with a reminder of how the United States viewed the defence treaty. The United States Department of State stated:
Quite apart from the present dispute, it should be clear that access to allied ports and airfield for United States ships and aircraft is critical to our efforts to maintain a strategic deterrence.
It would be difficult, if not impossible, for the United States to carry out its responsibilities to assist effectively in the defence of its allies, if it is denied the use of their ports.
The United States Government's reaction in relation to the matter is very clear. Specifically relating to the North West Cape, Mr Hayden, in April 1981, said:
We find the present arrangements covering North West Cape unsatisfactory.
The honourable member for Kingsford-Smith did not seek to move any amendment to the motion moved tonight by the Minister for Defence. That motion states:

. . . the present consultative arrangements between Australia and the United States relating to the Joint operations of North West Cape be preserved and recognises that those arrangements are fully adequate to meet the needs of the Treaty partners.
The honourable member said that the Opposition will support this resolution. The Leader of the Opposition said:

We find the present arrangements covering North West Cape unsatisfactory. We would seek to renegotiate the North West Cape agreement to provide first, that Australia's consent is mandatory for all orders to initiate military action which flows from the station and second, that we are given firm and convincing assurances that the station will not be used to send orders for first strike nuclear attack or to initiate a limited strike. If the United States would not accept these reasonable provisions, designed to protect our national sovereignty , then we would request them to wind down the operations of North West Cape as rapidly as possible.

I do not see that what the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition are saying about North West Cape and what the Government is saying about North West Cape are the same thing. There is not a bipartisan attitude on the part of the Government parties and the Opposition party on the question of North West Cape. Yet the Opposition is picking one paragraph out of the motion which is before the House and trying to make fun of that and is ignoring the other five articles of the motion which are specifically designed to state that this House is confirming ANZUS, the Australian-United States defence relationship, the importance of the North West Cape facility and the satisfactory nature of the relationships that exist over the management of that base.

It is hypocritical for members of the Labor Party to say that they support the motion and then to proceed with a debate of the nature that has emanated from that side of the House this evening, in the face of the statements, which are on the record, by various spokesmen for the Labor Party over the last couple of years. It is also important to note that, despite what the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition might say, there is total dissarray and confusion on these matters, as I said at the outset, within the Australian Labor Party and the Labor movement. I want to state a few of the facts. The present platform of the Victorian Labor Party Conference, one of the constituent parts of this great alternative government, contains this statement:
Co-operation with the people of the United States and New Zealand within the context of the Australian New Zealand United States (ANZUS) Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—I will tell honourable members about that because the ALP Conference in April passed a motion to send to the Federal Conference. The effect of that motion was to delete what I read out and to replace it with the following:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . pursue an independent and non-aligned foreign policy and develop reliable lines of communication with all great powers, thereby enabling Australia to achieve a closer association with non-aligned movement and to engage in effective collective action for the establishment of regional zones of peace and neutrality, notably in the Indian Ocean, Southeast Asia and the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that adopted?

—No, it was not passed. It was passed at the Victorian Conference and was put up at the Federal Council but it was defeated. The point I am making is that there is no unanimity even in the Labor Party. Its constituent parts, the socialist Left, the centre unity, the conservative Right and the moderates all have a different view of what the foreign policy ought to be. The Leader of the Labor Party, particularly, the captive of the socialist Left, has no idea of what he stands for and capitulates on every occasion. In May the Premier of Victoria wrote to the Prime Minister in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to give you early notice of my Government's policy that it will not permit visits of nuclear powered or nuclear armed vessels to Victorian ports .
This policy, which was part of the platform on which my Government was elected, will apply without qualification.

The Prime Minister reacted in the way honourable members would imagine. For a couple of weeks there were at least four discernible positions on the part of the Australian Labor Party in relation to this very important aspect of our defence alliance with the United States. I have quoted the view of the Victorian Premier. The New South Wales Premier, Mr Wran, banned visits by nuclear powered ships but allowed stops by conventionally powered vessels without insisting on knowing whether they were carrying nuclear--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There happens to be some legislation before this Parliament on the visit of nuclear powered ships. We are not discussing that legislation now. I suggest that the honourable member keep his intervention until the appropriate time, pursuant to the parliamentary Standing Orders.
—I think the honourable gentleman has so far been making reference to that legislation rather than debating it. I invite him to continue.

—Mr Wran's attitude was different again. The Leader of the Opposition opposed visits by nuclear powered ships but was relaxed about nuclear powered vessels which do not carry nuclear weapons. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that a Labor government would allow visits by nuclear armed ships, provided they were simply refuelling and not conducting some staging exercise. So there were four discernible views. As I understand it, there have been some more capitulations since then. I am not totally sure of the separate views within the Labor Party. The only thing I am certain about is that there are so many views within the Labor Party and so many statements on the record which conflict with the intent of the motion before the House that it is not possible for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to say that the Labor Party supports it. He stated that he supports the change of Exmouth in relation to the local commissioner and local government, et cetera. But the fact is that the Labor Party is about to go on record. I am very happy about that except that I think it ought to be honest and state what it is doing. It is not doing that now, and that is what the debate is about.

SPEECH.PARA: Having overcome for the moment the horrible internal conflict and schisms over the nuclear ships issue-the Opposition thought it had the problem sorted out-the USS Goldsborough came to Australia. What happened was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the honourable member's remarks are getting close to the legislation that is before the House.
—I will not pursue that matter. I was about to refer to Mrs Coxsedge's position which re-opened--
—Is this relevant?

—No. It is a very sensitive aspect of the United States-Australian alliance and Australia's security umbrella, and it is all part of the same umbrella of which the Harold E. Holt base is also a part. The Labor Party has no idea where it stands on these issues. Everybody in the Labor Party and every faction have separately identifiable points of view. It is a joke for the Labor Party to try to convince this House and the people of Australia that it supports the motion which has been moved tonight in this place by the Minister for Defence. I think it is of vital importance that we understand what the motion says and what the Labor Party says it will support. The United States naval communications station is an important element in the bilateral relationship and contributes to the fulfilment of our obligations under the security treaty. The Agreement advances the security of Australia and the Western alliance. The motion also states that no impediment should be placed on the use and operation of the base and that the present consultative arrangements between Australia and the United States relating to the joint operations of the North West Cape will be preserved. It also recognises that those arrangements are fully adequate to meet the needs of the treaty partners. If the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith do not agree with that they had better stand up and say so. By supporting the motion that is what honourable members are agreeing with. We are very pleased to see that they agree with it, as long as that is what they mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) I would like to say a few things about the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party, like all other political parties, thrives on healthy debate and at its conferences it deals with those issues that are the important issues of the day. The Labor Party is the party of Australian nationalism. It is the party that has always stood for a strong, free democratic Australia. It has always stood for the defence of Australia. It was a Labor government that introduced national service in the Fisher Government days. It was a Labor government that established the Royal Australian Navy in the days of the Fisher Government. It was a Labor Government that was elected to office to prosecute the First World War. It was a Labor government that took office in October 1941 during the Second World War when the coalition parties collapsed. Labor was called to take over the government of this country for the greatest war effort that Australia has ever mounted. So the Labor Party has no cause to run away from any of these issues affecting the defence of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: To support what I have said I remind honourable members that it was a Labor government at the end of the Second War War that passed the Statute of Westminster Adoption Act, the Act that brought into effect in Australia the Statute of Westminster which was agreed to in 1931 by what was then called an imperial conference.

Labor Party members are always having discussions about the needs of Australian nationalism in terms of serving our objective to achieve a strong, free, democratic Australia. But there are some consistent elements in the Labor Party policy. I have been curiously interested tonight by numbers of honourable members on the other side because of the way they have talked about debates about the Labor Party and its attitude towards ANZUS and the Australian-American alliance. There are not too many more consistent areas of the Labor Party platform that have stood for the order of 30 or 40 years than those decisions made by the national conference of the Labor Party and which reflect on the Australian-American alliance.

I find it very sad that something as important to this nation as the ANZUS treaty should be the subject of a petty partisan debate tonight. In terms of the agreement, apart from the pious things with which we all agree, the substance of the motion we are debating tonight is to agree to remove from the Agreement Article 6 which provides for the appointment of a civil commissioner at Exmouth to have such functions as both governments vest in him and to represent them in such maters as they determine. I have found to my amazement that this gentleman had his authority removed from him four years ago. That must be some indication of the importance which this Government attaches to keeping this very important agreement with the United States up to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago was that?

—I am told that this gentleman has been removed from office for four years. I make the point that the ANZUS treaty is the only treaty mentioned in the ALP policy document. The honourable member for Hume has read out that statement which, very briefly, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Labor will-
Co-operate with the people of the United States and New Zealand within the context of the Australian New Zealand United States (ANZUS) Treaty.

What has that meant in practice? It has been a consistent attitude for 40 years. Honourable members of this House will recall that it was John Curtin who, in February 1942 shortly after the Japanese had invaded Pearl Harbour and the United States had come into the war, appealed to the United States to join with Australia and help Australia in this nation's hour of need. So the Australian- American alliance was brought into being at the request of a Labor Prime Minister and a Labor Government. The attitude of the Labor Party has been consistent ever since. I could quote a number of people. I could quite easily quote from Sir Alan Watt or Sir Paul Hasluck if I had sufficient time. However I will quote from Mr Alan Renouf's book The Frightened Country in which, on page 93, he states:

The idea of a Pacific security agreement was first floated by the Lyons conservative government in 1937 without result. It was revived by the 1943 Labour Government without specific proposals. In 1945 Evatt tried to negotiate a pact with the United States as a guarantee against Japanese aggression but the United States was unenthusiastic. In 1947 Evatt, in the context of talk about an early Japanese peace treaty, proposed to the United States a Pacific Regional Security Commission to supervise the implementation of the peace treaty and other aspects of security in the Pacific. The proposal found no favour. Evatt revived the idea of a Pacific security arrangement in 1949, this time including Asian countries, but again unsuccessfully.

We all know that it was only at the time when a peace treaty was being negotiated with Japan the so-called soft peace treaty, as it was described as in those days-that the United States was prepared to enter into treaty arrangements with the Philippines, that was the PHILUS pact, and with Australia and New Zealand, and that was the ANZUS pact. The man who did the negotiation at that time, of course, was Sir Percy Spender, the distinguished first Minister for External Affairs in the Menzies Government. At the time that Curtin appealed to the United States to establish the Australian-American alliance members on the other side of the Parliament-on the coalition side; that is, the United Australia Party-Country Party side-criticised that appeal to the United States. In those days patriotism was judged by the British connection. It is only in more recent years that by honourable members opposite it has been judged by the American connection.

One could go ad nauseam, I suppose, through all of the events since then but I think it is useful to reflect on the state of the United States-Australian alliance and indeed the agreement for the North West Cape radio station as it emerged from the days of the Whitlam Government. The agreement we are debating tonight was negotiated by the Whitlam Government. This radio station and its operations survived three years of the previous Labor Government and it will survive six or nine years of the Hayden Labor government in the future. The record is there. The runs are on the score board. Mr Renouf admits that there were difficulties with the United States in the early days. Honourable members will recall that we had been involved in the Vietnam war and we had a distinctively different China policy from that of the United States. It was only in later days that the initiatives which Mr Whitlam and other people had taken were followed up by statesmen from the United States, not the least of whom were Mr Kissinger and, of course, President Nixon. On page 469 of his book Mr Renouf states:

However, as time passed, the United States got to know Whitlam and his governments and their policies better and then became more understanding, tolerant and less liable to misapprehension. The Whitlam Governments had by that time proven that they were not anti-American and had no intention of dissolving the long-standing United States alliance. When Whitlam was dismissed, Australian -American relations were as good as they had ever been.

I will quote Mr Marshall Green. The Whitlam Government was very grateful indeed that at a time of sensitive issues such as differences in policy about Vietnam and China the United States appointed a very distinguished career diplomat to this country in the person of Mr Marshall Green.

TALK.START.PARA: —A real professional.

—That is right. I will quote from a paper by Neville Meaney in the Australia in World Affairs 1971-1975 in which he mentioned an address by Mr Green in March 1975. Honourable members will recall that Australia in World Affairs is a well established standard work on Australian foreign policy. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Marshall Green towards the end of his term in office gave an international audience in New York a brief precis and friendly appraisal of these changes. He affirmed that Australian-American relations had been undergoing 'a maturation process'. Although the American ties were perhaps not as close as they had been with the previous Australian governments, nevertheless, the relationship was 'in many ways . . . healthier than it was before'. Australia was 'determined to do its own thing', he said. 'They don't want to be in lock-step with American policy'. He described the sycophantic slogans of preceding governments, such as 'All the way with L.B.J.', as a 'downright embarrassment'. Things had altered irretrievably. There was no way back. 'Now all the parties-Labor, Liberal and Country Party-are in favour of a nationalistic policy for Australia. We understand and agree with it.

This debate tonight has resulted from legislation introduced yesterday for the purpose of using the question of the Australian American alliance as an issue for a possible early election. We all remember 1951 when the Menzies Government had a double dissolution on the banking issue and fought the election on communism. Very clearly the Government is not prepared to fight any election in the short term on its economic policies. It is not prepared to fight any election on the state of the economy. It certainly would not be prepared to fight an election on the basis of the rubbery Budget it brought down earlier this week. Therefore Government members are shopping around for an issue. They are going back to the same issue that they used so successfully in 1966 at the time of the Vietnam war. They suggested then that under an Australian Labor Government the Australian-American alliance and the ANZUS treaty would be imperilled. I am sorry that I have to read so much history into the Hansard tonight but I believe that the record shows that any or those suggestions are totally untrue.

The Australian-American alliance emerged at the end of the Whitlam Government- we heard the distinguished former Minister and the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) talking about his personal experiences tonight-stronger than it had ever been before because it was operating on the basis of a new frankness, a greater degree of accountability and consultations and, indeed, in terms of the radio station, a much more practical agreement than had ever been negotiated before. It is very significant that this Government has not sought to change a single paragraph in the agreement negotiated by the Whitlam Government excepting that paragraph dealing with the change in the responsibility of the local authority. I regret that honourable members on the other side have seen fit to introduce many of the elements into this debate tonight. I believe that there is certainly common ground on both sides of this Parliament in support of the American alliance. It is sad indeed that for petty, party political objectives the United States and its representatives in this country will be able to read the Hansard of tonight's debate and see how many trivialities have been spelt out. I say only that when the Labor Government takes office-as it inevitably will after an election is held-we look forward to a firm, friendly and frank relationship with the United States such as we had between 1942 and 1949, between 1972 and 1975 and which we will have again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think an honourable member will claim that the motion before us will cause a lot of disagreement-in fact it has not because the Opposition has agreed with it. But I think it gives us all an opportunity to explore something of the Australian-United States relationship. It is a great mystery to me why the Australian Labor Party reacts so spontaneously to any discussion of this relationship. I have listened carefully tonight and have noted throughout the debate that the speakers on the Opposition side have all been from the conservative right wing element. The Labor Party is not game to put on the left wingers. I think that is very sensible. I have listened carefully to what they had to say and a lot of it made a great deal of sense. I learnt from the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison), who was very much involved in negotiating some of these agreements, and others the background to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think there is any great disagreement between what has been said tonight on this side of the House and what has been said on the other side of the House. The disagreement would arise if the Labor Party let loose some of its more rabid socialist left members. That is where the schisms would appear. It is the left wing of the Labor Party which causes such tremors with our American allies, with those on this side of the House and will those on the right wing of the Australian Labor Party. They are the people who want to keep our foreign policy in some sort of cacoon, in darkness. They are the ones who react nervously and agressively every time there is mention of B52s and every time we mention we are going to allow some allied ships, which may or may not be carrying nuclear arms, into this country's ports. The left wingers are the ones who react. They are the people who reacted when the going got tough in Vietnam. The left wing of the ALP does not understand the value of strength and friendship, whether during war or peace. Their policy is just to drag everyone down to some mediocre level.

The United States has been a friend of ours for a long time. Many of us would remember quite clearly what it was like in the years 1942 to 1945. There are a hell of a lot of us who can imagine what it might have been like had the Americans not come during those dark years. Since World War II we have had the ANZUS alliance. It has stood the test of time. It is still the cornerstone of our foreign policy. We want American assistance and the Americans want ours. If we are to get that assistance we have to offer some facilities in this country. We have to offer port and communication facilities. It is very disappointing to me and, I am sure, to many honourable members on the other side to see the Premier of Victoria trying to make petty political points out of what is firstly a Commonwealth issue and, secondly, what is fundamental to the defence of this country. This, thank God, was acknowledged by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and to their great credit by honourable members such as the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) who have the courage to visit allied ships when they are in Sydney to demonstrate that not the entire ALP wants to draw us into some mediocrity. I will dwell, while talking about the Australia-America relationship, on Vietnam. It is quite common for the left wing elements of the ALP to keep blaming America for dragging Australia into Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not exactly our finest hour.

—That is not the case at all. We went to Vietnam because we elected to do so and because at the time it was in our own interests to do so. We went because we decided to go and not because any threats were placed upon Australia. In those days we were following, rightly or wrongly, a policy of forward defence . We had been involved in Malaysia and I did not hear any great cries from the ALP then or when we were involved in Borneo. What happened when we went into Vietnam? Because it was a different ally-it is not a traditional ally-the left wing members of the ALP decided that it was not in our interests and they were quite wrong. No one on both sides of this House will ever forget the sight of Dr Jim Cairns entertaining a delegation from North Vietnam while Australian soldiers were still serving in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the future of this alliance. Whether honourable members like it or not we are a country with a small population. We need allies and our allies need us in this part of the world. If we are going to have a friendship or an alliance, there has to be some give and take. The first responsibility of any government is to the defence of its own territories. The second responsibility- one which I regret we have neglected in recent years-is to look after our neighbours and friends. We need some capacity in this area. The distance from one side of Australia to the other is something like 3,000 miles. Taking that as a yardstick, within 3,000 miles of Australia's shores there are something like 30 countries or territories all of which in some way or another, look to Australia for assistance and help in times of trouble. So, if we as a small country are to provide that friendship and that capacity to help we need allies ourselves to assist us when the going gets tough.

I think it can be said that the fortress Australia attitude which has prevailed since we pulled out of Vietnam is changing. I very much hope that it is. It has been said quite often that we have to look after ourselves. There are certain things we can do for ourselves but there are certain things we cannot and when that happens that is the time when we will need our powerful friends and allies. The ANZUS Treaty is not the final solution, but it stood us well in the past and I hope it will stand us well in the future until we are big and strong enough to undertake all of our own defence capabilities. It is very sad that the Government had to bring into this House the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill which will be debated next week. It should not be necessary. It is necessary only because the left wing of the ALP has cast doubt on that whole relationship. In fact, one man has done that or started it on his own.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?

—I refer to the Premier of Victoria. The Premier of New South Wales has managed to keep it very quiet but has had the same policies for years. How can we expect to go into any alliance if we do not offer our allies port or communications facilities, run joint exercises with them, or offer them maintenance facilities and facilities for re-supplying? The United States of America has chosen to arm its ships with nuclear weapons and to power them with nuclear engines. We have not. That is not our policy. We do not have nuclear power. But who are we to tell the United States how it should power its ships and what weapons those ships should carry? If the United States chooses to do something that honourable members opposite may not agree with, are we to tell the United States to take its ships elsewhere? What fine friends we would be!

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP keeps harping on the subject that this Government has put us in the position of being obsequious allies. Let us look at the agreement on the North West Cape. The agreement states:
First, that the agreement and the obligations it creates should respect the sovereignty of each.
Secondly, that the control of the station should rest with the United States.
Thirdly, that when desired by either, there should be consultation. . .
Fourthly, that the Australian armed forces should have the use of the communication services. . .
Fifthly, that the Australian Government should not seek to make a revenue profit out of the American establishment. . .
Sixthly, that in the establishment, operation and maintenance of the station, the maximum practicable use of Australian resources should be made.
Seventhly, that, without submitting to the jurisdiction of Australian courts, or compromising its sovereignty, the United States would conform to Australian law and its personnel would observe it.
It does not seem to me that anything in that agreement takes away the respect and dignity of this country.
I turn to a speech made by the Leader of the Opposition in May 1981. Having visited the North West Cape, he said:
The inescapable fact remains that Australia has a sovereign right to be in ultimate control of affairs on her own territory.
That is fair enough. But he goes on to say:
We would seek to re-negotiate the North West Cape agreement to provide, firstly , that Australia's consent is mandatory for all orders to initiate military action which flow from the station.

I do not think anybody in his right mind could say to an ally: 'We will determine what your policies will be and we will determine whether you will be allowed to pursue those policies'. I can understand that a lot of that reservation is caused by the fear of nuclear war; but, again, it is a matter of balance. Many of us are concerned about nuclear war. I say again that it is the United States and other countries that have chosen to arm themselves with nuclear arms. We do not have nuclear weaponry. But who are we as allies to say: 'You will not have those weapons and that is the end of it? It would be a hopeless sort of alliance. A two-way street is involved in these alliances. I hope that what I have said tonight might have outlined the facts to some of the more rabid members of this Parliament who do not see the other side of this debate. Time and time again in this Parliament there have been calls for a partisan approach to defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bipartisan.
—I mean bipartisan.
—There is a difference.

—The honourable member is right. It is very disappointing when we see not a bipartisan approach but a partisan approach taken by the left wing of the ALP. That is why there have been no ALP left wing speakers tonight. That would blow apart that front of solidarity that honourable members opposite are desperately trying to put up on this issue. Nothing would blow it apart more than letting some of those ALP left wing members speak tonight. I very much hope that the Opposition keeps them where they are tonight, and that is very much in the back room.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The despicable tactic involved in this motion is revealed by the total despair of the members of the Government that we in the Opposition are supporting this motion. Let us get clear what this motion is not about. The motion is not about the North West Cape agreement. It is not even, as in part it purports to be, about the momentous issue of dispensing with a civil commissioner at Exmouth, an earth shattering event which was achieved four years ago without recourse to the services of this House by the election of a local council in 1978.

SPEECH.PARA: The only way in which this motion remotely has anything to do with defence is that it is a blatant, miserable attempt to create a trigger for the pathetic desire of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for a premature, diversionary election-an election which will divert the attention of this country from the total failure of this Government to manage the economic affairs of this country. That is a pathetic failure which, in the 48 hours since the delivery of the Budget in this House, is already crumbling further as the deceitful, lying figures contained in the papers attached to the Budget have been revealed to be in both Houses of this Parliament.

The Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair), in introducing this motion, sought to put this matter in an historical setting by going back to Menzies' statement in this House 20 years ago. At the outset of this contribution I give the members of this coalition Government full marks for one thing in this area of defence and foreign policy: They get 100 per cent for total consistency. But it is a consistency of which they should be ashamed and this country terrified. It is a consistency which is characterised in two ways: Firstly, when the chips have been down in terms of the defence of this country they have been found wanting and have been rejected and, secondly, they have always been despicably prepared to use defence and foreign policy not as the intrinsically important issues which they are but with an astounding and absolute disregard for the truth as a plaything of politics, as something to divide the Australian community, and as an attempt to present the Australian Labor Party as unconcerned with or, even worse, opposed to protecting the security of Australia. In these terms, let us put this issue into its true historical perspective.

As one of my colleagues has already said, in the time of the First World War it was a Labor government that was called upon for the defence of this country. Let us come to more recent times. In the period just before the outbreak of the second World War a prominent leader of the conservatives of this country was praising Adolf Hitler; he was supporting the appeasement of Hitler that was taking place at that time. Indeed, that same gentleman, as documents which have recently come to light have shown, was criticising Winston Churchill for the attempts that Winston Churchill was making in the latter days of the 1930s to prepare Great Britain for the challenge which inevitably came. So inadequate were that man and his supporters, of whom Government members are the successors, to meet the defence of this country in the greatest challenge to it that has occurred that on 7 October 1941 two independents crossed the floor of this House to take away from the conservatives the responsibility for the defence of this country. That responsibility was given into the hands of the Australian Labor Party under the leadership of the greatest Prime Minister this country has ever seen-John Curtin. That is what happened when the chips were down and defence mattered. The Australian Labor Party met that challenge in war and went on in peace to establish the basis for the economic expansion of this country into the future.

Let us establish the second characteristic of the way in which Government members have been prepared in peacetime to use defence and foreign policy-not in terms of analysing and dealing with them in regard to the intrinsic importance of those issues but, as I said, as a plaything of politics, and attempt miserably to divide Australia. let us go into some of the issues. Vietnam has been talked about. But let us go back three years before Vietnam. Let us go back to 1963, to an election which I remember as the candidate for the seat of Corio at that time. What device was used then in terms of using defence and foreign policy issues in this country? What did Government members do then? They tried to paint the Indonesians as the threat to this country. What did they do? They sent a dying Mr Townley to Washington to negotiate the F111 agreement. That was not enough. The Government bought the B57s and had them flying over the skies of Australia in an attempt to persuade the people of Australia to accept that they were about to be invaded by the Indonesians. The Government was successful. It knew that what it was doing was totally untrue. It knew that there was not a scintilla of evidence to sustain that charade that it played upon the people of Australia, but it was successful. The Government was not decent enough to understand that one should not do those things because it repeated them in 1966.

Government members have had the temerity to raise the subject of Vietnam tonight. Let us talk about Vietnam. How did we get into Vietnam? We got into Vietnam on the basis of a phoney, non-existent letter which purported to request Australia to go into Vietnam. We knew at the time that this was not right. Events have revealed that it was not right. But that did not worry the Government. On the basis of a phoney, non-existent letter the Government sent young Australians to die in Vietnam. It had no compunction about it. Government members talk about Jim Cairns talking at the time to representatives of Vietnam. What was the Government doing at that time? At the very time that Government members were justifying the deaths of hundreds of young Australians in Vietnam on the basis that atheistic, yellow, communistic China was about to thrust down towards Australia and had to be fought this conservative Government was allowing the export of materials from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to China, material which inevitably ended up in the war machine in Vietnam for use against Australians who were fighting and dying in Vietnam. That shows the depth and the despicable nature of the hypocrisy in which the Government engaged at that time.

The Australian Labor Party said at that time that this was wrong, that it was based upon a lie. We had the courage to stand up and say that. We paid a heavy penalty in 1966 for it. But we stuck to our principle. As has always been the case with the position of the Australian Labor Party on issues of defence and foreign policy, the events proved the Australian Labor Party right. It took the election of the Labor Government in 1972 to end that infamous participation in Vietnam by Australians which had been initiated on the basis of a lie and which had been sustained on the basis of economic as well as political hypocrisy. Those are the facts.

Let us move from that time in regard to all those issues in respect of which I have put the facts-not opinions-to the present situation. We of the Australian Labor Party make no apology for the fact that we regard our relations with the United States as important. After all, as one of my colleagues has pointed out, it was in the time of war in 1941, after the electorate threw out the Government and put us in office, that we in the Australian Labor Party in government forged the most effective alliance and relationship between the United States and Australia that has ever existed between any two countries in the history of Australia.

It was my party in government which did that against the snide opposition and sneers of the conservatives who could look no further than to Mother England and who said that any suggestion that we should break down those ties and think about a relationship with the United States which would in any way replace that would be regarded almost as an act of treason. The strength of the relationship between Australia and the United States which is still a reality and which is important to the Australian Labor Party was in fact forged by the Australian Labor Party in government. Those are the facts.

Why is it that in August of 1982 we are being brought to the ridiculous situation where it is being put to us that there should be some surprise about the Australian Labor Party's supporting this motion? As my friend the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) has pointed out, why in the name of everything that begins to make sense should we not support a motion which talks about confirming the agreement of 1963 as amended? It was amended, as has been pointed out, in 1974 in the negotiations which took place between the Labor Government's Defence Minister, Lance Barnard, and the United States Defence Secretary, Schlesinger. What was done in those negotiations? What was achieved in those amendments. Let me refer to two of the significant achievements that had to wait until the Australian Labor Party was in government. This agreement had been in place since 1962 but it took until we got into government to achieve these things.

Let me refer to just two of them. One of the things which were done by us, which Government members had not been able to do and which they have been satisfied with leaving in abeyance since 1962, was the giving for the first time to Australian submarines access to VLF communications. That is what we achieved. That was our amendment. The Government could not do it. It asks in surprise why we support this motion. It was our amendment of the Treaty which achieved that. I ask Government members to notice the achievement in the 1974 amendment by the Australian Labor Party in government. The Canberra Times of 1 January 1974 stated:

The United States agreed to 'extend and strengthen bilateral consultations to ensure that the Australian Government would have full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to the station and their significance for Australian national interests.'

That is what we negotiated. It had been entirely absent in the agreement negotiated in 1963. It was in regard to those fundamental issues of importance to the sovereignty and integrity of this country that the agreement of 1963 was amended by the Labor Government. Government members wonder why we have no difficulty in coming into the House and supporting a motion which asks us to agree with what we achieved in our amendment which vastly filled out in terms of the responsibility, sovereignty and respect of this country what the Government had not been able or more importantly had not wanted to achieve in 1963.

As I said, this debate initiated by the Government is a miserable tactic. It is a degrading episode of which this Government should be, as the people of Australia will be, thoroughly ashamed and disgusted. The Prime Minister desperately wants to have an early election. He knows that he cannot possibly go to the people of this country and say: 'People of Australia, examine our economic record. Look at what we have done as we claimed we would do at the end of 1975 as the divinely ordained economic managers.' Government members know that if people look at their record as economic managers they will finish up where they belong. What do they try to do? Once again, they try to invoke the miserable tactics of 1963 in respect of Indonesia. They try to resurrect the miserable tactics of 1966 and 1969 in regard to Vietnam. They do the worst thing that members of any political party can do, that is to attempt to represent about half the people of Australia as people who are not concerned with the security, welfare and defence of this country. They try to make people understand that members of the Opposition are not concerned with those things. The Government has not learnt from 1963 or 1966 how to be decent. It only sees that on those occasions its expediency worked in electoral terms. Fortunately, members of the Government have been such abject failures as economic managers that people will see through this miserable tactic. On behalf of the Labor Party I say: 'Go to the electorate as soon as you possibly can and you will finish up where you deserve-with miserable rumps on the Opposition benches of the Parliament.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) came into the House today to advise the chamber of the Government's belief that a small and relatively insignificant amendment should be made to a most significant piece of the Australian agreement with the United States under the ANZUS Treaty. What we have just heard from the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) is simply a quite clear election speech to make sure that next time the left wing of the Australian Labor Party caucus will support him. I remind the gentleman, who has obviously forgotten the fact, that on 12 October 1976 the Federal President of the ALP, otherwise known as Mr Bob Hawke, signed an advertisement calling for Australia to end the ANZUS military alliance.
—Is that right?

—Yes. The full page advertisement appeared in the National Times on that day, 12 October 1976. It pledges the Opposition to oppose military alliances, foreign military bases and military interventions. It went on to state that the presence of bases in Australia was somehow or other to be seen as a diminution of Australia's sovereignty and independence. The interesting thing about this is simply that at the recent conference of the ALP held in Canberra the extreme left wing demonstrated a similar tendency. For example, a certain lady spoke in the most sonorous terms. I refer to a Ms McLean. I must emphasise that I am not saying that this is Labor Party official policy. What I am saying is that the views expressed by Mr Hawke in 1976, when he was the President of the Labor Party, and now being expressed by people such as Ms McLean demonstrate the depth of conviction in the left wing of the Labor Party caucus and throughout the entire left wing organisation of this country which primarily has one view and one view alone, that is, to deny Australia the capacity to defend itself and, at the same time, to make jolly sure that the allies which have backed it in the past will not see it as a reliable ally in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) quite rightly pointed out to us that the amendments to the agreement in 1974 were carried out by none other than the Labor Minister at the time, Mr Barnard. That is true but the important thing is that in the House of Representatives on 5 May 1981 the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden)-the man who one day expects to be the Prime Minister, although I strongly doubt that he will ever make it-said:

We would seek to renegotiate the North West Cape agreement to provide, firstly, that Australia's consent is mandatory for all orders to initiate military action which flow from the station; and, secondly, that we will be given firm and convincing assurances that the station will not be used to send orders for a first-strike nuclear attack or to initiate a limited strike.

He repeated those words in other forums such as a luncheon at the National Press Club. It is quite clear that the members of the Opposition have never gone to the trouble-I include the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) when I say this-to get beyond the academic textbook when they try to consider the command and control procedures of defence. We were told by the honourable member for Wills how the Labor Government in 1942 forged the agreement with the Americans for the defence of Australia. Of course that is an historic fact but is he going to come in here-are any other honourable members of the Opposition going to come in here-and seriously suggest that we had officers sitting in the Pentagon from 1942 to 1945 looking over the shoulder of every communicator? Of course not. That is not the way one runs an alliance. It is certainly not the way to run defence and it is certainly not the way to possibly run any war.

I emphasise that the parties on this side of the chamber believe that war ultimately demonstrates the failure of diplomacy. Nobody wants a war but it is the right of this Government-it is certainly the demand of the Australian people -that the country be adequately defended. One of the elements of the defence of Australia has been the need to enter into agreements which are holding on both sides and in which both parties are prepared to believe in the veracity of the case presented by the other side. What we have simply said in this debate is that whilst the Labor Party may say that the agreement of 1963, reformed in 1974 , is the basis of their policy, there is a contradiction. The contradication has been introduced by none other than the Leader of the Opposition himself. We have the right, therefore, to suggest that the Opposition which says to the Australian people: 'trust us, we will look after your interest, we will defend Australia' in fact speaks with a forked tongue-a forked tongue which started back in 1976 when the then President of the Labor Party quite clearly and without equivocation signed a public statement denying that he wished to support the ANZUS agreement. He now comes in here today and brings up every other possible subject one could imagine in a deliberate attempt to give a smokescreen to what is the essential problem of the Opposition, its lack of credibility and its inability to present to the Australian people a cogent defence policy in which all sides, Left and Right, are prepared to say that the ANZUS agreement is fundamental to Australia's protection and security, that the agreement on the North West Cape is an integral element of that agreement and that the Australian people can have confidence in its policies. I rest my case on the simple fact that from 1976 onwards those people who lead the Labor Party today have been dishonourable and dishonest to the cause of the defence of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 15 seconds remaining I wish to express my regret that none of the previous speakers on the Government side has spoken about what this motion concerns; namely, the fact that a civil commissioner is no longer needed at Exmouth. We have this enormous-
