DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Investment in Australia-Death of Mr W. T. Arthur-Immigration-Coal Mining Industry-Search and Rescue Device-Electoral-Computerised Legal Information Retrieval System

PROCTEXT.PARA: Foreign Investment in Australia-Death of Mr W. T. Arthur-Immigration-Coal Mining Industry-Search and Rescue Device-Electoral-Computerised Legal Information Retrieval System

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday we witnessed in this House a rather stirring debate on the export of Australian fauna and flora. Interestingly, there was much bipartisan concern, which was not evident tonight on another issue, that adequate controls should have been exercised to ensure the welfare of these creatures and the preservation of species. I want to address this House tonight on another matter concerning Australian heritage. I refer to the matter of the disposal of Australian land to foreign interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreign Investment Review Board is supposed to have an adequate series of controls over the acquisition of Australian land by overseas interests. Most of this land of concern to the FIRB is land in excess of $350,000 value. What concerns me is that the Government either does not know the full extent of the foreign ownership of Australian land or does not care about it. There is little evidence that the Government is concerned about the kind of business that is growing up around this industry. Of course, this being a government which raises the practice of making a fast buck to the status of a virtue, this does not really surprise me. Nevertheless there are many who are concerned about the practices of this recently evolved industry.

The particular aspect that has been brought to my notice concerns the acquisition by Australian companies of old subdivisions in rural areas which are then sold to ill-informed buyers in foreign countries. Much of this land would come within the real estate threshold area exempting it from the major concern of the FIRB. Many of these old subdivisions were made in the nineteenth century when the areas were more densely inhabited than they are today. In my own electorate of Ballarat many were thriving gold mining townships or towns servicing rural industries.

With changed circumstances the mellow patina of age has settled on these townships and they now have that gracious quality of a bygone era which provides residents with a quality of life which is the envy of many who live in urban Australia. But they are not rapidly developing towns. Much of this land which was subdivided in the nineteenth century has reverted to rural use, to all intentions as broad acres. Other estates were subdivided latterly but the assumption was that the land would be sold in Australia.

What has happened is that some sharp operators imbued with the 'spirit of Stumpy Gully' have acquired considerable areas of land with the purposes of making a fast buck. A number of companies have gone off-shore to places such as Singapore and Malaysia with apparently attractive propositions to put to the unsuspecting and ill-informed prospective buyers from these crowded countries. As an example, in the Shire of Talbot-Clunes the Shire Secretary has informed me of his Council's concern over this matter. In that Shire over 30 such people have purchased land. As with the Shire of Grenville and the Shire of Buninyong this has introduced a number of serious problems. For example, in the Shire of Grenville there are between 20 and 25 foreign owners in rate areas. These average around $50 per block. This is what Mr Lindsay Oldham, Shire Secretary of Grenville Shire, was reported to have said by an article in the Ballarat Courier of 4 September 1981, which reads:
About 40 two hectare blocks in the Shire had been bought by overseas people through some land sharks. He said many rate notices sent to Singapore had been returned marked 'address unknown'.

It costs $150 in legal costs to reclaim those rates. This situation is repeated throughout my electorate and I am sure in many other areas as well. In Grenville Shire now about 80 to 90 blocks have been bought by foreign owners. Many of these are two hectare blocks. The average purchase price of these is $11,000. Quarter-acre blocks on the outskirts of the town are selling at between $3,000 and $4,000. This is much higher than the local market is prepared to pay. The blocks are also completely unserviced. A number of the people who bought land contacted local agents when they discovered they had been taken and were told they have no chance of recovering their outlay.

Another effect, of course, has been the artificial inflation of the price of land to local townspeople and farmers. I do not know any benefits that have been gained by these sales unless the Government can convince me that quick exorbitant profits to land sharks and a lowering of our standing overseas are seen to be benefits. The cost of serving rate notices for rate arrears and for serving fire and hazard notices and for clearing these blocks is falling upon local ratepayers when owners cannot be contacted.

There is one more serious problem that has arisen in this respect. Recently in a letter to the Secretary of the Shire of Talbot-Clunes a Mr Kok Chye Boon of Singapore has indicated that the director of a company called Property Wholesalers of Australia Ltd, of 731 Glenferrie Road, Hawthorn had given an assurance which could not be honoured. He claimed that the director of the company assured him that if he were to build a house he would be granted permanent residence in Australia. Honourable members may draw their own conclusions about the purposes of this assurance. I seek leave of the House to have this letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some six months ago a former member of this House died. His death was duly reported to the House but no eulogy was read or tributes paid in this House of the Parliament. Tributes were paid in the Senate and his friends and family were touched by them. I refer to William Tevlin Arthur, who was a member for the seat of Barton between 1966 and 1969 and who met his death on 28 February this year. I rise at this time to record that many friends of Bill Arthur, or W.T.A. as he was known to many in this Parliament and beyond, are missing his company since his tragic death. It is not my intention to take much time of the House tonight in expressing a tribute. I believe all tributes paid to him were mostly eloquently epitomised by the Reverend Canon Ian George in his address at a memorial service for Bill Arthur on 24 March 1982 at the Church of St John the Baptist, Canberra. I seek leave of the House to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of that address as a fitting valedictory in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The address by the Reverend Canon Ian George at the Church of St John The Baptist, Canberra, on Wednesday, 24th March, 1982.
Memorial Service for William Tevlin Arthur
BILL ARTHUR was born at Arncliffe, N.S.W. in 1918, and was educated at Kogarah High School.
Since 1934 he was involved with the Y.M.C.A. and was a voluntary leader since 1938.
Bill started clubs in Erskineville, Newtown and Darlington for boys who needed guidance. He visited Long Bay Gaol and went bond for a number of men who later became solid citizens.
He was a gymnastics instructor for many years and was nominated to represent Australia at the 1948 Lingiad World Gymnastics Festival in Stockholm-only held every 10 years.

In 1940 Bill joined the Australian Army as a Gunner, rising to the rank of Lieutenant. He served in New Guinea, Morotai and Borneo, and late during the war he was seconded to the Army Education Service to lecture to the troops on current affairs.

After the war, the ABC approached Bill to write and compere a series of radio coaching lessons and for some years he did this, branching out into freelance journalism, writing for many papers and magazines.
He was a champion debater from the age of 18.
Naturally these gifts and experience led him to politics. Bill was a long-time member of the Liberal Party of N.S.W., its State Council and State Executive.

He contested the Barton electorate against Dr Evatt in 1954, 1955 and 1958, coming very close to winning on one occasion. Dr Evatt held him in high regard and gave him personal letters of introduction to some of the leading people in the world when he hitch-hiked around the world in the forties and fifties.
In 1960 the US Government gave him a Smith-Mundt Leader Grant to observe the US presidential election.
In 1966 Bill won the seat of Barton and held it until 1969. Subsequently he was a Research Assistant to PM Gorton (as he then was) from 1970-71.

Bill was a member of at least 10 parliamentary committees and his speeches display the value of his overseas travel experience. They show a deep concern for people, a fear of communism and a joy in the diversity of the world's races and traditions.
No doubt some here will remember his speech in 1967 when he recounted his attempt to combat the party line given him by his guide in Moscow, apparently with some success.
Bill's emphasis was always on unity and courtesy. In one speech he refused to call people names. And all those to whom I have spoken remember him for his gentleness and honour.
Bill regarded his parliamentary duty as an awesome privilege to serve so many people in so many ways. His concern for his electorate and especially the poor, aged, sick and helpless was intense.
There are few men who have given a more constant and dedicated service to this country.

It is fitting that we should be here this morning to give thanks for his life among us-especially in the Church which contains a plaque in memory of the service given by his friendly rival, Dr Bert Evatt.
It is good to remember Bill's own faith.
We thank God for Bill Arthur and commend him into God's hands, that he may go on from strength to strength in that Kingdom which we at this time barely glimpse. . . .
Let us sing the hymn 'Now thank we all our God'
With special thanks from the Arthur Family to Mr Don Dobie for the Memorial Service in Canberra for William Tevlin Arthur.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I conclude by saying simply and with deep regret: Vale, Bill Arthur. Lest we forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise in the adjournment debate tonight a difficulty involving representations that I have taken up with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) on behalf of a constituent, a Mrs Maria Koncewica of Strathfield, who has been seeking to bring to Australia three relatives-two young women and a man-who are Polish nationals. These young people fled from Poland and are now living in a refugee camp in Vienna. In August 1981 my constituent applied for entry to Australia for these young people. She subsequently made three visits to the Sydney office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as she could obtain no information about these applications over the telephone. On 12 October 1981 my constituent wrote a letter to the Honourable Ian Macphee, the previous Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and also forwarded a copy to my predecessor as member for Lowe. Unfortunately, she received a reply to neither letter.

SPEECH.PARA: On 23 February 1982 my constituent and her husband went to the Sydney office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, as they were becoming most anxious about their Polish relatives living in the refugee camps. On this occasion departmental officers advised Mrs Koncewica to sponsor the two young people who were women. She subsequently arranged for their fares to Australia to be paid through the Australian division of the International Catholic Migration Loan Scheme. She and her husband advanced a substantial sum towards bringing to Australia the three young people plus a relative of her husband. My representations were forwarded to the new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on 20 May 1982. I have since interviewed this lady on several occasions. On 4 June the Minister kindly acknowledged my representations. Because of the worry the delay is causing my constituent, I wrote again to the Minister on 23 July. I informed him that the young man in Austria had been told that he should arrange his own fare to Australia. This was eventually arranged by telephone calls and by letter. He was then refused a visa. He was told he should wait for his cousin-one of the two young ladies-who would soon turn 18. The present Minister subsequently replied directly to my constituent that he regretted that she had not received any reply to her correspondence sent during the last year.

It is extremely difficult for me to understand why these young Polish nationals with relatives in Australia who are anxious to come to our land as refugees, with refugee status, are denied admission to Australia by petty restrictions and red tape. Initially I thought that this case may have been delayed by the accidental dumping of 600 current files from the Sydney office of the Minister's Department, which was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 24 July. Now, however, I believe that the delay is occurring in Vienna. I know that the World Assembly on Ageing was held in Vienna in July and that a Minister and a large Australian delegation attended. I know that in August an Australian deputation attended the United Nations Conference on Outer Space, also in Vienna. However, such conferences should not delay the important work of the Embassy; that is, the processing of refugees from Poland who wish to settle in Australia.

These young people are fleeing from an oppressive government. The free world salutes and admires Solidarity and this Government has made some show of helping the Polish people. Regrettably, these young Poles living in a refugee camp in Vienna have been forgotten by the Australian Government. They are desplaced persons, they are away from their homes, families, and loved ones. They have nowhere to go, and they cannot obtain full time employment. I ask the Minister to investigate this matter, to examine these cases sympathetically and to take every possible action to bring these young people to Australia to be with their relatives as soon as possible. The conditions in the refugee camp are very difficult. I have raised this matter tonight not to embarrass the Minister but in an effort to obtain at long last some action for my constituent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are still experiencing considerable trouble in the coal mining industry in the Hunter Valley which I have the honour of representing. This week the general manager of Drayton Coal Pty Ltd, Mr Darcy Wentworth, expressed grave concern that the company's colliery in the Hunter Valley had not been able to commence operations. For six months the company has been prevented from employing mine workers. The executive has worked patiently to overcome the union ban on hiring labour. Two weeks ago, after long negotiations led by the Premier of New South Wales and the national leaders of the mining unions, agreement was reached to start mining. However, miners have not been allowed to sign on at Drayton. This is a great shame. It prevents this magnificant mine from starting operations. Drayton has vacancies for 145 men who could start work immediately and total employment would be approximately 400 people if the colliery were allowed to reach its full potential. We have unemployed people; and here would be an opportunity for them to gain employment if the union would approve the commencement of operations at this mine.

SPEECH.PARA: If the mine's customers do not receive Drayton's steaming coal they are likely to buy coal from the United States, Canada, South Africa or perhaps, Queensland rather than from other Hunter Valley mines. We are not the only people who are marketing coal. We have opposition from the United States of America, Canada, South Africa, Brazil and other sources. The Hunter Valley's credibility as a coal producer has diminished in the last two years largely through industrial action resulting in a lack of port throughput. Now, when shipments through the Newcastle port have improved, failure to supply Drayton's customers will again raise doubts about New South Wales as a reliable export coal producer. There would be financial losses to the community in the area through the loss of wages and jobs and to New South Wales through the loss of royalties, taxes, rail freights and port charges.

Drayton colliery has firm contracts with customers in Japan, Korea and Europe. Construction began in 1980, after all necessary Government approvals were obtained, and the first shipment was due in October 1982. Owing to the union intervention, the company will certainly not be able to complete its first shipment of coal, which it had contracted to do. One Japanese customer, Kyushu Electric, was depending on Drayton as the sole imported source of coal for their Minato Power station which was recently converted from oil to coal. Drayton therefore will not meet its first shipment to Kyushu and unless mining commences shortly, this mine will not be able to satisfy other contracts which start in January 1983. What a shameful state of affairs to think that nothing is being done when we have an opportunity for employment, an opportunity for this mine to start operating and provide markets overseas for which it has contracts. I say shame on the unions involved because they are causing a problem which certainly should not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure all honourable members who were in the House this morning were impressed by the device that was displayed to us by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron), a device which could be of assistance to search and rescue vessels which are distressed at sea. Unfortunately the device which was displayed by the honourable member for Fadden has already been superseded. The device was perfected by a constituent of mine, a Mr Laurie Bevan who lives in the town of Scamander on the east coast of Tasmania. He invented a device which does much more to aid in search and rescue than the device that was displayed today by the honourable member for Fadden.
—Show us the device.

—Unfortunately, I cannot show it to the honourable member. That is one of the problems that I wish to raise in the House tonight. The device has already been accepted for patent in Australia, the patent number being 486576. The device has been listed for a world patent. Mr Bevan has been working on this device for a number of years because of his concern about the cost involved in search and rescue and the number of lives that can be lost at sea. In his own time and with very little assistance he has perfected a device that will aid in all forms of search and rescue at sea.

SPEECH.PARA: The device which Mr Bevan has quite ingeniously invented is one that can be attached to the deck of a vessel but can be activated only when it floats. As with the device that was shown to us this morning by the honourable member for Fadden it will be activated when it is turned upside down. When it floats it turns upside down and automatically activates a radio signal which has a 70 mile transmission, unlike the device that was shown to us by the honourable member for Fadden. It also has a flashing light that can be of assistance for night search and rescue. In addition to that the device is attached by a lead line to the deck of the vessel so that in the subsequent event of the vessel sinking, it can assist in the recovery at a later stage, if that proves to be feasible. Taken all round, I think that the House would have to agree that the device that Mr Laurie Bevan has invented has an all-round attraction for use in search and rescue and must supersede the device that was shown to us by the honourable member for Fadden.

I think all honourable members would have to agree that this device could be of immense value to search and rescue around the Australian coastline and could certainly help in reducing the number of lives lost at sea and with the recovery of vessels in distress. The difficulty that Mr Bevan is facing at the moment is that the fishing industry and those engaged in it are very keen to have this device attached to their vessels. What would be of great assistance in having this device marketed commercially would be for the cost of the device to be accepted by the Government as an allowable tax deductible item. That undoubtedly would be an incentive to fishermen and other owners of small craft to have this device attached to their vessels. Naturally in the case of distressed vessels the fitting of such a device must save a lot of money in the cost of search and rescue, not to mention the saving of lives.

Mr Bevan has suggested also that it would be of value to the insurance companies to provide a lesser premium for marine insurance to those vessels that have this device attached. The recovery at a later stage of a vessel would naturally be a saving to the insurance industry. I urge that the Government accepts the device that Mr Bevan has invented, that it does provide these incentives for it to be marketed commercially and that we give Mr Bevan every encouragement to further the development and marketing of his device.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Dawson, which is a rural electorate, is one of 19 electorates in the State of Queensland. Being a rural electorate it has an entitlement to a 10 per cent tolerance in the number of electors below that of the average of metropolitan seats. From the statistics for the Queensland seats which are recorded in the table just incorporated, I find that Dawson, besides being the fourth largest in area of all the electorates, has the fourth largest average annual growth factor at 3.48 per cent per annum; the fifth largest population of 136,735 and the seventh largest enrolment of voters of 73,458.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last three mentioned factors, the electorates that are consistently ahead of Dawson are the seats of McPherson, Fadden and Fisher, all held by the Government. Three of the electorates, which are Brisbane seats held by Labor- namely Brisbane, Griffith and Lilley-have negative growth rates of 1.24 per cent , 1.07 per cent and 1.09 per cent respectively. The populations on the 1981 figures for these three Labor electorates were between 93,464 and 103,078 compared with Dawson's population of 136,735. The voters who were enrolled totalled between 64,535 and 67,087 again compared with 73,458 in Dawson. One could possibly traverse the Brisbane electorates in half an hour, while to cross Dawson takes about eight hours by car. The figures suggest that the number of constituents is building up in rural seats to an extent that the 10 per cent tolerance is in reverse and is contrary to the provisions of the existing Electoral Act.

When Labor members talk about gerrymanders in Queensland they may care to look at the situation of the federal seats. Certainly there is a massive gerrymander that favours the Australian Labor Party. All seats held by it except two have negative growth factors; all those seats have fewer constituents to serve; and all of them are pocket size when compared in area to the constituency of Dawson. I believe that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and the Government should look carefully at the predicament of a constituent in Dawson who is placed at a distinct disadvantage in trying to get equal representation for his inequal vote as compared with electors in Brisbane seats. In mentioning the electorate of Dawson, I believe that it is important for the House to realise that the electorate is responsible for between 6 per cent to 7 per cent of Australia's exports, making it one of the wealthiest and progressive of electorates in Australia. This explains its average annual growth and the increasing population. It is an electorate of opportunity for those who wish to work.

During this adjournment debate, I pay a member's tribute to Dawson's coal industry which supplies approximately 20 million tonnes of coal to the export market. I also acknowledge the tripartite approach of unions and State and Federal governments in keeping the Bowen Basin coal industry alive and alert as compared with the industry in New South Wales where mines are closing and export markets are being lost as described by my colleague the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) just a few moments ago. The unions, in putting forward their log of wage claims for annual review, scaled down their claims to a 2 per cent increase. I believe that this is a very positive and realistic approach to wage claims and would applaud the unions involved for their positive contribution in a difficult situation.

Last month the Federal Government played its part by removing the levy of $1 per tonne of steaming coal, accelerating the depreciation write off for new plant and equipment, and retaining the investment allowance. This will allow intending mining companies to rewrite their cash flow projections and some ventures that previously could not have commenced can now do so. The State governments of New South Wales and Queensland announced separate measures to encourage investment. These ranged from lesser infrastructure requirements, longer lead time for payment of up front contributions and a new look at royalties and rail freights. Unfortunately for some this package was too late. Some companies have shelved projects or ceased projects because too many fingers were in the honey pot, that is, until the honey pot dried up. I hope that the example of the Utah miners in accepting lesser increases may be followed by the whole of the Australian work force in this present stagnant industrial situation . Those who are responsible in Queensland at this very time for the lack of essential services and blackouts might reassess their position accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note, Mr Deputy Speaker, that not one member of the Australian Labor Party is in the chamber at this time. I wish to refer once again to computerised legal information retrieval systems in Australia. On two previous occasions, I have raised this matter in the House. I do so now following recent developments especially in Victoria but also in New South Wales which are of such concern that the matter warrants the attention of the Government, all honourable members and, in particular, the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack).

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that the Victorian Government acting on its own initiative, and without the full agreement of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, issued an invitation for proposals to set up a State- controlled monopoly Computer Legal Information Retrieval System-CLIRS-in the State. The New South Wales Government subsequently issued a similarly worded invitation. No public announcement of a decision has been made, but it is known that Victoria is currently negotiating with one company to set up the monopoly and that New South Wales is currently working towards making a similar decision. There are indications that the two States will appoint the same operator, effectively creating a national monopoly. This situation will be of great concern to this Government, since a monopoly operation, whether State by State or national, is contrary to the Government's policy. The present position clearly will result in active Government control over the dissemination of legal materials which, by tradition under our system of law, should be in the public domain, and which should, all members would agree, be as free from restriction of access as is possible.

It is pertinent to note by examining legislation recently introduced into the Victorian Parliament the degree of control that is envisaged. The legislation to amend the Council of Law Reporting in Victoria Act would make it unlawful:
To publish the whole or any part of reports of judicial decisions of any court in Victoria. . . . .

This amendment has enormous implications. It purports to cover federal tribunals sitting in Victoria, as well as Victorian tribunals exercising federal jurisdiction. It could be used to stop the reporting of Victorian judicial decisions in the Press, and stop the summarising or discussion of cases in learned journals or text books. It could even be used to stop anybody quoting from Victorian decisions, as the Act has no fair dealing provisions, as in the Copyright Act. It retrospectively takes away from authors the rights to publish freely materials they have written about cases heard in Victoria. It will enable a body such as the Council for Law Reporting in Victoria, which has already tried to levy royalties on case books for students, to start levying royalties on any text book or looseleaf service that merely quotes or discusses a judicial decision heard in Victoria.

Any legislation such as this should be soundly condemned by all, especially as it was introduced into the Victorian Parliament without general public debate. The Australian in its editorial on 31 July 1982 described this amendment as an ' intolerable attack on the freedom of the press'. The fact that the legislation is deemed necessary, when the Crown and Council purport to hold copyright in Victorian judgments, statutes and regulations, would indicate that the real purpose of the legislation may be to protect the monopoly operator from any competition whatsoever, whether in hard copy or electronic form, or to make other legal publication services, such as the well known loose leaf services, slower and more expensive to produce, and so make the monopoly computerised service more price competitive. A more sinister use of the legislation would be its use to suppress information or discussion about judicial hearings that were adverse to the interests of the government of the day.

All honourable members and the Government should soundly condemn legislation of this type, and condemn the move by New South Wales and Victoria to establish government controlled monopoly operations when private enterprise operators have shown their willingness to provide these services and to operate in a competitive market at no expense to government. In view of the Commonwealth Government's stated position that there ought to be more than one system, and that there ought to be competition in the market, I again urge the Attorney- General to take urgent steps to open access to cases, statutes and regulations, to encourage, and not hinder, private enterprise initiatives in the provision of computerised legal services, and to make a public statement of the Commonwealth Government's intentions in this regard. I also urge that the Commonwealth ensures that the public has unhindered access to the law by exercise of its powers under section 51 (xxv) of the Constitution, which enables Parliament to make laws with respect to 'the recognition throughout the Commonwealth of the laws, the public Acts and records, and the judicial proceedings of the States', and section 51 (xviii), which relates to copyright.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 10.30 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why are the 'broader financial aggregates', M4, M5, etc, not published regularly.
(2) As these more broadly defined money supply figures are mentioned from time to time in official publications, are they regarded by the Government as significant.
(3) What has been the rate of growth of M4, M5 and M6 (seasonally adjusted if such series exist) over the previous 3 months at an annualised rate in each month since January 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For some years, studies have been undertaken within the Reserve Bank, the Treasury and elsewhere, with a view to compiling aggregates which might assist a broader analysis of financial developments that can be derived from narrower aggregates such as M1, M2 and M3. Such studies have revealed difficulties in both the measurement and interpretation of such broader aggregates, including those which have been termed M4, M5. Until those difficulties have been resolved , such aggregates need to be treated with caution. For these reasons, the Reserve Bank has not to date seen it as appropriate to publish a time series of broader aggregates of this kind. It does, however, publish a range of information on the public's holding of claims against non-bank financial institutions, based on statistics collected under the Financial Corporations Act ; these comprise data from which various broader financial aggregates (including M4, M5 and M6) can be compiled.

(2) On occasions, broader aggregates have been mentioned in official publications to highlight monetary developments not adequately captured by the standard measure M3. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to growing concern among service and ex- service personnel regarding the declining value of Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits and Defence Force Retirement Benefits pensions because of delays in payment of cost of living increases.
(2) Are increases one year behind consumer price index adjustment figures, thus causing pensions to be paid at a rate below that which would apply if current figures were used.
(3) In view of the high level of inflation is annual adjustment adequate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware that there are delays in effecting payment of the statutory annual increases to pension, which are based on movements in the consumer price index.

(2) No. DFRB and DFRDB pensions are increased in July each year in line with the movement in the consumer price index for the 12 month period ending in March that year. This allows the first instalment of pension at the increased rate to be paid on the first payday in July. To use any later CPI figures would cause payment of the increased pension to be commenced from a correspondingly later date.

(3) The present frequency of updating DFRB and DFRDB pensions was introduced following an independent non-parliamentary inquiry by Professor A. H. Pollard into the methods of adjusting Commonwealth Superannuation and Defence Force Retirement Benefit Fund pensions after retirement.

Professor Pollard's recommendations that Commonwealth sponsored pensions be updated annually in line with movements in the consumer price index, was accepted by the Government and implemented through the Defence Force (Retirement and Death Benefit Amendments) Act 1977.
It is worth noting that most State Government schemes provide for annual updating of pensions as do those private sector pension schemes that update pensions regularly.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Had DFRDB and DFRB pensions been adjusted on a bi-annual basis for the financial year 1981-82 the additional amount of pension payments would have been (a) DFRDB $2.53m, (b) DFRB $1.09m.
The additional administrative cost in making the adjustments has been assessed at $25,000.

However, in keeping with the Government's even-handed approach to all its previous employees, a change to bi-annual adjustments of DFRB and DFRDB pensions would need to be extended to all Commonwealth pensions. The total cost would be substantial and could not be justified in the present economic climate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated cost of converting all Defence Force Retirement Benefit pension entitlements at 1 April 1982 to the entitlement available under the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme for the like service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A study carried out in 1979 to estimate the cost of converting all existing DFRB pensions to their DFRDB equivalent, indicates that the cost, at present day values, would be in excess of $12m (including retrospectivity to 1 October 1972) . The ongoing costs would be in the order of $2m per annum. In addition there would be a considerable cost associated with the implementation of any such proposal which could not be quantified at the moment.
However, if the thought behind the honourable member's question is that such a conversion would be desirable if financially practical then I would bring the following to his attention.

The 1979 study also indicated that the adoption of such a proposal would mainly benefit retired senior officers. It was found that two-thirds of the estimated $ 12m would be apportioned among 6% of the total number of DFRB pensioners.

In 1976, following the transfer of the assets of the DFRB fund to the Commonwealth, an actuarial investigation revealed an excess with accumulated interest of $8.3m which was distributed amongst all DFRB pensions. If there was to be any recalculation of pensions payable to DFRB pensioners, the justification for the distribution of the $8.3m would need to be re-examined.

Beneficiaries under occupational superannuation schemes generally are paid on their retirement the benefits for which they contributed during service in accordance with the rules and conditions of the scheme applying to them at that time. There would need to be the most compelling reasons to depart from this principle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1982 (Hansard, page 2023) Mr Kerin asked me a question without notice. His question concerned, inter alia, the importation of rice which may not be disease free and the quarantine and hygiene measures required for such imports.

ANSWER.PARA: I have taken up this matter with the Minister for Health and now advise as follows:
Unmilled rice and rice straw are prohibited entry into Australia because of the risk of introducing exotic diseases.

Milled rice may be imported under quarantine control to ensure it is free of pests and diseases. There is a permissible tolerance of 5 grains paddy and/or hulls per kg of imported milled rice which was accepted by the rice industry in 1978 as being in line with Australian milling standards.

My colleague, the Minister for Health, who is responsible for quarantine matters, is aware of the allegations and concern expressed by the rice industry . He has had these matters investigated and is satisfied that quarantine standards agreed to in consultation with the rice industry are satisfactory and are being rigidly followed. However, he has agreed to reconvene a meeting of industry and quarantine representatives to reconsider the tolerance in the light of present Australian milling standards.

Any representations from primary industry groups concerning quarantine risks associated with imports are carefully investigated by the Minister for Health. I am assured that Australia's high quarantine standards are being maintained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the practice of the Capital Territory Health Commission to compile dossiers on staff, by means of tape recordings and interviews, which are alleged to contain damning evidence on individuals and to which individuals have no access.
(2) Are locked single rooms used for seclusion of mental retardation residents in Australian Capital Territory hostels operated by the CTHC; if so, what is the basis for adopting this practice.
(3) What formal qualifications are hostel managers of Intellectually Handicapped Hostels expected to hold prior to appointment to the position.
(4) What formal training is presently given to hostel managers within IHS.
(5) When will the proposed Mental Health Ordinance be enacted in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes. There are occasional instances when it is necessary to protect intellectually handicapped children from the possible consequences of aggressive or disruptive behavior on the part of a fellow resident. In these circumstances, a child who is placing others at risk is separated in a quiet room for a period of time not exceeding 5 minutes during which time the resident is under constant external surveillance. Strict records are kept of all such occurrences.

The need for a period of quiet segregation is generally acknowledged by members of the professions concerned with the care of intellectually handicapped children and is generally supported by the parents of residents in the Commission's hostels. Temporary separation is considered to be the only reasonable response in some cases of violently aggressive behaviour, particularly in a situation in which other children, smaller or more frail, may be at risk.

(3) No formal qualifications are prescribed for hostel managers. However, substantial previous experience with the intellectually handicapped, preferably in a residential envirionment, is required. Desirable formal qualifications include basic and post-basic nursing qualifications in mental retardation or psychiatric nursing.

(4) There is a one year special care course conducted by the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education in co-operation with the Commission for the training of hostel staff, including managers. It is intended that all hostel staff will have the opportunity to take this course. No other formal training is given to hostel managers. The Canberra College of Technical and Further Education also conducts a Certificate level Course in Special Care.

(5) The draft Mental Health Ordinance was referred to the Australian Capital Territory of Assembly for advice. The Assembly agreed in principle to the draft ordinance and recommended that a number of amendments be made to the draft. Comments on the draft Ordinance are being sought from the Human Rights Commission. It is intended that the Ordinance be made during 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a letter dated 2 April 1981 from the Australian Council for Overseas Aid to the Prime Minister.

(2) If so, does the letter (a) support Brandt Report conclusions that 'North' countries will lose living standards if they continue to exploit the 'South', even though the rich in all countries get richer and (b) list urgent support for Brandt Report proposals including, (i) a public education program, (ii) a target date of 1985 to reach 0.7% of Gross National Product in aid, (iii) a larger share of aid for farm and energy research, (iv) more sympathy for third world proposals, (v) an Industries Assistance Commission study of effects of protection on the third world, (vi) more liberal World Bank and International Monetary Fund lending, (vii) a United Nations evaluation of international taxation, (viii) United Nations negotiations for a trans-national corporations' code of conduct and, (ix) 0.1% of defence spending to go to arms control and disarmament: about $3.8 million perhaps for a Peace and Development Studies centre, upgraded departmental work in this field, public education, research on disarmament verification and support for the United Nations Centre for Disarmament.
(3) What response has the Government made to each point in part 2 and when were the responses made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The letter was an open letter and was circulated by ACFOA to various members of parliament including myself.

(2) (a) The Brandt Report emphasises the increasing interdependence between the North and the South and draws attention to the dimensions of poverty and the differing development needs of countries in the South. the Report appeals to the common interest of all governments in international economic arrangements which would promote more rapid development of the poorer countries. The ACFOA letter ' regards the Brandt Report as presenting a constructive and helpful package of proposals' while conceding that 'not all of the Report's proposals will be practicable or achievable'.
(b) Yes. The ACFOA letter lists nine specific proposals, as summarised in the question, from the Brandt Report which it regards as meriting urgent Government action.

(3) (i) The Government acknowledges the important role a public education program can play in creating an awareness and understanding within the community of international development issues and informing people about the Government's program of official development assistance to developing countries. The Australian Development Assistance Bureau provides information on Australia's official aid program to the Australian community and information on North-South issues is also disseminated through Department of Foreign Affairs publications. In 1981-82 expenditure on ADAB's information program is estimated at $63,000 to cover the production of a number of essential publications including reports, occasional papers, statistical data and information leaflets on particular aspects of the aid program.

(ii) The Government continues to endorse the internationally accepted aid target of 0.7% of GNP, and will endeavour to maintain its official development assistance at the highest level consistent with the needs of developing countries and Australia's economic and budgetary circumstances.

(iii) The Government recognises the importance of agricultural and energy research to the future development of third world countries. Agricultural research relevant to the needs of developing countries is fostered through research components in a number of bilateral agricultural projects supported by Australia. Assistance is also given to several international and regional research programs, principally through support to the 12 international institutes which operate under the aegis of the Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research (CGIAR).

In addition, an Australian Centre for Agricultural Research (ACIAR) has been established in 1981-82. The Centre is to provide a means for Australian institutions to undertake research on problems of importance to agricultural production in developing countries. The Centre will also encourage closer collaboration between Australian institutions and international agricultural research centres.

The Government recognises that international efforts need to be made to tackle the global energy problem and the particular problems of non-oil producing developing countries. Australia has been active in promoting regional initiatives designed to assist developing countries in their attempts to reduce dependence on imported oil. We fund the Commonwealth Regional Renewable Energy Resources Information Service (CRRERIS) and other activities established under the CHOGRM Energy Group. We have been active in promoting and have recently organised discussion on increased coal utilisation for ASEAN countries. Australia funded an energy planning workshop in Papua New Guinea in July 1981 for some twenty developing countries in the region and was a major contributor to the ESCAP Secretariat's study into the particular energy problems of the ESCAP region. In December 1982 Australia will host a UN Symposium on Coal for Electricity Generation in Developing Countries. The symposium, which will be held in Sydney and Newcastle, will be attended by some 32 countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America. Finally, the Government supports the establishment of an energy affiliate in the World Bank.

(iv) Australia is sensitive to the concerns of developing countries and is sympathetic to third world proposals for overcoming the mass poverty and deprivation existing in these countries. Australia has taken concrete steps in various fields, such as energy, food and agriculture and trade in an effort to assist developing countries solve the development problems facing them. The developing countries have attached a high priority to launching a round of global negotiations on trade, raw materials, energy, development and money and finance. At the international level agreement has not been reached on the terms of an enabling resolution to launch these global negotiations but consultations are proceeding in New York and elsewhere. Australia has played an important role in attempts to reach agreement on global negotiations.

(v) Australia is fully aware of the need for there to be an international trading environment directed to stimulating growth in world trade and beneficial to all countries, including particularly developing countries. We have emphasised the importance of a balanced international approach to reductions in levels of protection and have, more specifically, pointed to the need for international action to combat non-tariff obstacles to trade and to reduce levels of agricultural protection. These measures, if successful, would be of considerable practical benefit to developing countries and would assist them in sustaining their development programs. The Australian Government has been and is involved in a number of reviews examining the effects of trade protection on developing countries. For example, the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne established an expert Study Group on the impact of protectionism on developing countries. This Study Group is expected to complete its report later this year. Domestically, the Industries Assistance Commission's various reports on levels of protection in Australia have inter alia been considered in the context of the impact of protection on our relations with other countries, including developing countries.

(vi) During the 1970s the international financial institutions expanded and adopted their activities to meet changing economic circumstances. Australia has supported this evolution of their programs. We will continue to support soundly based improvement in the international financial institutions, in particular the IMF and the World Bank, which are of benefit to developing countries, while maintaining the basic roles of those institutions.

(vii) The Government is aware of a number of proposals concerning international taxation, the proceeds of which would be devoted to development assistance. The weight of expert assessment is that such proposals have substantial disadvantages, both of a conceptual and practical/administrative nature. Automatic transfers deriving from international taxation have far-reaching implications for relations among nations. A commitment to the principle of international taxation by levies on activities of sovereign states would involve a degree of derogation of sovereignty which most countries at this stage are unable to accept. For these reasons, the Government has serious doubts that a special UN study would assist in overcoming the essential problems associated with international taxation proposals. It would prefer international attention to concentrate more on other measures to assure volume and continuity of funds for economic development.

(viii) Australia is not currently a member of the UN Commission on Transnational Corporations, or of the working group on the Code of Conduct ( which has been established by that Commission). While this limits Australia's ability to participate actively in the negotiations to draw up a universally acceptable code, the Australian Government has supported the concept of such a code. The Government has constantly demonstrated its willingness to co-operate with the Centre for Transnational Corporations by responding as fully as possible to its requests for information and statistics. Collection of statistics on foreign investment in Australia by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, as requested by ACFOA, has recommenced following a recent review by the Government.

(ix) The allocation of defence spending is decided in the context of many competing demands. With limited resources available, the Government has to decide on priorities. Defence spending is properly within the portfolio of the Minister for Defence and matters relating to this subject should be referred to him.

(c) In 1980/81 the load factor on each route as a whole was 44.8 per cent for Townsville/Mt Isa and 51.2 per cent for Brisbane/Central Queensland. Similar load factors might be expected in future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) recommended that the estuarine crocodile (Crocodylus porosus) should be removed from Appendix I of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) and placed in Appendix II.
(2) What are the most recent estimates of the population of the estuarine crocodile in (a) the Northern Territory, (b) Queensland and (c) Western Australia.

(3) How many people have been convicted of (a) illegally shooting estuarine crocodiles, (b) selling crocodile skins, (c) exporting crocodile skins and (d) processing crocodile skins in Australia, during each of the years 1979, 1980 and 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, CONCOM at its Hobart meeting in June 1982 supported the recommendation of a specialist working group to transfer the Australian population of the estuarine crocodile from Appendix I to Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).

(2) No detailed overall estimates are available. The Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australian Wildlife Authorities have provided the following estimates (largely based on surveys conducted on tidal rivers in 1979 by Professor Messel).
(a) For the Northern Territory the estimate is 10,000 animals plus hatchlings which comprise about 25 per cent of the non-hatchling population.

(b) In Queensland surveys of approximately 642 kilometres of four river systems in south western Cape York Peninsula, the Port Musgrave system and the Escape River in Northern Cape York Peninsula gave an estimate of 1,000 animals.
(c) For Western Australia the estimate is 2000 animals with about 500 hatchlings.
(3) (a) None.
(b) None.
(c) None.
(d) None.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights: Report by Mr Barry Rowlands, Q.C.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) organisations, Aboriginal or white, (b) State Government bodies, and (c) individuals were forwarded by the Minister or his Department a copy of the report by Mr Barry Rowlands, Q.C., entitled 'Examination of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976-80' with a request for comment on the report.
(2) When was each request for comment made, who has replied to date and what was the date of each reply.
(3) When will the Minister make a statement to the Parliament outlining the Government's response to this report.
(4) Will the Minister make available to members and senators, on request, copies of all comments received by him to date.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Copies of the report were sent on 18 November 1980 for information and with a request for comment to:
Tiwi Land Council, Northern Territory
Northern Land Council, Northern Territory
Central Land Council, Northern Territory
Chief Minister, Northern Territory

The report was also widely distributed for information to members of parliament and industry, and it was publicly available through all offices of my Department in the Northern Territory, as well as the Department's regional offices in the States.
(2) Written responses were not received.
(3) The then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, made a statement to Parliament when tabling the report on 2 December 1980.

Following publication of the report the Northern Territory Government forwarded to my predecessor and to the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Councils a submission entitled 'Examination of Land Rights Legislation.

Negotiations between the Aboriginal Land Councils, the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory Government have taken place since March 1981 concerning possible amendments to the legislation. These negotiations deal with issues raised in the Rowland report.
(4) Members and senators wishing to receive copies of the Northern Territory Government's submissions may wish to direct such requests to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Herbicides in South East Asia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister or his Department obtained a copy of the United States Office of Air Force History report entitled 'Operation Ranch Hand: The Air Force and Herbicides in South East Asia 1961-1967'; if not, will he now do so.
(2) If a copy is available, will he table it in the Parliament; if not, why not .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) My Department and I are aware of press reports concerning a document prepared by the United States Office of Air Force History bearing a title similar to that quoted. The Office of Air Force History report on Operation Ranch Hand was released in the United States on 11 August 1982 and copies have been requested to be made available through the Parliamentary Library.
